title: Naming and definitions
ai_summary: Naming and defining concepts is crucial for clear communication, shared understanding, and memory retention. Proper definitions enhance precision and learning, while effective naming transcends language barriers and preserves knowledge for future generations.
body:
Why is naming always important? In the future, you might need to understand it without having a lexicon. A chair can be named a chair. There is a reason for that. We call communicate without translation.
Autor: Cincdntg DNL
![[naming.webp]]

## Perplexity

https://www.perplexity.ai/search/easy-to-understand-text-about-8aNYirNBQmyF9IYnPl4G3w
### The Importance of Naming and Definitions
Naming and defining things is a fundamental aspect of human communication and understanding. Let‚Äôs explore why it‚Äôs so crucial in an easy-to-understand way.
### Why Naming Matters
1. **Clear Communication**: When we give something a name, we can easily refer to it in conversations. For example, calling a chair a ‚Äúchair‚Äù allows everyone to understand what we‚Äôre talking about.
2. **Shared Understanding**: Names create a common ground for people to discuss ideas, objects, or concepts without confusion.
3. **Memory Aid**: Names help us remember and categorize things in our minds. It‚Äôs easier to recall ‚Äúchair‚Äù than ‚Äúthat thing we sit on with four legs and a back.‚Äù
### The Power of Definitions
1. **Precision**: Definitions explain what something is, helping to avoid misunderstandings. For instance, a chair is ‚Äúa separate seat for one person, typically with a back and four legs.‚Äù
2. **Learning**: Good definitions help us learn about new things quickly and accurately.
3. **Consistency**: When everyone agrees on a definition, it ensures we‚Äôre all talking about the same thing.
### Universal Communication
1. **Beyond Language Barriers**: Well-chosen names and clear definitions can often transcend language differences. For example, a chair‚Äôs function is understood globally, even if the word for it differs.
2. **Future-Proofing Knowledge**: By naming and defining things clearly, we preserve knowledge for future generations who might not have the same context we do.
3. **Avoiding Confusion**: Proper naming and definitions reduce the need for constant explanation or translation, making communication more efficient.

In essence, naming and defining things well is like creating a shared language that helps us understand our world and each other better, both now and in the future.

## Reference

Here are some references to papers and books on the topic of naming and definitions:
Sager, J. C. (1990). A Practical Course in Terminology Processing. John Benjamins Publishing.
This book provides an in-depth look at terminology and naming practices, including the importance of clear definitions.
W√ºster, E. (1991). Einf√ºhrung in die allgemeine Terminologielehre und terminologische Lexikographie. INFOTERM.
A seminal work on terminology theory that discusses principles of naming and defining concepts.
Temmerman, R. (2000). Towards New Ways of Terminology Description: The Sociocognitive-Approach. John Benjamins Publishing.
This book examines sociocognitive approaches to terminology and naming, emphasizing the importance of context.
Cabr√©, M. T. (1999). Terminology: Theory, Methods and Applications. John Benjamins Publishing.
A comprehensive overview of terminology theory and practice, including naming principles and definition writing.

1. Kageura, K. (2002). The Dynamics of Terminology: A Descriptive Theory of Term Formation and Terminological Growth. John Benjamins Publishing.

This work looks at how terms and names evolve over time in specialized domains.

1. Faber, P. (Ed.). (2012). A Cognitive Linguistics View of Terminology and Specialized Language. Walter de Gruyter.

A collection of papers examining cognitive approaches to terminology and specialized naming practices.

title: cause effect
ai_summary: Understanding cause and effect is crucial for professional growth. Key questions to consider include measuring success, decision-making, potential consequences, desired outcomes, and the probability of those consequences. What control questions do you use?
body:
Learning about Cause ‚Üí Effect is your most underrated skill to elevate in your profession.

![[Cause-Effect.png]]
Learning about Cause ‚Üí Effect and the consequences of a decision is your most underrated skill to elevate in your profession.

To get into the mood, try to ask questions like:
- How do we **measure** success?
- What **decision** do we need to take?
- What could the **consequences** be?
- What is the **outcome** we are looking for?
- What is the **probability** of the consequences?
- Are you sure the **success** is the Cause of your decision?

It‚Äôs an excellent start to understand better why we are doing things.
I‚Äôm curious: what control questions do you use?

Inspiration_

[https://www.linkedin.com/posts/florian-hameister_innovation-productdevelopment-customercentric-activity-7153294549920940032-A7lp?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/florian-hameister_innovation-productdevelopment-customercentric-activity-7153294549920940032-A7lp?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop)

title: Dont make easy things hard
ai_summary: Simplicity is key in delivering professional results; making things complicated is easy, but true expertise lies in keeping things straightforward.
body:
![[Complex_Machine.webp]]
Some would argue that if it isn‚Äôt simple, it isn‚Äôt a hobby. If I ever built a juice machine, I would probably have this freak monster in mind.
But when we deliver to our customers, they do not ask for hobbyists or amateurs. They ask for professionals, and professionals don‚Äôt make easy things hard.
Dave Trott said:
-Any idiot can make something complicated.
Don‚Äôt be an idiot :-)

[[Complicated vs Complex]]

title: Challenge A word I really dislike when used in the wrong context
ai_summary: Using the term "challenge" to describe problems created for customers is misleading; companies should take responsibility and acknowledge their mistakes instead of deflecting blame. An example highlights this misuse from a Swedish IT vendor after a hacking incident. The real challenge is to stop using euphemisms to avoid accountability.
body:
You can use it for many things, but here‚Äôs when it goes wrong: When you mess up and call it a challenge for your customers.
No.¬†That‚Äôs not a challenge for them‚Äîit‚Äôs a problem you created. Take responsibility. Own it. Say, ‚Äúwe apologise for the storm your customers are now having to endure.‚Äù
A quote I remember from a large IT vendor in Sweden after they were hacked, causing weeks of downtime:
‚ÄúWe sincerely apologise for the challenges this attack is causing our customers and everyone affected.‚Äù

This wasn‚Äôt their customers‚Äô challenge. It was the company‚Äôs problem, and it should‚Äôve been addressed as such.
The real challenge? Stop using this word to avoid responsibility when it‚Äôs your issue to fix.
Questions on this?

---

title: Back to basics
ai_summary: Visiting family in Sweden offers a peaceful connection to nature, with activities like fishing and snowmobiling, providing a much-needed break from everyday life and a reminder of the importance of simplicity. The fish caught made for an excellent lunch.
body:
A few times a year, I travel north to Sweden and visit my family‚Äôs old house from the late 1800s. There, the whole family accepts what we have at the moment.

A few people still live here, and it‚Äôs always fun to fish whenever we are here. In winter, we go by Snowmobile and in the summer, by canoe.

My kids love being near nature, and with a fire outside, there is a calm that I seldom get in our everyday lives.

I believe that it has to do with what humans sometimes need: being close to nature, being close to the basics, and not complicating things.

I hope that this feeling lasts for a long time.

By the way, the fish were an excellent lunch today.

title: Why you shouldnt use Processes for mapping software requirement
ai_summary: Processes may hinder flexibility in mapping software requirements; instead, focus on defining capabilities and outcomes without strict sequences, allowing for adaptability to market needs.
body:
Processes can be good if you have something repetitive and without too many deviations. In the real world, there are sometimes only deviations.
A process also describes HOW we do things, which can differ from the new system you want to buy.
When we say, ‚ÄúFirst, I do a, then b, then c,‚Äù that is how the new system will operate. I think we need to flexibility to say that I need to be able to start with b, go from b to a to c, or add a new step between b and c whenever the market requires it.
Suppose I split everything to Lego parts and describe WHAT we need to do. And we take, e.g.¬†‚Äúregister a new customer‚Äù If we break that down, one part can be ‚Äúadd customer contact data‚Äù and another ‚Äúadd a product/service to the customer. And what is important is that you don‚Äôt set them in a specific order. That can be done later.
The next requirement is to understand what information we need in each of our Lego blocks. For e.g.¬†CUSTOMER should include‚ÄùName, Email, Phone‚Äù and is needed in the Lego-block ‚Äúadd customer contact data‚Äù.
If you look into how systems describe WHAT they can do, it says ‚ÄúOur Capabilities‚Äù.
Your challenge is to describe everything separately first and then try to find suitable parts that fit the whole Capability requirements.
This is a true story of how wrong something can be.
When replacing an accounting system for incoming invoices, the process is as follows:
1. Receive invoice with email.
2. Print the invoice.
3. Go to another computer and scan.
4. Open it in the accounting system.
When I asked ‚Äúwhy‚Äù, I got the answer, ‚Äúbecause we always have done like this‚Äù.
There was no reason why we couldn‚Äôt skip 2 and 3 in a new system, but the customer insisted on the same process. Now, everything isn‚Äôt this clear, but we often do things in our process because of the lack of functions in the current system.
If we define the outcome we are after in each lego-bricks we will never replace step 2 and 3 because they don‚Äôt bring any value.

[[The Change Management Process]]

title: Patterns of Business (Now)
ai_summary: Understanding organizational patterns is crucial for long-term success. Effective business models, capabilities, and operating models should be aligned, focusing on the "what" of the organization. Visual tools like maps can clarify connections, while recognizing the difference between processes and capabilities is essential for optimization. Identifying missing elements in alignment can enhance overall effectiveness, and a unified model can simplify complex business structures.
body:
[](https://files.oaiusercontent.com/file-5W8GPaTN5NP9jCFXNtgEtglA?se=2123-12-14T23%3A21%3A57Z&sp=r&sv=2021-08-06&sr=b&rscc=max-age%3D1209600%2C%20immutable&rscd=attachment%3B%20filename%3DScreenshot%25202024-01-07%2520at%25205.15.47%2520PM.png&sig=YjPzJoBOA6H7DIGnZApDhY/uh/pSd7mL5a87fAhpiyw%3D)

Here‚Äôs a reworked version of your article with a more direct, authoritative tone, while stripping away the unnecessary jargon:

---

**Why Patterns Matter in Your Organization**
You should care about the patterns in your organization because understanding them leads to long-term results. No fluff, just facts.
I‚Äôm a practical guy. I like models because they help make sense of complicated issues quickly. Business is no different. Some models work, some don‚Äôt, and the sooner you figure that out, the better.
**Here‚Äôs the reality:**
- Some models fail fast.
- Some models get the job done.
- Some are just distractions.
**Why Maps Work**

People think in pictures‚Äîit‚Äôs how we make sense of things. That‚Äôs why maps are powerful tools. They help you see connections clearly. Christopher Alexander‚Äôs *Pattern Language* talked about this back in 1977. It‚Äôs about building blocks and how they fit together‚Äîlike towns need lakes to have rivers, businesses need the right components connected to succeed.

**Business Is Like LEGO**

Think of your organization like LEGO. Each block has a place, and there are rules on how they connect. No guesswork. I also like models where you can zoom in and out as needed because business problems come in different sizes.

Here‚Äôs what you need to focus on at a high level:

- **WHY**: Why are we doing this?
- **WHAT**: What exactly are we doing?
- **HOW**: How are we doing it?
- **WHO**: Who is responsible?

To me, the **WHAT** is the foundation. Sure, Simon Sinek says ‚ÄúStart with Why,‚Äù but that‚Äôs not always practical. You need to know **WHAT** you‚Äôre doing first.

---

**The Building Blocks of Your Business**

Now, let‚Äôs get real. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôre working with:

- **Business Models**: What‚Äôs the product, service, or strategy?
- **Capabilities**: What can your company do?
- **Operating Models**: How does the work actually get done?
- **Information and Tools**: What resources do you have to support all this?

**So, What‚Äôs the WHAT?**

After years of trial and error, I always come back to this: **Business Capabilities** explain **WHAT** your company can actually do. Whether it‚Äôs logistics, sales, or finance, it‚Äôs what you‚Äôre equipped to deliver. Sometimes, you‚Äôve got different parts of your organization acting like separate businesses.

From this **WHAT**, you answer everything else‚Äîwhy, how, and who.

**Types of Capabilities**:

1. **Strategic Capabilities**: Set the direction‚Äîmarket analysis, planning.
2. **Core Capabilities**: Define your offering‚Äîproduct development, customer service.
3. **Supporting Capabilities**: Keep it all running‚ÄîIT, admin, support.

---

**The Big Picture**

Business is about solving real problems people are willing to pay for. Not every problem can be fixed, but they can be managed. That‚Äôs where business models come in.

Most organizations are drowning in models that don‚Äôt work. You don‚Äôt need more; you need the right one. Start with **WHAT** and build from there.

---

**Making the Right Connections**

A lot of businesses miss the link between process and capability. It‚Äôs simple:

- **Processes** are about flow‚Äîgetting things done efficiently.
- **Capabilities** are about resources‚Äîhaving the tools and people to get the job done.

You need both. Otherwise, you‚Äôre just improving one thing while another part of the business lags behind.

---

**What‚Äôs Missing in Your Organization?**

Let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîyou‚Äôre probably missing a few building blocks. The **why, what, how,** and **who** aren‚Äôt fully aligned, and the connections are weak. I can help you fix that.

**When do we start?**

Shoot me a message. Let‚Äôs get it done.

Why should you care about your patterns in the organisation? Because it will give you a better understanding and value in the long term.
I‚Äôm a model guy. I really like good models because they create a faster understanding of a complex issue. The whole business is one of those.
But remember that:
Some models fail faster than others.
Some models are useful.
Some bit in working life, I have come to the conclusion that we humans are always trying to imagine things that people say in pictures. If there is a picture it is easier to relate to. That is why I believe maps are a good tool.
With all patterns, I want it to be connected. Already in a Pattern Language (from 1977) by Christopher Alexander, he described the basic patterns that are used to build a town. It is basic building blocks and layers of information. In the patterns, he described not only the pattern itself, but also how it is connected and rules how it can be connected. You need a lake to have a river. You can‚Äôt have a driveway to the house without some kind of road.
With business, it is the same.

You have building blocks, and like LEGO, and it is possible to connect them with a certain constrains and rules.
I also like fractal models, where I can zoom in and out.
On a very high conceptual level, I see at least four things that need to be connected. It explain what are the things we do.
WHY, the purpose of the things we do
WHAT, are the things we doing
HOW, are we doing things
WHO, is doing things
As you can see, WHAT becomes the backbone of my reasoning.
Simon Senik famously wrote about this in ‚ÄúStart With Why‚Äù. I do not agree that starting with Why is always a good idea. I think trying to figure out WHAT we are doing first is better.
The next step of building blocks concerns the disparate things we are discussing.
Business Models, products or services, marketing, strategy, bets.
Organisational capability, resources,
Operating Models, processes, way of working
Information and tools.

So, what is the WHAT in the organisation?
From years of trying different ways, i still circle back to that WHAT is the central thing we can explain the organisation from (some say enterprise just not to lose anyone here)
Business Capability explains what the organisation can do.
A business capability can be defined as the organisation‚Äôs ability to perform unique activities that deliver value, such as logistics, finance, or sales.
You can also see the whole organisation as a capability. The Capability to deliver a service or product. And often, we find that we do different things that are separate enterprises within the same organisation.
From the overall capability, we can answer the other questions.
There are probably different types of capabilities that can suit your organisation, such as operational capabilities and supporting capabilities. Sometimes, you want to have different strategic capabilities as well.
1. **Strategic Capabilities**: These set the direction for the organization, including market analysis and planning initiatives.
2. **Core Capabilities**: These define the organization‚Äôs market proposition and include functions like product development, delivery and customer relationship.
3. **Supporting Capabilities**: These facilitate core functions, such as IT support and administrative services

And what is a business mode?
A business addresses a real problem that someone is willing to pay to get help with. I intentionally wrote help because some problems can‚Äôt be solved. They can be mitigated.

So how can it all be knitted together?
Most organisations have more models than they need but still miss some that make all the difference.
I see something in the organisation that can be used as an Anchor Model. One Model to rule them all. And what could be better than to start with WHAT?
((Image: 1 Capability Maps))
The traditional method only has to do with creating boxes and sorting things. But when we add it to the contract with everything else, such as customer journey, information and tools, we realize that the lens of ONLY what we do doesn‚Äôt get us all the way.
((Image: Where it is connected))

How do you go from strategy to code? Or from product to end user. Or from internal processes to customer satisfaction. All these require different building blocks to be combined.
I often find that some are missing. The most straightforward example is the difference between process and business capabilities (or business functions).
The process (or, nowadays, value flow, value streams) is trying to flow-optimize.
The capabilities (or functions) are trying to resource-optimize.
Optimising becomes true when both aspects are taken into consideration. Otherwise, it is often just sub-optimizing.
(good bad)
So what building blocks do you need?
That depends on what you need.
Why, what, how, and who are good starts. And my guess is that you are missing at least one of them and that you haven‚Äôt glued them together for different purposes.
Sorting that out is what I‚Äôm good at, so let me help you with that.
When should we start?
Send me a DM.

In the area of trying to explain what a business do there have been a lot of attempts such as Zachmnans Framework for enterprise architecture, Koppler in Operational Processes, BMC, Kottler in marketing, x in change, y in strategy and Meyer Briggs type indicator in personal test.
Some are aleady outdated. All of them had a purpose in trying to explain something that is abstract. And I would argue that the easiest to understand models are the one that sticks.
Easy dosent mean that it is uncomplicated. For e.g.¬†Chess is easy to understand how to move the pieces on the board but takes a lifetime to master.
I have my bag of tools with me when I enter and work in a organisation. For me SImon Sinek really did mess things up for a while but now I just came to understand it better and need to interpetad his words in another context.
In his book he starting with Why as a groundwork for every organisations existance.
And that is correct if you understand what Simon means with why.
I reprase everything as our need to solve things. Task oriented. A problem.
A definition would be something like:

[[Naming and definitions]]

# References

1. https://unfix.com/blog/try-some-patterns

title: Planning Each Day, Week, Quarter, Year, Five Years, or 500 Years?
ai_summary: Effective planning requires a balance between flexibility and structure, as each team and organization is unique. Business agility is about the ability to adapt to changes rather than the frequency of planning. Utilizing scenarios can help prepare for uncertainties without overcommitting, allowing for adjustments in goals, budgets, and strategies as needed.
body:
[[000 WIP]]
Status: #idea
Planning Each Day, Week, Quarter, Year, Five Years, or 500 Years?
Is planning each day a way to be flexible? No.¬†That‚Äôs bureaucracy. Is never planning at all flexible? No.¬†That‚Äôs anarchy.
The real challenge: finding what works best for you.
Every team is different. Every level of your organization is different. There‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all answer.
Think about a budget:

‚Üí It‚Äôs just a framework.

‚Üí It‚Äôs the money we predict we‚Äôll get and plan to use.

‚Üí The difference, ideally, becomes profit, or at least breaks even for non-profits.
Business agility (or Business Flexibility) isn‚Äôt about how often you plan but how easily you can adapt to change.
Ask yourself:

Can you adjust these in under a year without chaos?
‚Ä¢ Goals

‚Ä¢ Revenue targets

‚Ä¢ Budget allocation

‚Ä¢ Resources (staff)

‚Ä¢ Big bets

‚Ä¢ Strategy

‚Ä¢ Projects

‚Ä¢ Markets
This is where flexibility truly lives.

Hack: Use scenarios when uncertainty is high.

Example: Customer revenue might shift unpredictably, like how COVID-19 hit the restaurant industry.
Scenarios help you prepare without overcommitment in planning.
But in the end. You got this. So stop listening to everyone :-)

title: The Data in the Middle
ai_summary: Organizations often struggle with scattered data when creating reports, leading to reliance on Excel, which raises concerns about data accuracy and management. To address this, it's essential to define an operational model that outlines key processes and to choose a more effective data management system, such as Airtable, to improve workflows and data accessibility. Focusing on these areas can transform operations and enhance value delivery in 2025.
author: Thomas Larsson
body:
The Data in the Middle

We‚Äôve all been there: scrambling to create a report or status update that pulls from scattered data‚Äîfinancial follow-ups, customer projections, layoff plans, and next year‚Äôs budget. It‚Äôs everywhere and nowhere at the same time. Frustrated, we think, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no tool for this mess, and I‚Äôm not doing this again next year.‚Äù

The Default Solution? Excel.

This Excel file quickly becomes the most critical document in the organization. Everything hinges on it being accurate. But is it?

- Have we evaluated what kind of data we‚Äôre using?
- Can we trust its accuracy?
- Do we even know who‚Äôs changing what?
- And will this same file be used again?

These gaps highlight the need for two things:

1. An Operational Model
2. A System to Manage Data for That Model

What‚Äôs an Operational Model?

Think of it as the blueprint between strategy and execution. It defines how your organization delivers value to stakeholders, outlining the key components and actions of operations. Today, many operating models are buried in the chaos of scattered Excel files.

What Needs to Change?

Define Your Operational Model: Start by identifying the processes and data that truly matter for delivering value. This step is simpler than it sounds but is often overlooked.

Choose the Right System: You need a system that manages data effectively. Hint: it‚Äôs not Excel. For me, Airtable stands out. It connects with other systems, replaces Excel, and creates workflows where updates and automations are seamless.

Looking Ahead

For 2025, my focus is on these two areas: defining clear operational models and leveraging systems that elevate the quality and accessibility of critical data. These steps don‚Äôt just clean up chaos - they transform how we work and deliver value with better focus on becoming better.

What‚Äôs your plan for getting better with the data in the middle?

title: Keep Strategy Simple
ai_summary: A strategy should focus on solving a hard problem or overcoming a challenger, answering the question "how do we win?" Simplicity is key, as strategy involves positioning rather than immediate action, requiring understanding of external factors before decision-making.
body:
Keep it simple. A strategy should have either a hard problem to solve or a enemy that requires a strategy to win over. It needs to answer the question ‚Äúhow do we win?‚Äù. It the organisation dosent have a challenger or a hard problem to solve then it is not in a need of a strategy.

## Reference

[https://hbr.org/2024/08/keep-strategy-simple](https://hbr.org/2024/08/keep-strategy-simple)

## Metadata

- Author: Graham Kenny
- Publisher: HBR
- Published Date: 2024-08-27
- Note: Is strategy a plan With action? No it shouldn‚Äôt.
Its a trap for setting focus on the right level.
Its only human to get directly to solution and action.
To stay in the problem. To try to understand marketing position, outside forces as
The market and political landscape is needed to set the stage.
After that it is time for a descision.
What should we do and what should we not do to reach our goals?

Lower price
New market
Remove a product line
Invest to remove tidius manual work with automation
* Tags:

## Highlights

- As Steve Jobs once put it: ‚ÄúSimple can be harder than complex: You have to work hard to get your thinking clean to make it simple. But it‚Äôs worth it in the end because once you get there, you can move mountains.‚Äù
- Strategy involves positioning, not action.
- outside with stakeholders, not inside with functions.

title: Why No One Understands Enterprise Architecture  and Why Technology Abstractions Always Fail
ai_summary: Enterprise Architecture should focus on aligning business strategy with technology, simplifying the explanation of how they connect, and emphasizing the importance of a dynamic business-technology strategy for future success.
body:
## Metadata

State: #idea
* URL: [https://www.forbes.com/sites/steveandriole/2020/09/18/why-no-one-understands-enterprise-architecture‚Äìwhy-technology-abstractions-always-fail/?sh=3eac9b397eb5](https://www.forbes.com/sites/steveandriole/2020/09/18/why-no-one-understands-enterprise-architecture--why-technology-abstractions-always-fail/?sh=3eac9b397eb5)
* Author: Steve Andriole
* Publisher: Forbes
* Published Date: 2020-09-19
* Tags: #ea

[[Simplify how you explain your business for quicker, clearer results]]
It‚Äôs time to get the basics right. What main parts do we need to keep track on and how should it be connected to each other.
A long time ago I thought that Scrum was the solution for everything. In it‚Äôs first simple version it provided a process how to think. I said back in the days. ‚ÄúIt is very easy to understand, but hard to master.‚Äù Chess is that as well.
The people winning this race is the one that can explain for everyone how things are glued together.
It is all about down to the core.

It‚Äôs now time to strip EA down to its most basic properties ‚Äì the alignment of business strategy with operational and strategic technology.¬†¬†We can continue to complicate all this, or just admit we‚Äôre seeking business-technology alignment through the development of a dynamic business technology strategy.
## Highlights
* Enterprise planning or Enterprise Business- Technology Strategy might be better, or even just Business-Technology Strategy (BTS). Why? Because ‚ÄúEnterprise Architecture‚Äù is nothing more than an alignment exercise, alignment between what the business wants to do and how the
* A description of how the company makes money. A description of the processes, products and services that make money. A description of how the company makes money today and how it expects to make money in the next 3-5 years. A description of the competitive marketplace where the company makes money. (There are tools to help do this.)

title: Delivering the strategy: The COO agenda | McKinsey
ai_summary: COOs must define their agenda by understanding their role's scope and situation, ensuring alignment with business strategy, engaging stakeholders effectively, and focusing on organizational excellence to drive operational success and transformation. Effective time management and delegation are crucial for prioritizing strategic topics over day-to-day operations.
body:
[https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/operations/our-insights/delivering-the-strategy-the-coo-agenda?hsid=7475259f-4483-4918-91e6-c5cb12e36be4#/](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/operations/our-insights/delivering-the-strategy-the-coo-agenda?hsid=7475259f-4483-4918-91e6-c5cb12e36be4#/)

**We‚Äôve all heard someone** say that something is ‚Äúon‚Äù or ‚Äúpart of‚Äù the COO agenda. But all too often, what that means is unclear. Indeed, in a recent roundtable discussion, few COOs said that they had taken the time to think through and define their agenda.

Part of the reason lies in how people become COOs. Most move into the role from a closely related operations position, making the transition feel less like a change than moving between functions.

Before starting in a COO role, the new incumbent needs to answer two simple but critical questions:

- Why do we, the organization, have a COO?
- Why am I, specifically, in the role?

Understanding the context of the role is important, particularly the *scope* and the *situation*. The *scope* varies by organization and industry. It could encompass overall responsibility for primary or core operations, as is often seen in heavy industries such as mining or transportation. In financial institutions or holding companies, by contrast, the COO might be responsible for business support functions, such as HR or back-office processes. In other organizations, the COO‚Äôs role is akin to that of a president, overseeing business units.

The *situation* refers to factors in the overall business‚Äîor market‚Äîdriving what needs to happen in operations. A particular business may be undergoing significant transformation, for example, or a period of recovery. At one major retailer, the COO role was established to lead the operations until a designated successor gained more experience and was ready to move into a senior executive role.

The COO must then understand *why they, themselves, are in the role*. It could be because of a specific skill set or linked to the overall situation, such as Industry 4.0 expertise in the case of digital transformation. Given that more than 25 percent of Fortune 500 CEOs came from the COO role, it could also relate to succession planning.

A particular COO may be selected to balance the strengths of another executive, such as the agribusiness COO whose detailed operational expertise provided a counterweight to a strategic, visionary CEO. The combination helped the company reach new levels of operational excellence.

The scope and situation illustrate another important point: the COO role is much more than an extension of what the individual was doing before. The job is not just being a ‚Äúsuper site manager‚Äù who now oversees multiple sites. It is a true C-level role, with a broader view and often new responsibilities.

## Seeing what drives value

The COO must be crystal clear on what creates distinctive value for the company‚Äîhint: it probably isn‚Äôt just low cost‚Äîwhile understanding what the strategy means, how operations drives the strategy, and which operational sensitivities will determine the outcomes.

Connecting the cascade of drivers to strategic objectives is essential. A logistics company launched a portfolio of operations initiatives but found that even the most wildly successful ones had little impact on overall results. A mining company worked to raise the performance of individual sites until all showed ‚Äúgreen,‚Äù only to discover that company-wide operational performance remained ‚Äúred.‚Äù In both cases, the linkages between the overall strategy and operations initiatives were broken‚Äîa gap that the COO is best positioned to fill, leading to better prioritization of operations efforts and investments so that they achieve strategic outcomes.

## Setting the COO agenda

The COO agenda guides COO actions, tests whether investments are being made in the right places, withstands day-to-day firefighting, and helps the COO focus on ‚ÄúCOO-only‚Äù topics. The core elements of a COO agenda vary by company and context, but in general, the primary elements include:

- **Vision.** Our research found that only 22 percent of employees believe that their leaders have a clear direction for the organization, understand the strategic mandate, and create one if it does not exist.
- **Plan and execution.** While this step‚Äîthe ‚Äúhow‚Äù of making the vision real‚Äîincludes near-term operational excellence, it also looks anywhere from six months to three years ahead with a portfolio of initiatives designed for each time frame.
- **Stakeholder engagement.** One COO we interviewed defined operational excellence as ‚Äúa full appreciation of the complete set of stakeholders and what their requirements are, including customer, board, public, and employees.‚Äù This is a clear COO-only topic, essential to leading operations supporting the business strategy.
- **Organization and talent.** The COO role is not about running the operation but leading and enabling the operations organization. Experienced COOs have told us to ensure that ‚Äúthe team is in control‚Äù and to ‚Äúfind the best team and lean on them.‚Äù The COO is responsible for creating the most capable operations organization, including succession planning.
- **Personal operating model.** The COO role and its responsibilities differ from previous roles and vary from organization to organization. COOs need to manage how they spend their time and attention, lead, and interact with stakeholders.

These elements will help a COO forge a proactive agenda, make decisions, and prioritize tasks. The perspectives and expectations of core stakeholders‚Äîinvestors, CEOs, and other C-suite executives‚Äîshould also guide the COO agenda.

## The COO vision begins with the overall business strategy

An effective operations vision clearly articulates the plan for success and serves as the ‚Äútrue north‚Äù for employees across the organization working toward shared goals. To successfully craft the vision and execution plan for operations, the COO must understand the overall business strategy, how operations will drive that strategy, and the role they, as the COO, play in delivering it.

An enterprise-wide mandate, such as a transformation, business recovery, or shift to digital, can largely shape a COO‚Äôs vision. Clearly communicating this vision so that all operators‚Äîincluding those on the front line‚Äîcan understand and repeat it is crucial. High levels of ownership and buy-in among this group of stakeholders increase the odds of success. If the vision is too complex or fails to resonate among employees, there is little chance of inspiring action.

An effective vision must be unambiguous, with no room for alternative interpretation. At one financial services company, the vision was expressed as the share of clients engaging through a new channel by the end of the following year. The operational vision of a logistics company was expressed as achieving a consistent capacity above a forecast volume without additional capital investment. There are also times when a qualitative vision and statement of a ‚Äúleader‚Äôs intent‚Äù[1Chad Storlie, ‚ÄúManage uncertainty with commander‚Äôs intent,‚Äù *Harvard Business Review*, November 3, 2010.](javascript:void(0);) are required. At one transportation provider, the vision entailed achieving a service level that matched its top-performing alternative‚Äîbut at a lower customer cost.

## A robust plan and effective execution are essential to make the vision a reality

A vision without a *plan* is simply a wish. Time flies, and a host of distractions will hinder progress. A solid plan intertwined with the vision to drive coordinated actions and track progress is essential for moving forward.

There is nothing magic about the concept of ‚Äú100 days‚Äù and no need to adopt a 100-day plan, but stakeholders expect the COO to act in the near term. The COO‚Äôs vision also needs a long-term horizon and a plan to match, albeit with appropriate granular detail.

To build a robust plan, COOs should assess and act across five areas:

1. **Operations.** What is the current performance and capability? Is the operation aligned with the vision? If not, what will that take to achieve?
2. **Stakeholders.** What are the expectations of the CEO, chief experience officers (CXOs), boardroom, employees, customers, and other stakeholders?
3. **Culture.** What is the organization‚Äôs culture, and are there changes needed? If so, how can I influence those changes?
4. **Team.** Are the right team members in the right roles? Does the organizational structure support the operational requirements, particularly regarding the vision?
5. **Themselves.** What are my strengths? What are my weaknesses? Am I meeting all the requirements of my role?

By ensuring a thorough understanding across these five areas, the COO can quickly identify and prioritize gaps or challenges, enabling them to act quickly where clear change is necessary. As COOs create and act on a plan, they need a portfolio of initiatives that include the desired impact, challenges to overcome, and a time frame for action. For longer-term initiatives, COOs can implement plans that yield benefits in six months, a year, or longer. As one COO stated in a recent interview, ‚ÄúTime is your friend; invest in capabilities.‚Äù

With a clear vision and plan in place, a COO is well-positioned to *execute* effectively on the business strategy. If running the core of the operation lies within their mandate, the COO also owns operational excellence and will be deeply involved in aligning the company‚Äôs operational technology, technical systems, management systems, and organizational principles and behaviors with its purpose and strategy.

‚ÄúTechnical systems‚Äù refers to the people, processes, tools, and materials needed to execute the operation. As the one overseeing the nuts and bolts of the operation, the COO must ensure all parts work together to enable the business to deliver on its strategy. This includes not only the ‚Äúhard‚Äù elements of operations, such as equipment, inventory, and logistics, but also elements like data management, digital enablement, and analytics.

Management systems represent the mechanism for COOs and their teams to monitor and orchestrate operations. COOs need a clear view of the drivers behind desired outcomes, enabling them to monitor and question top-level metrics, as well as the ability to dig deeper into the root drivers.

Organizational principles and behaviors are equally important. The COO has to set the tone while staying close to the pulse of the culture. The Gemba walk‚Äîa classic lean management concept where leaders spend time with employees to see how the work is done‚Äîprovides a powerful platform to engage with the front line.

## Effectively engaging stakeholders

A COO plays a pivotal role in building relationships for their organization. Fostering connections that last requires care and consideration.

In modern business, no single element acts alone. As a result, the role and importance of stakeholders have continued to increase. Nowhere is this truer than for the COO. In this role, the COO must look beyond the operation internally and externally and foster productive relationships with a broad group of stakeholders. To do so requires a thorough understanding of and a deliberate approach to each stakeholder‚Äôs objectives, incentives, and expectations.

A COO interacts with a broad set of important stakeholders, both internal and external. Each is unique and can often have competing demands that a COO must balance and manage. Several COOs we interviewed stated that they were unprepared for the increased demands of stakeholder engagement and advised new COOs to prepare.

**Key internal stakeholders include the following:**

**The CEO.** The CEO is the most proximate stakeholder, and it is essential to understand the working relationship and expectations. The COO must clearly understand why their role exists in the organization, how the CEO perceives that role, and how best to work together. Often, a COO is selected to complement the CEO‚Äôs working style.

The COO should understand how to collaborate with the CEO effectively. For example: What decisions should the COO take autonomously? What type and depth of information does the CEO want and need for decisions and reassurance? What issues need to be escalated, and how?

**The C-suite.** Nearly all executives we interviewed agreed that increased cross-functional engagement is critical to COO success. The COO is uniquely positioned to help familiarize other C-suite executives with a business‚Äôs operations, particularly if those executives have come from another industry. This, however, requires the COO to communicate the ‚Äúfull operational picture,‚Äù as one COO described it, including the long-term implications of decisions and investments. Another COO cautioned, ‚ÄúWhile it is important to teach other leaders about operations, you must also learn to speak their language.‚Äù Taking the time to understand others‚Äô objectives and challenges will pay dividends toward fostering genuine collaboration and avoiding disagreements. Among the key C-suite stakeholders are the following:

- **The CFO.** There is tremendous opportunity in closely aligning with the CFO, especially on planning, budgeting, and top-of-mind investor issues such as working capital, large capital expenditures, and productivity. The COO, like the CFO, has a bird‚Äôs-eye view of cross-business and cross-functional opportunities. The two can educate each other on best practices in procurement, for example, and even share talent on key short-term projects.
- **The CMO.** COOs we interviewed noted that the relationship with sales and marketing is particularly important. Operations leaders must thoroughly understand the customer value proposition and what it will take for operations to deliver on it. Furthermore, successful collaboration between marketing and operations functions can help deliver a better customer experience, increasing satisfaction and loyalty.
- **The CIO.** Technology is at the heart of how we do business today, and the relationship between the COO and CIO, as well as other digital and data leaders, is essential to ensure that operations sees the right return on its investments. Technology investment and deployment present unique opportunities to transform businesses, but this requires deep partnership. For example, daily operations produce an enormous amount of data that, when collaboratively governed and managed, can yield insights that unlock the next S-curve of impact.

**The board.** Board engagement is one area where many COOs expressed dissatisfaction, with some describing board interactions as ‚Äúscripted presentations.‚Äù The best CEOs use the collective experience of the entire board to help solve problems or give advice. Several COOs encouraged seeking this kind of relationship, ensuring that their exposure to and engagement with the board consisted of focused meetings and problem-solving sessions versus presentations.

**Key external stakeholders include the following:**

Regulators, suppliers, organized labor, investors, and others are important, but the final and perhaps ultimate external stakeholder is the customer.

The COO is the operational link to the strategy, so they should know the market. At least one executive we interviewed strongly believes that every COO, whether new to the organization or coming up from within, should have market-facing experience. This helps when collaborating with the marketing function and provides the COO the ability to factor customer experience early into any decisions.

Stakeholder engagement is a COO-only topic that is essential to operational excellence in support of the strategy. COOs who prioritize key stakeholders (for example, those with the ability to influence the success or failure of the plan) and are thoughtful in how they engage them have a far greater likelihood of success than those who don‚Äôt.

## Building organizational and talent excellence

Around 70 percent of corporate transformations fail. Some of the most common reasons cited for transformation efforts that fail to achieve their full potential are related to organizational culture, mindsets, capabilities, and talent. The COO plays a critical role in ensuring the right infrastructure is in place and establishing a leadership-oversight cadence to drive mindsets and behaviors to execute the business strategy successfully.

In most organizations, the COO is not expected to run the day-to-day operations but to focus on the more strategic aspects of operations to enable the overall business strategy. For rising COOs, this can be a difficult transition; indeed, too often, it leads to failure. Successful COOs do not act as ‚Äúsuper site managers‚Äù but rather rely on their team to handle the day-to-day. In our COO interviews, this was a recurring theme: ‚ÄúThe team is in control,‚Äù ‚ÄúFind the best team and lean on them,‚Äù and ‚ÄúSet it [the operations] up to run without you.‚Äù

Our research found three key ways that successful COOs navigate strategy around organizational infrastructure and talent.

**Ensure the right frontline leadership.** Strong teams are led by strong managers. In *Power to the Middle: Why Managers Hold the Keys to the Future of Work* (Harvard Business Review Press, 2023), frontline (middle) managers are referred to as the ‚Äútrue center of the organization and its most valuable asset,‚Äù as they possess the granular knowledge, direct influence, and perspective necessary to effectively lead any operational realignments (for example, change initiatives or digital disruption).

COOs should place special focus on assessing their organization and talent. This begins by distinguishing what skills and capabilities are needed to execute the operational plan and then partnering closely with HR and senior leaders to find and develop the people accordingly. While it is important for the COO to work in close partnership with HR and other senior leaders, it is imperative that they own the outcome: the successful placement of top talent in critical roles.

Once the right team is in place, the COO should ensure they remain high-performing through capability building, performance management, mentoring, and coaching. Additionally, the COO should ensure that detailed succession planning is in place‚Äîfor the COO role as well as other leadership roles in operations. However, those who do not aspire to senior leadership should not be overlooked as they are often the heroes of the operations‚Äî[good managers should often be given higher-value compensation instead of being promoted out of their jobs](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/middle-managers-are-the-heart-of-your-company).[2Emily Field, Bryan Hancock, and Bill Schaninger, ‚Äú](javascript:void(0);)[Middle managers are the heart of your company](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/middle-managers-are-the-heart-of-your-company),‚Äù *McKinsey Quarterly,* July 17, 2023.

**Be clear about your intentions.** As an operations leader, a COO should give deliberate thought to how they will lead. One effective concept is that of a leader‚Äôs intent. Adapted from the military concept of commander‚Äôs intent,[3‚ÄúManage uncertainty with commander‚Äôs intent,‚Äù November 3, 2010.](javascript:void(0);) leader‚Äôs intent can be incredibly effective in a distributed operation. It provides the ultimate objective, not prescriptive decisions, so that in a situation filled with ambiguity and requiring an urgent and autonomous decision, the distributed operator will make decisions that are consistent with the COO‚Äôs intent. They will not get it right 100 percent of the time, but in most situations, the operator makes the right decision (and often a decision that no one previously imagined but that has a significant positive impact).

The COO must also recognize the impact of their behaviors and actions. At one organization, for instance, leaders wanted to see a shift in focus in asset maintenance toward productivity to ensure that maintenance tasks of all sizes and scope were performed in an efficient manner. On the daily operations call, the leaders asked questions about jobs completed. In response, the team began tackling small jobs to maintain a high number of completed jobs while larger jobs were sidelined. The questions asked by leaders inadvertently drove frontline behaviors that created a maintenance ‚Äúdebt‚Äù across the organization‚Äôs assets, diminishing overall asset health. This example reinforces how important it is for COOs to model what is important (in other words, framing questions in a way that drives specific, intended outcomes) and provide reinforcement mechanisms, both positive and negative, for operators.

Lastly, the COO must consider how they amplify. The clear articulation of strategy is a key pillar of success, but stakeholders may find their own source of meaning through personal, company, or team success or impact on the customer or society. Therefore, COOs should amplify all of these elements to ensure that success feels shared across the organization. In fact, previous studies have shown that each of these is a common source of meaning and roughly equally distributed among the population. Few people in operations are likely to share the same source of meaning. Therefore, if the COO only communicates in terms of their own source of meaning, they are likely missing the majority of the population.

**Be deliberate in how you influence.** One COO described the role as being about leading change‚Äî‚ÄúYou have to be comfortable making people uncomfortable,‚Äù also noting, ‚ÄúYou need to proactively manage the inertia of the organization,‚Äù calling attention to the inherent tendency of an organization to keep moving in its current or historical direction. As a change leader, the COO can deploy many influence techniques. For example, they can be an inspirational leader who convinces the organization of the value of change. They can be the expert, teaching and enabling others. They can influence through incentives, both carrots and sticks. Or they can be a role model, setting the example as an operational leader.

While each of these approaches increases the probability of success in leading change, a McKinsey study found that successful transformations were almost eight times as likely to employ all four approaches (exhibit). However, most organizations default to one technique, communications. By failing to address the other influence factors, particularly incentives and role modeling, an organization risks experiencing competing influences, which can lead to failure. For example, if a COO communicates a new way of working but does not change incentives from rewarding the previous operating model, change is unlikely.

[](https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/operations/our%20insights/delivering%20the%20strategy%20the%20coo%20agenda/svgz-coo-agenda-ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center)

Given their unique role relative to other operations leaders, a COO benefits greatly from stepping back and thinking through how best to organize their team to drive outcomes, develop the talent required, and be clear about the role they will play in leading operations.

## Establishing a personal operating model

One sentiment widely shared across COOs we interviewed was that a COO‚Äôs role and expectations are different than ‚Äúwhat got you here.‚Äù Being COO is different from other operations roles. Stakeholders are not looking for the COO to be a ‚Äúsuper site manager‚Äù or a version of the COO‚Äôs previous role with just a larger scope. COOs are expected to hand off and delegate running the operation and focus on COO-only and strategic topics, many of which were not part of their previous role.

Using a basketball analogy, one COO describes it as the need to ‚Äúlean into your left hand,‚Äù meaning to improve shooting with your nondominant hand. For the COO role, this means becoming stronger in areas outside your core expertise.

For example, in business case analysis, the COO is often the owner of pitching to the CEO or CFO for major operations investments. Reviewing, explaining, and often asking hard questions of their own staff become important skills. Another COO reflects that in his previous role, he was a great operator and site leader. However, his new COO role includes collaborating on core ERP systems and advanced manufacturing technology, requiring him to learn much more about technology quickly.

Successful COOs find a balance between running the operation and delivering strategic outcomes, but that doesn‚Äôt happen by accident. COOs need to be deliberate in establishing their personal operating model, clearly defining the role they will‚Äîand won‚Äôt‚Äîplay in operations leadership. This allows them to be structured and intentional in how they spend their time and energy to ensure a focus on COO-only and strategic topics.

### Be clear about the role you will play

For many COOs, this means shifting working methods to expand capacity for COO-only topics. COOs should be clear about their priorities and personal leadership focus and limit their involvement in tasks that others can deal with. Where a COO should engage will vary based on scope, situation, and mandate.

COOs should know their strengths but be honest about their limitations and strategically align talent to bridge any gaps toward delivering the vision. This can increase personal efficiency and effectiveness and create succession planning and development opportunities. Familiarity with other functional areas will serve the COO well as they look to improve collaboration.

### Create an actionable plan and stick to it

COOs should have a clear view of areas that will require more of their focus and ensure the right mechanisms are in place to make it happen. For those COO-only topics, this means identifying and outlining the cadence for critical interactions. They should be clear on what data and reports they need to see, at what level, and how frequently.

In thinking through delegation, they should consider their level of involvement in delivering operational excellence and determine where direct leadership is required. For example, COOs can achieve high ROI from their time by strategically conducting site visits, both in terms of their personal learning and providing visible leadership, mentoring, and role modeling at the front line.

### Lead to inspire talent and shape the culture

COOs should move beyond a vertical hierarchy and, instead, see themselves as catalysts and connectors to drive empowerment and collaboration. The result is high-performing teams, operating in a culture of trust and human connection that extends past formal structures.

### Proactively manage your time and energy

COOs tell us that effective time management is a frequent challenge. Some say it is perhaps the biggest challenge of all‚Äîbeing able to focus on the right topics at the level of depth required. As a general rule of thumb, several COOs offer that no more than a third of their time should be spent on running the operation. The rest of their time should be spent on COO-only topics such as strategy, governance, transformation, people/talent, and organizational health.

Day-to-day firefighting can feel like a constant demand-pull for COOs. A COO who is reactive risks focusing only on the near term and making decisions based on experience, heuristics, and gut feelings. Stepping back instead and making data-based decisions with a strategic versus reactive view will help the COO stay ahead.

To maximize time spent on critical areas, COOs need to embed a steady rhythm‚Äîfor example, how they manage their year/month/week, workflow, and travel schedule. This can be codified and communicated with the operations team and reinforced through the COO‚Äôs assistant. Meeting archetypes should be predefined, as should how meetings are run, including preparation expectations. Free capacity should be actively built in to protect time for long-term needs, including critical priorities and energy maximizers.

Schedule activities to prevent ‚Äúenergy troughs‚Äù and make room for recovery activities such as time with family and friends and exercise. COOs should be comfortable and confident in setting boundaries. This ensures they set a pace they can sustain for a marathon-length effort rather than burn out from repeated sprints.

Today‚Äôs most effective COOs have a defined agenda that is aligned with the overall business strategy, focusing on how operations can drive that strategy and what role they will play in delivering results. The COO agenda lays out the operational vision of an effective organization, clearly articulates a plan for success, and serves as a North Star for employees working together toward shared goals.

Successful COOs drive effective collaboration and engagement with all key stakeholders to fully drive their agenda and deliver the business strategy. They are inspirational leaders and role models who are also methodical in building a team to which they can delegate day-to-day operations, allowing them to focus on COO-only topics and determine where and how to spend their time best to deliver the highest impact for the organization.

[**Darryl Piasecki**](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/darryl-piasecki) is the managing partner of McKinsey‚Äôs St. Louis office.

### Explore a career with us

title: PUR - Painful Urgent Recognized
ai_summary: Many businesses fail to solve painful, urgent, and recognized problems due to lack of customer involvement, reliance on weak market signals, and a product-first approach, leading to inadequate solutions.
body:
[[System for Content]]
A way to explain something is to use PUR.

Solving the wrong market problem sounds like this:

- Client A: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs interesting but we don‚Äôt need it now‚Äù

- Client B: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have time to train our teams‚Äù

- Client C: ‚ÄúOur current solution is doing fine‚Äù

The problem solved is not painful enough to justify the cost.

And a lot of businesses are in this situation for 3 reasons:

- They didn‚Äôt include customers as part of the development

- They‚Äôve built a product based on weak market signals

- They thought ‚Äòproduct‚Äô first, then ‚Äògo to market‚Äô

As a result, they are NOT solving a PUR problem:

- Painful ‚Üí Prospects need to solve it

- Urgent ‚Üí They need to solve it now

- Recognized ‚Üí They can describe it
# References:
1. [https://www.linkedin.com/posts/pierre-herubel-540b3949_solving-the-wrong-market-problem-sounds-like-activity-7155832059846922240-RcLN/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/pierre-herubel-540b3949_solving-the-wrong-market-problem-sounds-like-activity-7155832059846922240-RcLN/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios)

title: Kreativitet uppst√•r i frihet, inte i fl√∂desscheman
ai_summary: Kreativitet uppst√•r i frihet snarare √§n genom strikt processkontroll. Det √§r viktigt att fokusera p√• vad som ska uppn√•s snarare √§n hur det ska ske. Kreativitet √§r en icke-linj√§r process som involverar serendipitet och variation, och organisationer b√∂r skapa ramar och syften f√∂r att m√∂jligg√∂ra kreativt arbete snarare √§n att detaljstyra varje steg. Detta g√§ller inte bara inom kreativa f√§lt utan √§ven i andra verksamheter f√∂r att fr√§mja innovation och engagemang.
body:
![Kreativitet.png](Kreativitet%20uppst%C3%A5r%20i%20frihet,%20inte%20i%20fl%C3%B6desscheman/Kreativitet.png)

**Kreativitet uppst√•r i frihet, inte i fl√∂desscheman**

Beskriv vad som ska uppn√•s, inte varje steg p√• v√§gen.

*Beskriv vad som ska uppn√•s, inte varje steg p√• v√§gen.*

ARTIKEL SUBSTACK (NEDAN)

# Kreativitet uppst√•r i frihet, inte i fl√∂desscheman

Att styra kreativa processer som om de vore produktionslinor √§r sj√§lvbedr√§geri. Det som g√•r att beskriva √§r ramar, syfte och output, inte varje steg p√• v√§gen.

### **F√∂rm√•gor i st√§llet f√∂r processer**

N√§r ett modehus ska ta fram en h√∂stkollektion √§r det meningsl√∂st att rita upp alla t√§nkbara steg: inspirationsresor, skisser, workshops, urval, provkollektioner. V√§gen dit √§r alltid olika, processen och *hur:et*. Det viktiga √§r att f√∂rm√•gan, vad man g√∂r, t.ex. *att ta fram en h√∂stkollektion* finns i organisationen. Den kan beskrivas i form av:

- Input: tema, material, budget, tidsramar
- Output: f√§rdig kollektion som kan lanseras p√• marknaden
- Ramar: aff√§rskrav, tid, resurser

Hur teamet n√•r dit √§r just den kreativa delen. F√∂rm√•gor handlar om *vad* som ska uppn√•s, inte *hur* det ska ske.

### **Kreativitet kan inte processkartl√§ggas fullt ut**

Flera har f√∂rs√∂kt processkartl√§gga kreativitet. Inom forskningen s√• tycker jag resultatet √§r tydlig. Kreativitet √§r inte en linj√§r process. Wallas klassiska modell med fem steg (f√∂rberedelse, inkubation, illumination, verifikation) erk√§nde att **stegen √∂verlappar och blandas**. Campbell och Simonton beskrev kreativitet som en evolution√§r urvalsprocess d√§r **slump och variation √§r avg√∂rande**.

Liane Gabora har i sin ‚Äúhoning theory‚Äù visat att kreativa id√©er snarare v√§xer fram som gradvisa omstruktureringar av en mental representation, inte som en sekventiell pipeline. Andra forskare betonar **serendipitet,** det ov√§ntade sammantr√§ffandet √§r ofta det som √∂ppnar v√§gen till nya l√∂sningar.

![I en fantastik liten bok s√• f√∂rs√∂kte jag tidigt i min karri√§r processkartl√§gga kreativitet, d√• jag jobbade enbart kreativt. N√•gra √•r slutade den illusionen vid en flygplats i London 2014.](Kreativitet%20uppst%C3%A5r%20i%20frihet,%20inte%20i%20fl%C3%B6desscheman/Uppslag_Frilagd.png)

I en fantastik liten bok s√• f√∂rs√∂kte jag tidigt i min karri√§r processkartl√§gga kreativitet, d√• jag jobbade enbart kreativt. N√•gra √•r slutade den illusionen vid en flygplats i London 2014.

### **Andra som ha givit en hint**

> ‚ÄúThe creative process is a process of surrender, not control.‚Äù 
- Julia Cameron
> 

> ‚ÄúThe creative process is not controlled by a switch you can simply turn on or off; it‚Äôs with you all the time.‚Äù 
- Alvin Ailey
> 

Att f√∂rs√∂ka detaljstyra blir kontraproduktivt. Organisationen skapar falsk trygghet och tappar konkurrenskraft.

### **Slutsats**

Den som vill ha resultat m√•ste ge f√∂ruts√§ttningar. S√§tt ramar. Klarg√∂r syftet. Beskriv vilken f√∂rm√•ga (eller funktion) som ska aktiveras. Beskriv *vad* som ska g√∂ras. Men l√§mna v√§gen dit, *hur*, √•t de som kan sitt hantverk.

F√∂r kreativitet h√∂r inte bara hemma i modehus och innovationslabb. √Ñven ink√∂p, kundtj√§nst och administration beh√∂ver utrymme f√∂r att m√§nniskor ska kunna t√§nja p√• formen, pr√∂va nytt och f√∂rvandla bra till fantastiskt. Det √§r s√• organisationer blir levande och det √§r s√• man √§r fortsatt en kraft att r√§kna med. M√•nga skriver innovation med massa mumbojumbo. Men kreativitet √§r hj√§rtat av allt.

John Cleese sa det bra:

> Vet du vad den st√∂rsta fienden mot kreativitet √§r?
Det √§r att du inte till√•ts g√∂ra fel.
> 

[John Cleese on Creativity In Management](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pb5oIIPO62g)

Det b√§sta √§r om kreativitet och nyfikenhet blir en del av er kultur p√• riktigt oavsett vad processen s√§ger att den h√∂r hemma.

title: What Is Jobs-to-be-Done-
ai_summary: A job-to-be-done describes what people aim to achieve in a situation, expressed as a statement that includes a verb, an object, and optional context, such as "pass on life lessons to children" or "repair a torn rotator cuff.
body:
## Metadata
* URL: [https://jobs-to-be-done.com/what-is-jobs-to-be-done-fea59c8e39eb](https://jobs-to-be-done.com/what-is-jobs-to-be-done-fea59c8e39eb)
* Author: Tony Ulwick
* Publisher: jobs-to-be-done.com
* Published Date: 2020-11-10
* Tags:

## Highlights

- A JOB-TO-BE-DONE is a statement that describes, with precision, what a group of people are trying to achieve or accomplish in a given situation. A job-to-be-done could be a task that people are trying to accomplish, a goal or objective they are trying to achieve, a problem they are trying to resolve, something they are trying to avoid, or anything else they are trying to accomplish. A job statement is written as [verb] + [object of the verb] + [contextual clarifier] (optionally). For example, pass on life lessons to children, repair a torn rotator cuff and prevent a shooter from entering a school, are all jobs-to-be-done.

Om det inte g√∂r det s√• har troligen du inte ett fungerande systematiskt arbete. Inom ISO 9001 (kvalit√©tsarbetet) s√• har jag valt att g√∂ra f√∂ljande tolkning:
üìå Systematiskt kvalitetsarbete √§r det strukturerade s√§tt som en organisation anv√§nder f√∂r att planera, genomf√∂ra, f√∂lja upp, utv√§rdera och f√∂rb√§ttra sina processer, produkter och tj√§nster, s√• att de uppfyller kunders krav och andra intressenters f√∂rv√§ntningar ‚Äî med st√§ndiga f√∂rb√§ttringar och l√§rande som grund.

√Ötg√§rd ‚Äì korrigerande eller f√∂rebyggande"] n1 -- Utv√§rdering vidare --> R T --> R %% --- FORM OCH KLASSER --- A:::audit AH:::adhoc F:::finding n1:::finding T:::task R:::review AU:::audit K:::knowledge %% --- FORMDEFINITIONER --- AH@{shape: proc} n1@{shape: diam} %% --- F√ÑRGSTILAR --- classDef audit fill:#D9EAFD,stroke:#2B6CB0,stroke-width:1px classDef adhoc fill:#FDEBD0,stroke:#C0392B,stroke-width:1px classDef task fill:#EAF2F8,stroke:#1B4F72,stroke-width:1px classDef review fill:#E8F8F5,stroke:#117A65,stroke-width:1px classDef knowledge fill:#E9F7EF,stroke:#1E8449,stroke-width:1px classDef finding fill:#FDFEFE,stroke:#85929E,stroke-width:1px ``` ![CleanShot 2025-10-14 at 09.45.22@2x.png](Saknade%20pusselbiten%20f%C3%B6r%20systematiskt%20arbete/CleanShot_2025-10-14_at_09.45.222x.png) ## **Systematiskt kvalitetsarbete ‚Äì gemensam l√§randeloop f√∂r Audit och Ad-hoc** Det systematiska kvalitetsarbetet skapar en tydlig struktur f√∂r hur uppt√§ckter leder till l√§rande och f√∂rb√§ttring. Fl√∂det ser ut s√• h√§r: **Audit / Ad-hoc Event ‚Üí Finding ‚Üí Task ‚Üí Review ‚Üí Audit Update / Knowledge Base** ## **Audit** Planerad och strukturerad granskning som syftar till att verifiera att processer, rutiner och krav fungerar som avsett. Audit identifierar m√∂nster, systemfel eller brister i efterlevnad, men √§ven f√∂rb√§ttringsm√∂jligheter. > ‚ÄùVid internrevision uppt√§cktes att incidentrapporter inte f√∂ljs upp inom beslutad tid.‚Äù > **Typ:** Planerad, formell **Output:** Findings ‚Äì avvikelser, observationer eller f√∂rb√§ttringsf√∂rslag **Frekvens:** √Örlig, kvartalsvis eller enligt revisionsplan ## **Ad-hoc Event** Spontan h√§ndelse eller observation fr√•n verksamheten ‚Äî ofta en incident, f√∂rb√§ttringsid√© eller o√∂nskad h√§ndelse. Ad-hoc √§r en reaktiv k√§lla till l√§rande och ofta f√∂rsta signalen p√• ett problem som systemet √§nnu inte f√•ngat. > ‚ÄùEn anv√§ndare rapporterar manuellt dubbelarbete i tv√• system.‚Äù > **Typ:** Oplanerad, operativ **Output:** Findings **Viktigt:** M√•ste kopplas in i samma systematiska loop, annars blir l√§randet lokalt och f√∂rsvinner. ## **Finding** Uppt√§ckter som kan vara en avvikelse vi vill hantera. Det kan √§ven stanna som en observation, eller n√•got som beh√∂ver bevakas. En finding ska alltid v√§rderas ‚Äì √§r det n√•got som kr√§ver √•tg√§rd, uppf√∂ljning eller endast dokumentation? > ‚ÄùFlera avdelningar anv√§nder olika kunddefinitioner i sina rapporter.‚Äù > **Syfte:** Samla och kategorisera vad som uppt√§cks, oavsett k√§lla **Resultat:** Prioritering av vad som ska hanteras vidare ## **Task** Konkreta aktiviteter f√∂r att √•tg√§rda eller f√∂rb√§ttra. Kan vara korrigerande √•tg√§rder (r√§tta till) eller f√∂rebyggande √•tg√§rder (undvika att det h√§nder igen). > ‚ÄùHarmoniserade kunddefinitioner (begrepp) i CRM och BI-system.‚Äù > **Ansvar:** Tydligt utpekad √§gare **Sp√•rbarhet:** Status, prioritet, deadline **Dokumentation:** Vad som gjordes, n√§r, och varf√∂r ## **Review** Utv√§rdering av resultatet och l√§randet. H√§r analyseras om √•tg√§rden l√∂ste problemet, och vad vi kan l√§ra oss: - Fungerade l√∂sningen? - Fanns rotorsaker vi missade? - Borde audit-systemet ha uppt√§ckt detta tidigare? > ‚ÄùEfter tre m√•nader visar m√§tning att antalet datakonflikter minskat med 90 %, men vi beh√∂ver √§ven uppdatera rapporteringsrutiner.‚Äù > **Syfte:** Bed√∂ma effekt och identifiera l√§rdomar ## **Audit Update** N√§r l√§rdomen visar att kontrollsystemet eller revisionsplanen beh√∂ver uppdateras. Det kan handla om nya kontrollpunkter, f√∂r√§ndrade urval eller uppdaterade checklistor. > ‚ÄùL√§gg till kontrollpunkt f√∂r dubbelregistrering i n√§sta internrevision.‚Äù > **Syfte:** G√∂ra revisionen smartare n√§sta g√•ng ## **Knowledge Base** N√§r l√§rdomen g√§ller arbetss√§ttet snarare √§n kontrollen. H√§r uppdateras processbeskrivningar, riktlinjer, mallar och rutiner. Syftet √§r att s√§kra kollektivt l√§rande och sprida f√∂rb√§ttringen till hela organisationen. > ‚ÄùInf√∂rt gemensamt dokumentationsfl√∂de i processbiblioteket.‚Äù > **Syfte:** F√∂rvalta l√§rande och f√∂rb√§ttra arbetss√§tt

title: The problem with Context Switching
ai_summary: Focus on completing one task at a time and avoid distractions; prioritize important tasks and eliminate those that aren't necessary.
body:
Do one thing and be done with it. Fight it to the end.
If the task isn‚Äôt important. Then, it shouldn‚Äôt be done in the first place.
But if you have a priority. Stick to that and don‚Äôt get distracted.

The quote is held by Marc Zuckeberg

Everything that can go wrong will do (law of)
All you have to have is faith.

1. ‚ÄúHope for the best, but don‚Äôt be surprised when the worst shows up at your door.‚Äù

title: I'm focusing on long-term organization survival, not next quarter's profit.
ai_summary: Focusing on long-term organizational survival rather than short-term profits involves rejecting quick turnaround requests and instead building a solid foundation for change. This includes recalibrating expectations, setting new goals, and gaining team commitment. The author is also working on a book about staying relevant to customers by identifying future problems to solve.
body:
I'm focusing on long-term organization survival, not next quarter's profit.

When I get an ask if I can help with a quick turnaround I usually say no. What I have done is going into project where often a few persons already have tried. After a while we create a better foundation for the change and callibrating expetations. We set new goals and get the team onboard for real.

To get some things out of my head I usually end up in writing something. Now I‚Äôm currently focusing on finnishing my book on that topic, ‚Äúhow to stay relevant for your customer by finding future problems to solve‚Äù.

title: Is your Business map or model relevant
ai_summary: For effective mapping in business changes, set clear purposes, involve diverse stakeholders, test early for feedback, and iterate to deliver value. Context is crucial for understanding and creating useful maps.
body:
Facing a big system change? User stories alone won‚Äôt cut it. And process mapping? That is not the answer either. Design thinking? Nope, not for this.
What you really need is to set the right context. You need a map!
I‚Äôll admit, as a former project manager, I didn‚Äôt know what I didn‚Äôt know. It took me a while to accept that I was missing the big picture. Remember Obi-Wan in Return of the Jedi?

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to find that many of the truths we cling to depend greatly on our own point of view.‚Äù

Yep, context is everything‚Äîeven when it comes to ‚Äútruth.‚Äù
So, here‚Äôs my two cents for creating better maps:

Set the purpose

‚Üí Why are we doing this, and who‚Äôs it for?
Start with a small team
‚Üí Keep it simple. Create a map with minimal effort.
3. Get different perspectives
‚Üí Mix up your stakeholders to avoid tunnel vision.
Test the map early

‚Üí Get feedback ASAP. Make sure you‚Äôre on the right track!
Iterate and deliver value
‚Üí Keep tweaking. Deliver results regularly that matter in your context.

Here‚Äôs a little secret: Sometimes, I intentionally do something wrong. Why? If the person across from me has an opinion, they‚Äôll help fix it‚Äîand now, we‚Äôre stuck in co-creating the map!
What extra questions do you ask when creating a map or model? Let me know! üëá

Earlier version below‚Ä¶..
If you face a larger change for a central system replacement, you will always come short with only user stories. It would help if you didn‚Äôt do process mapping; design thinking is not for this purpose.
You need to set the context or your point of view.
As an earlier project Manager, this was a problem I didn‚Äôt have enough knowledge to begin to accept that I had a problem :-) I didn‚Äôt know what I didn‚Äôt know.
Today, I think everything is in a context, even the ‚Äútruth‚Äù people discuss. As Obi-Wan says in Return of the Jedi, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to find that many of the truths we cling to depend greatly on our own point of view.‚Äù
My two cents for creating better maps:

Set the purpose
‚Ü≥ WHY and for WHO?
Start with a small team
‚Ü≥ Create a map with minimum effort.
Get different perspective
‚Ü≥ Vary your stakeholders in your meeting
Test the map very very early
‚Ü≥ Get Feedback that you are on the right track!
Iterate, redo and deliver the result
‚Ü≥ Create VALUE frequently in the context of your organisation.

The most important thing is that you bring different perspectives and ask around. Sometimes, I intentionally do something wrong, and if the person on the other side has an opinion, I fix it, and then the person is stuck in creating the map :-)
What are the additional questions you ask when creating a map or model?

title: How to Make Your Next Team Review Useful
ai_summary: To make team reviews constructive, ask three questions: What went well? What didn't go well? What should we do differently next time? Focus on learning and improvement rather than blame to enhance future performance.
body:
How to Make Your Next Team Review Useful
Let‚Äôs be real‚Äîmost post-project reviews can feel like a blame game. But they don‚Äôt have to! Here‚Äôs a better way to approach it with three easy questions that can lead to real improvements:

1. What Went Well?
Start with the positives: ‚ÄúWhat went well, and how can we do that again?‚Äù
It‚Äôs easy to jump straight into what went wrong, but first, let‚Äôs celebrate the wins. If something worked, let‚Äôs make sure we don‚Äôt forget it next time!
2. What Didn‚Äôt Go Well?
Next, it‚Äôs time for some constructive feedback: ‚ÄúWhat didn‚Äôt go so well, and what did we learn from it?‚Äù
No one‚Äôs perfect, and that‚Äôs fine. But let‚Äôs focus on what we can learn instead of just pointing fingers. The goal is to avoid making the same mistakes again.
3. What Should We Do Differently Next Time?*
Finally, let‚Äôs look ahead: ‚ÄúWhat can we tweak to make things run even smoother next time?‚Äù
This is where we take the lessons from what went well and what didn‚Äôt and turn them into new ideas for improvement. It‚Äôs all about getting better, not staying stuck. Remember that improvement is better than perfect.

These three simple questions keep things positive and productive. Plus, they help avoid those awkward blame moments we all dread if you look at what we have learned.
Did I miss anything? üëá

Three very easy questions to ask yourself in the middle and after something has happened:
1. What Went Well?
2. What Didn‚Äôt Go Well?
3. What would be our new Standards?
By asking your team these questions and asking them to write a few words and read them out loud at the beginning of a meeting, you can neutrally get into what we can change and make better next time.

Step 1: What Went Well

We begin every AAR by asking this question:

‚ÄúWhat replicable new learning did we gain from what went well?‚Äù
In any post-mortem, our brains can naturally focus on what went wrong. However, it is critical to get clear on what went RIGHT so the good can be repeated.

‚Äî

Step 2: What Didn‚Äôt Go Well

After reviewing what went well and the successes we can repeat in the future, we move on to constructive criticism.

We frame the discussion with a similar question:

‚ÄúWhat replicable new learning did we gain from what did not go well?‚Äù

Notice - the question isn‚Äôt asking what went wrong‚Ä¶ specifically what is the new LESSON we can incorporate for the future.

‚Äî

Step 3: New Standards

Once we‚Äôve dissected the lessons from what went well and what didn‚Äôt, we turn our focus to the future.

Combining the insights from the first two steps, we assess the following::

‚ÄúDrawing upon questions 1 and 2, what changes can we make to our processes to systematically improve our consistent tactical excellence?‚Äù

This reinforces that the standard is excellence, clear process is how we get there, and asks what improvements to our process move us ahead?
# References

[https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mattschnuck_navy-seals-use-a-tool-called-aars-after-activity-7092170889957425152-t23T?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mattschnuck_navy-seals-use-a-tool-called-aars-after-activity-7092170889957425152-t23T?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios)
