title: TBM 308- Boundary of Safely Challenged Assumptions
ai_summary: To effectively address issues during crises, teams must be closely integrated with the technology and people involved. A blameless approach should focus on systemic failures rather than individual mistakes, emphasizing that organizations should be designed to handle change and challenges effectively. The ideal team size is one that can function well in a crisis.
body:
TBM 308- Boundary of Safely Challenged Assumptions
* Note: If you need to understand what have happened when shit hits the fan you need to be where the work was executed. You need talk to people and you need to understand technology.
* Tags:

## Highlights

- To have a clear sense of what is going on‚Äîespecially when something is going wrong‚Äîyou need to be very close to the people and technology (sociotechnical) close to the work. Comparing teams isn‚Äôt as helpful as we might think.
- software company has a multi-day (technology) outage, loses millions of dollars, its
- Ideally, these activities are ‚Äúblameless‚Äù and explore human factors, incentives, and other system-oriented areas.
    - **Note**: When something really catastrophic happens it is always the system that is wrong. Not the individual. A good system prevents the real ugly impacts. A single person has seldom that influence.
    The reason for a bad system comes from management.
- What if we should be designing our software development organizations based on the premise that 1) shit happens, change happens, things change, and therefore 2) the maximum size of a team of teams should be the largest group of people that can actually challenge its own assumptions under challenging conditions (not ideal conditions).
    - **Note**: What is the ideal size of an team?
    The size that can fuction in a crisis.
    Like
    Mikitary!
- One of the central problems is that we create idealized structures that only work under ideal conditions
## Reference
[https://getmatter.com/email/48357018/?token=48357018%3ADHaH2hNvpIuQiiwe95MI5RMXS-Y](https://getmatter.com/email/48357018/?token=48357018%3ADHaH2hNvpIuQiiwe95MI5RMXS-Y)

title: No one accurately sees the world as it is
ai_summary: Everyone perceives the world differently based on their experiences, and no one sees it as it truly is. Instead of striving for correctness, we should aim to share useful perspectives that acknowledge diverse viewpoints, recognizing that each person's experience is valid.
body:
Seth Godin wrote
No one accurately sees the world as it is.
A rock climber doesn‚Äôt see a steep slope the same way an elderly person does.
Both are correct from their point of view. And the same goes with every ‚Äútruth‚Äù.
What we need to do is accept that we see the world in a useful way that can be shared.
Don‚Äôt try to always get it correct. Be useful instead.

A person with hearing loss doesn‚Äôt experience the world the same way a synesthete does. A rock climber doesn‚Äôt see a steep slope the same way an elderly person does. And an optimist and a pessimist rarely experience opportunities in identical ways.
And each is correct.
Correct in that their experience of the world is their experience of the world. It‚Äôs not possible for anyone to actually see the world as it is.
But there‚Äôs a significant opportunity we can work toward:
To experience the world in a useful way.
Not correctly, but usefully.

title: Do you need a single point of truth Use a map!
ai_summary: Maps serve as essential tools for navigation and transparency within organizations, promoting clarity and order, though they may be resisted by those accustomed to operating in secrecy. Leonardo da Vinci's 1502 ichnographic map exemplifies the transformation of cartography into an informational asset.
body:
Already 500 years ago‚Ä¶

> [!info] This Old Map: Da Vinci‚Äôs Plan of Imola, 1502
> 
> 
> The fourth installment in this occasional series features the world‚Äôs earliest surviving ‚Äúichnographic‚Äù map.
> 
> [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-22/this-old-map-da-vinci-s-plan-of-imola-1502](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-22/this-old-map-da-vinci-s-plan-of-imola-1502)
> 

![[Untitled 20.png|Untitled 20.png]]

![[Untitled 1 4.png|Untitled 1 4.png]]

I have always been facinated by maps. My first job was to create informationsmaps for cities in Sweden finances by small ads 5x5 cm. A lot of them :-) At the time we only created printed versions in end of 1990. The purpose of the map was of course to navigate and find what location you where looking for.

> [!info] How Leonardo da Vinci made a ‚Äúsatellite‚Äù map in 1502
> 
> 
> It was a feat of technological and symbolic imagination.
> 
> [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2gEwEcYnewE&t=252s](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2gEwEcYnewE&t=252s)
> 

Maps can have a different purpose.
Maps can be created by people with an agenda.

One of the first ‚Äúsatellite‚Äù maps was created in 1502 for the Italian town of Imola, drawn by none other than Leonardo Da Vinci. The purpose of this map was to help Cesare Borgia, son of Pope Alexander VI and marshal of the papal troops, become more aware of the town‚Äôs layout for defence.

The type is a concept of [ichnographic](https://bigthink.com/strange-maps/geoglyphs/) maps that was developed by the Roman architect Vitruvius to describe the art of drawing realistic ground plans. A simplification.

## Maps of today

If you use Leonardo Da Vincis 500 year old map you can still walk around in the center of old town and navigate with it.

The Iconograpic is what we are used to see the world as today.

![[Untitled 2 4.png|Untitled 2 4.png]]

But it is just a simplification. The truth is much more complex.

![[Untitled 3 4.png|Untitled 3 4.png]]

But that doesn‚Äôt help you most of the time.
A flat representation does.

## Single point of truth

We belive that you need a map to be able to navigate in your organisation or enterprise. And what is most important is that this map becomes single point of truth and adding transparency in your work.

What is true is that everyone dosen‚Äôt like this! If people in the organisation are used to work in the shadows without anyone else knowing what they do, how they do it and what purpose they have a map wont be their friend. A map will bring clarity and some order. It will help change. And most middle manager don‚Äôt like that because we disturb the status que.

[**1**](https://www.vox.com/2019/4/11/18306214/leonardo-map-imola)

[**2**](https://www.rct.uk/collection/912284/a-map-of-imola)

.¬†Leonardo was appointed as Cesare Borgia‚Äôs military engineer, giving him the power to requisition men for surveying and to order improvements to fortifications

[**2**](https://www.rct.uk/collection/912284/a-map-of-imola)

.¬†To create the map, Leonardo combined cutting-edge surveying techniques with his artistic imagination, resulting in a groundbreaking ‚Äúichnographic‚Äù map that transformed cartography from a partly imaginative exercise to an informational asset

[**1**](https://www.vox.com/2019/4/11/18306214/leonardo-map-imola)

.¬†The map was centered in a circle with four crossing lines, representing the points on a compass, and showed the city from above, marking the points of the compass around its perimeter

[**3**](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-22/this-old-map-da-vinci-s-plan-of-imola-1502)

[**6**](https://www.leonardo-da-vinci.net/plan-of-imola/)

.¬†The resulting map was accurate enough to navigate the Italian city today

[**5**](https://www.nationalgeographic.co.uk/history-and-civilisation/2020/05/leonardo-da-vinci-transformed-mapping-from-art-to-science)

.

An ichnographic map is a type of map that shows the area on the ground as if the viewer were directly above it

[**1**](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/d17cf0a6f6f24bd197c31de7ed7f9def)

.¬†This type of map is different from other types of maps, such as hillside (bird‚Äôs-eye) perspective maps, which show the subject aslant and are usually inexact and incomplete

[**2**](https://bigthink.com/strange-maps/geoglyphs/)

.¬†Ichnographic maps, on the other hand, are accurate and complete, showing all buildings and features in a flattened-out, bird‚Äôs-eye view

[**5**](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-22/this-old-map-da-vinci-s-plan-of-imola-1502)

.¬†The concept of ichnographic maps was developed by the Roman architect Vitruvius to describe the art of drawing realistic ground plans

[**2**](https://bigthink.com/strange-maps/geoglyphs/)

.¬†Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs City Plan, 1502 of the Italian town of Imola was a groundbreaking ichnographic map that transformed cartography from a partly imaginative exercise to an informational asset

[**1**](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/d17cf0a6f6f24bd197c31de7ed7f9def)

[**3**](https://www.vox.com/2019/4/11/18306214/leonardo-map-imola)

title: N√§r jag sa till en CEO: ‚ÄùDu l√∂ser inget riktigt problem.‚Äù

body:
[N√§r jag sa till en CEO: ‚ÄùDu l√∂ser inget riktigt problem.‚Äù](https://thomaslarsson.substack.com/p/nar-jag-sa-till-en-ceo-du-loser-inget)

Jag tr√§ffade en startup som ville ha hj√§lp med sitt budskap. En klassiker. De hade byggt n√•got ‚Äúintelligent‚Äù med AI, automation och realtidsanalys. En adaptiv plattform, som det s√• fint hette.

Jag bad dem f√∂rklara sin produkt.

‚ÄúAI-driven automation, prediktiv analys, en adaptiv plattform med machine learning och realtidsinsikter riktade mot customer engagement.‚Äù

Jag sa: ‚ÄúOkej‚Ä¶ men vad √§r det riktiga problem ni f√∂rs√∂ker l√∂sa? F√∂r vem?‚Äù

D√• kom svaret jag ofta h√∂r: ‚ÄúAllts√•, kunden beh√∂ver ju bara ett smartare system. Det √§r ju det som √§r grejen.‚Äù Egentligen s√§ger de inte exakt det, men det √§r vad de egentligen s√§ger.

Jag f√∂rklarade att det d√§r inte √§r ett problem. Det √§r en l√∂sning. Eller r√§ttare sagt: det √§r buzzword bingo. Jag fr√•gade inte vad tekniken hette. Jag fr√•gade vad kunden har f√∂r problem?

De fortsatte. ‚ÄúMen det √§r ju AI! Det √§r framtiden!‚Äù

Och d√§r n√•gonstans fick jag s√§ga det som vi m√•ste s√§ga oftare:

‚ÄúSom jag ser det l√∂ser du ett hitte-p√•-problem. Och du vet inte heller vem kunden √§r.‚Äù

Tystnad. Sedan: ‚ÄúS√• du menar allts√• att vi bara fluffar runt?‚Äù

Jag svarade: ‚ÄúJa. Fast dyrt. Med investerarnas pengar.‚Äù

Det blev tyst igen. Och sen, lite ov√§ntat.

‚ÄúOkej. N√§r kan du b√∂rja jobba med oss d√•?‚Äù

Det h√§r h√§nder oftare √§n man tror, att n√•gon inte riktigt vet vilket problem de ska l√∂sa. D√§remot h√§nder det inte s√• ofta att en CEO f√•r h√∂ra sanningen.

Min po√§ng √§r: Mina kunder √§r inte dumma, bara lite vilse ibland. De saknar ofta n√•gon som s√§ger ifr√•n. Som v√•gar kalla det f√∂r vad det √§r, fluff. Hitte-p√•. Teknik utan behov.

I Startup-v√§rlden √§r det enkelt. Om du inte kan peka ut vem som har ett riktigt problem, och hur det p√•verkar deras vardag, s√• har du inte ett f√∂retag. Du har en PowerPoint med feature-listor.

Och det √§r inget att bygga p√•.

Det borde inte du g√∂ra heller, √§ven om du inte driver en startup.

title: The Chinese long term goals
ai_keywords: Incremental Growth, Long-Term Success, Strategic Adaptation
ai_summary: The Communist Party of China's long-term goal is to restore China to a position of global influence aligned with its ancestral heritage, aiming for a technological transformation akin to the industrial revolution. The perceived ideological threats to this rise are global, and Chinese leaders plan to reshape the global order primarily through economic means rather than military force.
body:
In school, we learned about the plan economy and the five-year plan. It is supposed to be wrong, and everything with capitalism would be good. Today, I guess, the world has seen the bad from the outskirts of both sides.
For many years, I have been interested in the East, as a karate practitioner, and in a major interest in Chinese history. I worked with a Chinese team for six years, full-time remotely from Sweden.
I‚Äôm not an expert in China or the UK, but I smile a little when a representative from China tries to explain how they see the UK as a competition. None is the answer. ‚ÄúI consider them important friends and business partners who have mutual value.‚Äù
The quote: ‚ÄúI think the British overestimate their importance on the global scene.‚Äù
The long-term goal stretches in intervals of 5, 50, and 500 years. To restore China to a position of glory in line with ancestral heritage. In the West, our politicians can‚Äôt agree on 500 days.

The Five Fundamentals of Chinese Grand Strategy

title: Patterns and chaos
ai_keywords: Growth Mindset, Problem Identification, Reflective Strategy Development
ai_summary: Identifying patterns in business can provide understanding and leverage, but sometimes chaos and unpredictability prevail. It requires effort to find patterns and humility to accept the absence of them.
body:
[[Patterns of Business (Now)]]
It would help if you held on to something. What products or services do you sell? We need to find patterns and understand how everything is connected. Some would say that it doesn‚Äôt need to be connected.
You need plenty of models.
They do not always align.
Sometimes its just caos.
But you might find patterns and correlations.
There yours stating Point.
Finding a pattern that explains events that seem like chaos is a breakthrough. It offers us understanding and a lever we can use to make an impact.
Sometimes, though, the breakthrough lies in understanding that there is no pattern, simply unpredictable noise. We need effort to find patterns. We need humility to accept the chaos.
## Reference
[https://seths.blog/2024/07/patterns-and-chaos/](https://seths.blog/2024/07/patterns-and-chaos/)

title: Align how to prioritise for everyone to accept and work towards common goals
ai_summary: To achieve alignment in prioritization, eliminate reliance on the Highest Paid Person's Opinion and use a single transparent process for approving projects. If the current process is inadequate, it should be changed rather than creating new priority lines.
body:

- [x] Due üóìÔ∏è(@[[2024-08-30]])

![[Pasted image 20240805200722.png]]
There will always be a gap in how to prioritise in an organisation. Often, it is based on HIPPO, the Highest Paid Persons Opinion. But if you accept that, there will never be alignment.
Instead, you must remove the priority line at checkout to approve projects or initiatives.
All should be handled equally, using the same transparent process and criteria for approval.
If that process isn‚Äôt suitable for the management:
Change the process and redo the prioritisation.
Do not open a new priority line.

Only use one way of prioritising initiatives in an organisation.

title: Operational Excellence with Airtable
ai_summary: Achieve enterprise alignment by using Airtable for data transparency and operational efficiency, replacing disconnected Excel files with integrated workflows, and adopting incremental changes for flexibility and trust in decision-making.
body:
[[Excel]] [[Airtable]]
Status: #article

How to reach enterprise alignment by using transparency for the descisions and data that support it.
In most cases we seek to align our enterprise to whatever end we need to focus. Often there is no one that is responsible to overseeing it from end-to-end.
I have come to the conclusion that what is to often broken is the information and systems that is actually drivning the organisation.
There is stable ground in our core systems, such as ERP and CRM, from vendors like SAP, Microsoft, Oracle, or IBM.
But between that and the strategy in Power Point there is just an unstructure mess of Excels. And more Power Points. And on top of that some Process Description that is made by one of the big 4.

I think it is in this middle where you can make all the difference.
5 years ago, the NoCode weren‚Äôt so Enterprise ready. But boy, is it now! You would need a stack of tools that can create that efficient workflow and optimized processes. And one tool is sticking out more than all others.
Airtable.
It can be the central for all data used for operational management.
It can connect to for e.g.¬†SAP, Salesforce and pretty much anything else. Even an Excel file :-)
In the transition from 1 000 of Excel-files that stears the organisation you need to take it piece by piece. Have a initial thoughts on how to do this with the basics of information and process mapping. Then iterate. One Excel at the time. One workflow at the time.
And here is the thing. It needs to be super-adaptive to change. What we know after 5 excel isn‚Äôt the same as after 100.
So make the transition from a unefficient way of working to something that gives you and true advantage and start trusting your data again.

On tool to rule them all

A large problem in organisations is a lack of ownership of enterprise alignment. There is no one overseeing the enterprise from end-to-end.

Remove your Excel Nightmare: Find a replacement for middle management Tools.
Enterprise alignment is often hindered by a need for more transparency and accountability, particularly across the systems and data that drive decision-making. Many organizations have a stable core - ERP and CRM systems - but a messy middle filled with disconnected Excel files and scattered PowerPoints.
The real opportunity lies in fixing this chaotic middle. Here‚Äôs is an idea for you:
Focus on Data Transparency
‚Üí Ensure all data that drives decisions is easily accessible and trustworthy.
Use NoCode Tools
‚Üí Modern NoCode solutions, like Airtable, are now enterprise-ready and can fill the gaps.
Connect Systems Seamlessly
‚Üí Integrate Airtable with ERP, CRM, and even legacy tools like Excel.
Adopt Incremental Changes
‚Üí Move from all your excel-files by iterating one file, one workflow at a time.
Stay flexible
‚Üí Build systems that can change and evolve often; what you know today isn‚Äôt the same as what you know in a few months.

To achieve alignment, you need a system that is flexible and transparent. Airtable can be your central hub, connecting disparate data sources and driving operational efficiency. Start replacing the Excel chaos piece by piece, transform it into a reliable system, and trust the data again for better and faster decisions.¬†
When it comes around, it is the decision we need to be better at.

title: Redefining success- why outcomes not output truly matter
ai_summary: Output refers to the act of creating, while outcome is the impact of that output. Understanding the relationship between output and outcome is crucial, as significant output can occur without meaningful outcomes. The focus should be on identifying what generates effective outcomes early in the process.
body:
Output is putting stuff into the world.

Outcome is the effect of the output.

There can be no outcome without output,
but there can be a lot of output without any outcome.
The main question is if we can learn to understand what is giving effect, or not, early. I think that is the most important step in the process of all things we do.
What do you think?

title: Att bli datadriven b√∂rjar med ett problem, inte med ett verktyg
ai_summary: Att bli datadriven b√∂rjar med att identifiera och l√∂sa konkreta problem snarare √§n att bara k√∂pa verktyg och samla data. Det handlar om att hitta relevant data f√∂r att f√∂rst√• problemen, testa hypoteser, och dela insikter som en ber√§ttelse f√∂r att bygga en datadriven kultur. Genom att fokusera p√• verkliga utmaningar kan organisationer gradvis f√∂r√§ndra sitt arbetss√§tt och bli mer datadrivna.
body:
Vilken story vill du ber√§tta om ditt data? Det l√•ter ju s√• bra! Det st√•r i n√§stan varje strategidokument numera. ‚ÄúVi ska bli datadrivna.‚Äù

Men vad betyder det egentligen?

F√∂r m√•nga betyder det: vi k√∂per ett nytt verktyg, samlar in √§nnu mer data, dumpar allt i en data lake, och hoppas att n√•gon hittar n√•got anv√§ndbart. Som att spela ‚Äúfinns i sj√∂n‚Äù med hela organisationens beslut.

Men oftast h√§nder inget. F√∂r man har gl√∂mt det viktigaste: vilket problem f√∂rs√∂ker vi faktiskt l√∂sa?

## N√•gra punkter mot att bli datadriven, som ger resultat

1. B√∂rja med n√•got som skaver

Det finns n√§stan alltid n√•got som skaver i verksamheten. En flaskhals. N√•got som tar f√∂r l√•ng tid. N√•got som borde g√• att f√∂rklara men som alla bara ‚Äúk√§nner p√• sig‚Äù.

D√§r ska man b√∂rja. Inte i framtiden, utan i nuet. Inte i visionen, utan i vardagen.

Exempel: Varf√∂r halkar vi efter i leveranser? Varf√∂r tappar vi kunder efter onboarding? Varf√∂r tar vissa beslut s√• l√•ng tid?

N√§r du har en konkret fr√•ga, d√• har du n√•got att unders√∂ka.

1. Hitta relevant data

D√• f√∂rst √§r det dags att prata data. Inte all data. Inte ‚Äúvi borde m√§ta allt‚Äù. Utan: vilken data kan hj√§lpa oss f√∂rst√• just det h√§r problemet b√§ttre?

Det kan vara siffror. Det kan vara m√∂nster. Det kan vara loggar, samtal, e-post, kund√§renden, excelfiler. Det beh√∂ver inte vara perfekt. Det beh√∂ver bara vara tillr√§ckligt f√∂r att b√∂rja dra en slutsats.

1. Testa. Misslyckas. L√§r dig.

Sen testar man. Kanske hittar man inget. Kanske hittar man n√•got. Man f√∂rs√∂ker se samband. Pr√∂var hypoteser. Pratar med folk. G√∂r fel. F√•r nya id√©er.

Det √§r inte s√§rskilt digitalt. Det √§r bara vanligt arbete. Skillnaden √§r att man jobbar med verkligheten, inte med gissningar.

1. Och viktigast av allt. Ber√§tta!

N√§r man v√§l hittar n√•got som funkar, √§r det l√§tt att g√• vidare till n√§sta grej.

Men h√§r √§r ett b√§ttre r√•d: stanna upp. Skriv ner det. Visa hur ni t√§nkte. Ber√§tta vad ni s√•g. Vad ni √§ndrade. Vad resultatet blev.

Ber√§tta det som en story. F√∂r andra i organisationen. F√∂r chefer. F√∂r nya team. F√∂r er sj√§lva.

F√∂r det √§r s√• man bygger kultur. Inte med dashboards, utan med en story.

1. Och s√• g√∂r ni om det

N√§sta g√•ng √§r det lite l√§ttare. N√•gon annan i organisationen t√§nker: ‚ÄúHmm, kan vi kolla p√• datat innan vi gissar?‚Äù

Och n√§sta g√•ng igen √§r det kanske n√•gon som ber om hj√§lp med att tolka ett m√∂nster.

Efter ett tag har n√•got f√∂r√§ndrats. Folk b√∂rjar leta efter orsaker, inte symtom. De b√∂rjar fr√•ga efter data, inte efter mer magk√§nsla.

D√• har ni b√∂rjat bli datadrivna. Inte f√∂r att ni sa det, utan f√∂r att ni visade det.

---

LinkedIn

Datadriven kultur b√∂rjar inte med data. Den b√∂rjar med ett problem.

Det √§r l√§tt att s√§ga att man vill bli datadriven. Det l√•ter modernt. Strategiskt. R√§tt.

S√• man k√∂per ett verktyg, samlar mer data, s√§tter upp dashboards och v√§ntar p√• f√∂r√§ndring.

Men ingenting h√§nder. F√∂r man har inte b√∂rjat i r√§tt √§nde (den h√§r g√•ngen heller).

Vill ni bli datadrivna p√• riktigt?

B√∂rja i det som skaver. Det ni inte riktigt f√∂rst√•r. Det ni mest gissar kring.

Och bygg d√§rifr√•n.

L√§s artikeln: Datadriven kultur b√∂rjar inte med data. Den b√∂rjar med ett problem.

[https://thomaslarsson.substack.com/p/datadriven-kultur-borjar-inte-med](https://thomaslarsson.substack.com/p/datadriven-kultur-borjar-inte-med)

title: What is Enterprise Debt
ai_summary: Enterprise debt encompasses broader organizational issues beyond technical debt, including process, people, technology, and cultural debt. It can hinder growth and efficiency, leading to decreased productivity and competitiveness. Managing enterprise debt involves assessing and identifying inefficiencies, prioritizing critical issues, implementing agile methodologies, investing in training, modernizing technology, and fostering a culture of continuous improvement to enhance organizational agility and innovation.
body:
[What is Enterprise Debt (it‚Äôs worse than technical debt) and how to manage it?](https://youtu.be/jeLfFCVElgU)
Status: #reference
Tags: #debt
[[100 Zettelkasten/Tech debt is not a burden, it‚Äôs a strategic lever for success|Tech debt is not a burden, it‚Äôs a strategic lever for success]]

## Copy below, not mine

https://www.perplexity.ai/search/what-is-enterprise-debt-it-s-w-J3enxFQMQ2GeT3g.SO0LlA
Enterprise debt is a concept that extends beyond technical debt and encompasses broader organizational issues that can hinder a company‚Äôs growth and efficiency[1]. Unlike technical debt, which primarily focuses on software development challenges, enterprise debt affects the entire organization and its ability to adapt and innovate[1].

## Key Aspects of Enterprise Debt

**Types of Enterprise Debt:**
- Process debt: Inefficient or outdated processes that slow down operations
- People debt: Skill gaps or misaligned talent within the organization
- Technology debt: Outdated or incompatible systems across the enterprise
- Cultural debt: Resistance to change or lack of innovation mindset

**Impact on the Organization:**
Enterprise debt can lead to decreased productivity, increased costs, and reduced competitiveness in the market[1]. It often manifests as a struggle to implement new technologies or adapt to changing business environments.

## Managing Enterprise Debt

**Assessment and Identification:**
- Conduct a comprehensive audit of processes, systems, and skills across the organization
- Identify areas of inefficiency, redundancy, or misalignment with business goals

**Prioritization:**
- Evaluate the impact and urgency of each identified debt
- Create a roadmap for addressing the most critical issues first

**Debt Reduction Strategies:**
- Implement agile methodologies to improve processes and adaptability
- Invest in employee training and development to address skill gaps
- Modernize technology infrastructure and systems
- Foster a culture of continuous improvement and innovation

**Long-term Mitigation:**
- Establish governance structures to prevent the accumulation of new debt
- Regularly review and update processes, technologies, and skills
- Encourage cross-functional collaboration to break down silos

By addressing enterprise debt holistically, organizations can improve their agility, efficiency, and ability to innovate in an ever-changing business landscape[1].

Citations:
[1] https://youtu.be/jeLfFCVElgU

title: The Process Paradox
ai_summary: Finding the right balance between too little and too much process is essential for productivity and organizational effectiveness. Insufficient processes can lead to inconsistent quality and confusion, while excessive processes can stifle creativity and slow decision-making. Organizations must adapt their processes according to specific needs, ensuring flexibility and competitiveness in a changing environment.
body:
![[Pasted image 20240914164946.png]]
Too little process and you can‚Äôt get good work done.
Too much process and you can‚Äôt get any work done.
Most organisations never find the middle

The Process Paradox is a mind exercise that helps you understand how detailed you need to be and follow to produce the optimal level of quality work.
(Disclaimer - The quote in the picture is not mine, but unfortunately, I don‚Äôt know where I have stolen it from; sorry for that.)
In different areas, we require different levels and compliance toward the processes.
For example, in the security-related perspective, it is often a must-have requirement to do it step by step as the process instructs (or instructs, if you want).
In other areas, it might be a placeholder, such as discovery or innovation, where the processes are a mere part of the delivery of what the stakeholders need for further approval.
And just for clarification, when I say processes, I mainly Refer to HOW we are doing things, not WHAT.
So your challenge is to balance Steve Jobs‚Äôs quote, ‚ÄúIt makes no sense to hire smart people and tell them how to do things,‚Äù with Marc ZuckerBorg‚Äôs (double pun intended) ‚Äúmove fast and break things.‚Äù
The process may be the boundaries.
On a side note.
A process that explains HOW we do things can NEVER represent overall planning, budget, or organisation. In my humble opinion, WHAT we do is much better.
You want to change HOW you do things, even daily. That is the only way to have a competitive edge and be truly flexible to the only constant in the world.
Change.

[[When is enough process documentation for you?]]
## Below from:
https://www.perplexity.ai/search/too-little-process-and-you-can-5ooVoKLmRgiGGI5Iie53_Q
Finding the right balance between too little and too much process is indeed a challenge many companies face. This balance is crucial for maintaining productivity, employee satisfaction, and overall organizational effectiveness.

## The Process Paradox

**Too Little Process**When a company lacks sufficient processes, several issues can arise:
1. Inconsistent work quality
2. Difficulty in scaling operations
3. Inefficient communication
4. Lack of accountability
Without proper processes, employees may struggle to understand expectations, leading to confusion and reduced productivity.**Too Much Process**On the other hand, excessive processes can be equally detrimental:
1. Stifled creativity and innovation
2. Decreased employee autonomy
3. Slower decision-making
4. Increased bureaucracy
Overemphasis on process can lead to a culture where following procedures becomes more important than achieving results.

title: Seven Habits of Highly Effective People
ai_summary: The seven habits for effectiveness include being proactive, envisioning desired outcomes, prioritizing important tasks, fostering win-win relationships, practicing empathetic listening, collaborating for synergy, and committing to continuous self-renewal across physical, mental, social, and spiritual areas. These principles aim to enhance personal and professional growth, build meaningful relationships, and achieve goals through a principled approach.
body:
Stephen Covey, success-by-pattern gurus.
His book The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People
1. Be proactive.
2. Begin with the end in mind. (Imagine a good outcome.)
3. Put first things first. (Set priorities.)
4. Think win-win. (Don‚Äôt be greedy.)
5. Seek first to understand then be understood.
6. Synergize. (Use teamwork.)
7. Sharpen the saw. (Keep learning.)
Sure thing! Here‚Äôs a more detailed summary of Stephen Covey‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Seven Habits of Highly Effective People,‚Äù with an expansion on each of the habits:

1. **Be Proactive**
    
    This habit emphasizes taking responsibility for your life. Instead of reacting to external circumstances, you focus on what you can control and influence. It‚Äôs about being proactive in how you choose your responses, leading to more empowered outcomes.
    
2. **Begin with the End in Mind**
    
    Covey encourages you to envision what you want to achieve before you begin any task or journey. This habit is about setting a clear vision of your goals, values, and principles to guide your actions, ensuring that your efforts align with your ultimate purpose.
    
3. **Put First Things First**
    
    Prioritization is key to effectiveness. This habit urges you to focus on what‚Äôs truly important, not just what‚Äôs urgent. By managing your time according to your values and priorities, you ensure that your actions contribute to long-term success rather than just reacting to immediate demands.
    
4. **Think Win-Win**
    
    Effective relationships are built on mutual benefit. This habit focuses on finding solutions that satisfy both parties, fostering a mindset of abundance rather than competition. When you strive for ‚Äúwin-win‚Äù outcomes, you create sustainable partnerships that are beneficial for everyone involved.
    
5. **Seek First to Understand, Then to Be Understood**
    
    Communication is more effective when you first seek to understand others before expressing your own perspective. This habit is about practicing empathetic listening to genuinely grasp others‚Äô needs and concerns, which builds trust and lays a foundation for meaningful dialogue.
    
6. **Synergize**
    
    This habit is all about collaboration. It‚Äôs the idea that combining the strengths of people can lead to outcomes greater than the sum of individual contributions. Synergy leverages diverse perspectives and talents to create innovative solutions that wouldn‚Äôt be possible alone.
    
7. **Sharpen the Saw**
    
    Covey concludes with the importance of self-renewal in four areas: physical, mental, social, and spiritual. By regularly ‚Äúsharpening the saw,‚Äù you maintain your effectiveness and prevent burnout. This habit is about continuous growth and maintaining balance in your life for sustained success.
    

These habits are designed to transform how you approach both personal and professional challenges, focusing on character growth, building meaningful relationships, and achieving goals through a principled approach.

- by Liz Wiseman

Our greatest strengths can also be huge weaknesses when we misapply them. I‚Äôd rebuy this book, just for the table of strengths and their plus and downsides.

- by Trevor Noah

From Township to Television, his incredible story is both hilarious and profound. The Audiobook narration is by Trevor himself, which I highly recommend.

1. üìöBeing Mortal¬†- Medicine and What Matters in the End
- by Atul Gawande

In our quest to delay death, we often make choices that affect the quality of life. Should we weigh quality more heavily in this equation?

1. üìöInvisible Women¬†- Data Bias in a World Designed for Men
- by Caroline Criado P√©rez

Designing for the average man affects everything from seatbelt safety for pregnant women to heart attack medication. This book will make you angry.

1. üìöWinners Take All¬†-¬†The Elite Charade of Changing the World
- by Anand Giridharadas

Uncovers the dangers of Philanthropy and how often it causes more problems than it solves. (He‚Äôs also the husband of Priya Parker)

1. üìöInferior¬†-¬†How Science Got Women Wrong‚Äîand the New Research That‚Äôs Rewriting the Story
- by Angela Saini

The research this book shares challenge many things we teach kids. Specifically women‚Äôs contributions to the development of the world and challenges men‚Äôs historical role in i

title: Packaged Business Capabilities to determine Microservices
ai_summary: Composable Business Capabilities (CBCs) are modular units of business functionality that enhance agility, scalability, and innovation in enterprise architectures. They enable the creation of microservices by identifying discrete business functions, defining APIs for integration, and ensuring independent deployability. APIs facilitate communication between CBCs, allowing organizations to adapt quickly to changing needs.
body:
![[Pasted image 20240823220119.png]]

Composable Business Capabilities (CBCs) are a key concept in building flexible and modular enterprise architectures. Here‚Äôs more information and background on this approach:

## Definition and Concept

Composable Business Capabilities (CBCs) are modular, self-contained units of business functionality that can be assembled, disassembled, and reassembled to create new business processes or applications[1]. They are the building blocks of a composable enterprise architecture, allowing organizations to quickly adapt to changing business needs and market conditions.

## Key Characteristics

CBCs have several important characteristics:

1. **Modularity**: Each CBC is a discrete unit of business functionality that can operate independently[1].
2. **Interoperability**: CBCs are designed to work together seamlessly, allowing for easy integration and recombination[4].
3. **API-driven**: CBCs typically expose their functionality through well-defined APIs, enabling easy communication and integration with other components[2].
4. **Business-oriented**: CBCs are aligned with specific business outcomes or use cases, making them meaningful to business users as well as technical teams[3].

## Benefits of Using CBCs

Implementing Composable Business Capabilities offers several advantages:

1. **Increased Agility**: Organizations can quickly assemble new business processes or applications by combining existing CBCs[1].
2. **Improved Scalability**: Individual CBCs can be scaled up or down as needed, without affecting the entire system[3].
3. **Enhanced Innovation**: The modular nature of CBCs allows for rapid prototyping and experimentation with new business models or services[2].
4. **Better Resilience**: Isolating functionality in CBCs minimizes the risk of system-wide failures[3].

## Creating Microservices with CBCs

When using CBCs to create microservices:

1. **Identify Business Functions**: Break down complex business processes into smaller, discrete functions that can be encapsulated as CBCs[3].
2. **Define APIs**: Create clear, well-documented APIs for each CBC to facilitate integration and communication[2].
3. **Ensure Independence**: Design each CBC to be independently deployable and scalable[1].
4. **Consider Data Management**: Determine how data will be shared and managed between CBCs, often using event-driven architectures[2].

## Role of APIs in CBCs

APIs play a crucial role in Composable Business Capabilities:
![[Pasted image 20241013002602.png]]
1. **Technical Communication**: APIs provide the technical means for CBCs to interact with each other and with external systems[2].

1. **Interaction Agreements**: APIs define the contract for how different components should communicate, including data formats and protocols[2].
2. **Flexibility**: APIs allow for ad-hoc communication between CBCs, enabling dynamic composition of business processes[4].

By leveraging Composable Business Capabilities and well-designed APIs, organizations can create flexible, modular architectures that enable rapid adaptation to changing business needs and foster innovation.

Citations:
[1] https://www.bluestonepim.com/blog/packaged-business-capabilities
[2] https://mia-platform.eu/blog/packaged-business-capabilities-pbc/
[3] https://sageitinc.com/blog/packaged-business-capabilities-composable-businesses
[4] https://www.shopify.com/enterprise/blog/composable-business
[5] https://quixy.com/blog/composable-business-101-everything-you-need-to-know/
[6] https://www.tietoevry.com/en/blog/2023/09/composable-architecture-exploring-business-design-and-architecture-of-the-future/
[7] https://www.trisotech.com/composability-and-packaged-business-capabilities/
[8] https://www.gartner.com/smarterwithgartner/gartner-keynote-the-future-of-business-is-composable

Using BC to create a composable Business Capability that can be used for creating a ‚Äúmicroservice‚Äù of a function.
API:s are:
API:s for technical communication
Agreements for how to interact
Ad hoc - communication

Modular Business Capabilities
Interoperable Business Capabilities

title: Alla s√§ger samarbete. Men vi organiserar oss som om vi riktigt ogillar varandra.
ai_keywords: Collaborative Innovation, Customer-Centric Approach, Strategic Adaptation
ai_summary: Organisationer fastnar i silos trots str√§van efter samarbete, ofta p√• grund av okunskap om hur man kan g√∂ra annorlunda. F√∂r att bryta dessa silos kr√§vs en gemensam f√∂rst√•else av verksamhetens struktur och beroenden, vilket kan uppn√•s genom att definiera processer, funktioner och produkter. Genom att skapa en karta √∂ver dessa relationer kan organisationer b√∂rja t√§nka systematiskt och bygga en mer sammanh√§ngande verksamhet.
body:
**Alla s√§ger samarbete. Men vi organiserar oss som om vi riktigt ogillar varandra.**

PowerPoints om tv√§rfunktionalitet. Workshops om v√§rdestr√∂mmar. Strategier om samverkan.

√Ñnd√• bygger vi silos.

Igen och igen.

Inte av illvilja, utan av okunskap. Vi vet helt enkelt inte hur vi ska g√∂ra n√•got annat.

Den h√§r texten handlar om varf√∂r det h√§nder, vad som faktiskt kr√§vs f√∂r att g√∂ra annorlunda och hur du b√∂rjar bygga ett operativsystem som h√•ller ihop hela din verksamhet.

# **Alla s√§ger samarbete. Men vi organiserar oss som om vi riktigt ogillar varandra.**

Trots alla strategier, initiativ och workshops ser jag samma m√∂nster g√•ng p√• g√•ng:

**Organisationer fastnar i silos.**

Inte f√∂r att du vill det.

Utan f√∂r att f√• vet hur man g√∂r n√•got annat.

Ledningsgrupper, CIO:er och CTO:er pratar om samarbete, gemensamma m√•l och plattare strukturer.

Men n√§r det v√§l √§r dags att bygga organisation, processer och information, d√• faller vi tillbaka i gamla m√∂nster:

- Varje funktion optimerar enbart sin egna del.
- Vi √§r inte medveten om vad n√§sta steg i kedjan √§r och vad de beh√∂ver av dig f√∂r att kunna utf√∂ra sitt jobb.
- Information och data sprids ut i sm√• √∂ar, sv√•ra att koppla ihop.
- Vi t√§nker i b√§sta fall i processer, inte ett n√§tverk av systematik.
- System och processer speglar intern avdelningsstruktur ist√§llet f√∂r kundens resa.

Vi bygger vackra PowerPoints om f√∂r√§ndring.

Men i vardagen styr gamla vanor, gamla maktbalanser och gamla tankes√§tt.

Du har varit d√§r.

## Vad kunde vara annorlunda?

Okej, ibland beh√∂vs ett st√∂rre omtag, inte minst inom ledningsgruppen.

Men en start √§r att f√• ledningsgruppen att tillsammans artikulera ‚Äúdet h√§r fungerar inte‚Äù s√• har vi en bra start.

Acceptans.

Tror att kultur och systematik, ordning och reda, h√∂r samman. Om vi har en kultur d√§r det inte finns ett erk√§nnande att hela verksamheten √§r en organism (eller systematiskt t√§nkt beh√∂vs) s√• uppst√•r oundvikligen silos.

(Video om n√§r han pratar om systematik)

Ett f√∂rsta steg √§r att du f√∂rst√•r vilka drivkrafter som skapar silos?

M√•nga p√•st√•r att det √§r f√∂r att skydda sin makt och position. Men det √§r inte min bild. Jag menar att de flesta har tagit sig till en position genom ett slit i att f√∂rs√∂ka f√∂rst√• sin del av organisation och har all intention att g√∂ra den b√§ttre. I det h√§r arbetet skapar man sig oundvikligen sin bild hur organisationen som stort ska drivas fram√•t, utan att den f√∂r delen √§r synkad med andra. Anledningen att det inte √§r synkad √§r det finns inte ett s√§tt att g√∂ra det. Enligt mig √§r h√§r verksamhetsarkitektur kommer in.

Vad √§r d√• verksamhetsarkitektur? En enkel definition skulle kunna vara:

> Det √§r en beskrivning av en verksamhets struktur i termer av dess m√•l, f√∂rm√•gor, processer, information, organisation och resurser ‚Äì med syfte att skapa en gemensam f√∂rst√•else f√∂r hur verksamheten fungerar och kan utvecklas.
> 

Men ordet verksamhetsarkitektur √§r abstrakt och jag gillar inte abstrakt. S√• f√∂rs√∂k komma √∂verens om ett ord ni anv√§nder f√∂r att beskriva er verksamhet. N√•gra f√∂rslag:

Vad vi g√∂r, v√•rt s√§tt att jobba, hur vi h√§nger ihop, v√•rt operativsystem, v√•r spelplan, s√• h√§r g√∂r vi saker, v√•r inre karta, det som h√•ller ihop oss, v√•rt maskineri eller v√•r systematik. Kommer skriva **v√•r systematik** fram√•t.

## Vad vi g√∂r

En av mina favoriter att jobba med f√∂r att f√∂rklara en verksamhet √§r vad vi g√∂r. Ett exempel att beskriva verksamheten √§r d√• att beskriva vad:et.

1. Hantera kundf√∂rfr√•gningar.
2. Skapa och hantera offert.
3. Boka arbetet.
4. Utf√∂ra arbetet.
5. Fakturera arbetet.

Dessa beskrivningar √§r fritt vad avdelningar heter utan utg√•r g√§rna fr√•n vad kunden vill g√∂ra och f√• utr√§ttat. Ibland kallas detta f√∂r verksamhetsf√∂rm√•gor eller funktioner. Men det √§r en religion i sig s√• vi l√§mnar det.

N√§sta steg √§r att f√∂rs√∂ka f√∂rst√• vilka beroende som finns mellan varandra.

‚ÄúSkapa och hantera offert‚Äù l√§mnar en godk√§nd offert inklusive vad som ska utf√∂ras till ‚ÄúUtf√∂ra arbetet‚Äù. D√• kan man b√∂rja fundera p√• vilken √∂verenskommelse finns d√§remellan? Vad m√•ste offerten inneh√•lla? Produkt, kontaktpersonens telefonnummer, adress dit vi beh√∂ver √•ka, vad jag ska ha med mig kan vara n√•gra saker som vi har som krav f√∂r att kunna utf√∂ra v√•rt arbete.

Jag gillar definitionen ‚Äúvad jag beh√∂ver f√∂r att kunna utf√∂ra mitt arbete‚Äù som krav p√• f√∂reg√•ende steg. Det √§r inte elakt att st√§lla krav p√• varandra. Tv√§rtom. De flesta uppskattar det och vi skapar ocks√• f√∂rst√•else.

Men som i exemplet ovan s√• slutar det inte h√§r. Fler har behov av information i offerten, de som ska fakturera. Vilken √§r faktureringsadressen och organisationsnumret.

Som ni m√§rker √§r det detaljer som kr√§vs f√∂r att p√• riktigt f√∂rst√•. L√§mnar vi detaljerna s√• blir det fort abstrakt och sv√•rt f√∂r verksamheten att h√§nga med i resonemanget.

Steg f√∂r steg l√§gger du ett pussel och ritar en karta d√§r mycket beroenden finns och ungef√§r d√§r brukar insikten komma att vi jobbar egentligen inte alls i silos. I verkligheten √§r vi ett n√§tverk. Vi har dock valt att organisera oss i silos.

## Silos eller h√§ngr√§nnor?

Det √§r dock lite humor i m√•ngas f√∂rs√∂k att f√∂rs√∂ka komma √•t silosproblemet genom att skapa nya silos. De kanske anv√§nder begrepp som ‚Äúvi ska organiseras oss med v√§rdestr√∂mmar ist√§llet‚Äù. Det enda du lyckas med √§r d√• att skapa samma problem. Om silos √§r det negativa uttrycket s√• √§r h√§ngr√§nnor samma sak f√∂r att organisera med fl√∂den.

Oundvikligen har du tv√• perspektiv som beh√∂ver samordning eller synkning.

‚Üí Du har ett fl√∂de - t√§nk produkt.

‚Üí Du har en funktion - t√§nk vad som internt beh√∂ver g√∂ras.

I boken Team Topology av Matthew Skelton and Manuel Pais beskriver de tre s√§tt huvudsakliga s√§tt att se samarbeten p√•.

- **Samarbete:** arbeta tillsammans under en best√§md tid f√∂r att uppt√§cka nya saker (API:er, arbetss√§tt, tekniker etc.)
- **X-som-tj√§nst:** ett team tillhandah√•ller och ett annat team anv√§nder n√•got ‚Äùsom en tj√§nst‚Äù
- **Facilitering:** ett team st√∂ttar och v√§gleder ett annat team

![CleanShot 2025-05-15 at 08.15.59 2@2x.png](Alla%20s%C3%A4ger%20samarbete%20Men%20vi%20organiserar%20oss%20som%20om/CleanShot_2025-05-15_at_08.15.59_22x.png)

B√•da perspektiven beh√∂vs. Ibland g√•r jag s√• l√•ngt att prata om vad som optimeras.

- Processer: Beskriver fl√∂desoptimeringar - hur vi g√∂r.
- Funktioner: Beskriver resursoptimering - vad vi g√∂r.

Och om du √§r lite observant s√• ser du att det saknas minst ett perspektiv üôÇ

- Produkt: Beskriver int√§ktsoptimering - varf√∂r vi g√∂r saker f√∂r vem.

Med dessa som bas och du hittar vilka relationer som finns mellan teamen, se ovan, s√• b√∂rjar du skapa en karta √∂ver ett system, en organism som har ordentligt med beroenden.

F√∂r att bryta silos s√• beh√∂vs den kartan s√• att vi kan tillsammans s√§ga ‚Äúja det d√§r √§r v√•r verksamhet‚Äù. Vi kan ocks√• vara √∂verens om ‚Äúvad jag beh√∂ver‚Äù f√∂r att kunna utf√∂ra mitt arbete, det vill s√§ga mitt krav p√• f√∂reg√•ende del i kedjan samt vara medveten om vad n√§sta beh√∂ver.

N√§r jag √§r i service f√∂r n√•gon annan, d√• finns ett leveransansvar till andra f√∂r att de ska kunna g√∂ra sitt jobb. Precis som v√•ra relation till kunderna.

Dr. Russell Ackoff en av grundarna till systemt√§nkande i v√§rlden.

[https://youtu.be/FhcfjE7tJDY?si=LKT94OwZ8-_UH4DW](https://youtu.be/FhcfjE7tJDY?si=LKT94OwZ8-_UH4DW)

Han beskriver att man l√∂ser problem genom att jobba en av fyra principer, och han menar att den fj√§rde √§r viktigt att fundera √∂ver.

1. **Absolution**: Att ignorera eller anta att problemet l√∂ser sig sj√§lvt.
2. **Resolve**: Att √•tg√§rda problemets grundorsak och till√§mpa samma procedur.
3. **Solve**: Att hitta en verklig l√∂sning som kr√§ver forskning och unders√∂kning.
4. **Dissolve**: Att omdesigna systemet eller dess milj√∂ f√∂r att hantera problemet.

## **S√• hur g√∂r man?**

G√∂r x och y s√• uppn√•r du z.

Tyv√§rr. Nej. S√• enkelt √§r det inte. Jag skulle fundera p√• om vi har bra beskrivningar p√• f√∂ljande tre saker.

- Produkt: Beskriver int√§ktsoptimering - varf√∂r vi g√∂r saker f√∂r vem.
- Processer: Beskriver fl√∂desoptimeringar - hur vi g√∂r.
- Funktioner: Beskriver resursoptimering - vad vi g√∂r.

N√§sta steg √§r att fundera hur dessa relaterar till varandra?

D√• b√∂rjar en karta ta form. 

Med olika intressenter b√∂rja d√• diskutera den kartan i olika perspektiv.

- Skav och problem
- V√•r plannering
- Resurstills√§ttning och kompetens
- V√•ra arbetss√§tt

B√∂rja sm√•tt. Utveckla stegvis. Acceptera att den √§r scrappy i b√∂rjan.

Skapa dig en en karta, bild som kan s√• sm√•ningom vara startpunkten f√∂r de flesta diskussioner. D√• skapar du gemensam f√∂rst√•else p√• riktigt.

Och en startpunkt att t√§nka systematiskt har b√∂rjat.

Stort lycka till!

---

Det h√§r √§r vad jag jobbar med p√• dagarna som konsult.

Jag vill visa att det finns **anv√§ndbara m√∂nster.** Inte stora f√∂r√§ndringsprogram som d√∂r efter tv√• √•r. Utan sm√•, begripliga s√§tt att bygga systematiskt b√§ttre verksamhet, varje dag.

M√∂nster f√∂r:

- Att brygga √∂ver silos.

title: What is the Difference between Mission Vision and Values-
ai_summary: Purpose defines why a company exists, vision outlines its future direction, mission describes what it does to achieve that vision, and values establish how it conducts business. A practical exercise can help clarify these concepts by substituting key terms.
body:
## Metadata

- Status: #idea
- URL: [https://getmatter.com/email/16743031/?token=16743031%3ADI8mfQT1inLWsSB4V6nMeVitQbU](https://getmatter.com/email/16743031/?token=16743031%3ADI8mfQT1inLWsSB4V6nMeVitQbU)
- Publisher: The Extraordinary Strategist from Brian Sooy
- Published Date: 2022-12-23
- Tags: #Purpose, #Values, #strategy, #vision

## Highlights

- A practical exercise is substituting the words Why, What, Where, and How for Purpose, Mission, Vision, and Values.
- The¬†**company purpose**¬†is¬†*why*¬†an organization exists beyond generating a profit. Purpose helps companies stay aligned around why it matters.
- The¬†**company vision**¬†is¬†*where*¬†you or your organization are headed and what the future looks like. Vision keeps a company focused.
- The¬†**company mission**¬†is¬†*what*¬†an organization does to achieve its vision. The mission is how a company puts its purpose and vision into action.
- **Company values**¬†define¬†*how*¬†your company does business. Company values are guiding principles for how people show up, treat each other, and how a company succeeds.

title: Future Studies- Forecasts Scenarios Roadmaps and Pathways
ai_summary: Future Studies emphasizes the importance of continuous exploration and multiple emergent pathways in strategy formulation, acknowledging high agency and uncertainty in forecasting and scenario planning.
body:
![[Pasted image 20240808144100.png]]
# 4. Pathways

```
_High agency, high uncertainty._
Forecasts, scenarios, and roadmaps are tremendously useful, but neither is well suited for the type of trial-and-error experimentation that you go through when formulating strategy. The world is a crazy place, and while you have agency to do what needs to be done, you can never be quite sure how things will turn out. Instead, Future Studies suggests that you engage in a process of continuous exploration involving multiple emergent pathways.
```

Even more uncertain than Scenarios. In the state of Exploration eventually set the state with Scenarios.
Status: #idea
Tags: #Roadmaps
[[Roadmaps]]
[[Scen]]

title: How many OKRs is enough
ai_summary: Focusing on fewer goals increases the likelihood of achieving them; for teams of around 30, one objective with up to three key results is optimal to manage ambitions effectively.
body:
## Highlights
* We‚Äôre all victims of our own ambitions, especially as leaders. Applying OKRs gives us the opportunity to focus our ambitions on the work that requires the majority of our attention right now.
* If you have 30 employees in all likelihood one objective and up to three key results is the most they can handle.
* The fewer your goals your teams are chasing, the more likely they are to reach them.
## Reference
[https://getmatter.com/email/6679268/?token=6679268%3ARQGOyqfe-ihUsIOxZvzKpa3nbMs](https://getmatter.com/email/6679268/?token=6679268%3ARQGOyqfe-ihUsIOxZvzKpa3nbMs)

title: Set the progress
ai_summary: To set a team's purpose, consider the vision (why), aspiration (where to go), assessment (readiness), architecture (what is needed), action (managing the journey), and advancement (continuing progress). The concepts are derived from "Beyond Performance" by Scott Keller and Colin Price.
author: [Scott Keller and Colin Price](https://www.amazon.comundefined/)
body:
How can we set the purpose for a team? What is important?

Vision: Why do we want this?
(From book)
Aspire: Where do we want to go?
Assess: How ready are we to go there?
Architect: What do we need to do to get there?
Act: How do we manage the journey?
Advance: How do we keep moving forward?

Beyond Performance
Author: [Scott Keller and Colin Price](https://www.amazon.comundefined/)

title: The North Star Playbook
ai_summary: North Star Playbook syftar till att skapa en gemensam produktmetrik genom en North Star Metric (NSM) som reflekterar kundv√§rde och l√•ngsiktig tillv√§xt. Den inkluderar input-metrikar som teamen kan p√•verka, och ger v√§gledning f√∂r att formulera ett tydligt North Star-statement, validera det, och implementera det operativt. Boken adresserar vanliga f√§llor som f√•f√§nga metrikar och vikten av att integrera ramverket i teamets ritualer f√∂r att uppn√• verklig effekt.
body:
### North Star Playbook ‚Äî sammanfattning p√• svenska

- Syfte
    - Skapa en gemensam produktmetrik och ett gemensamt spr√•k som knyter ihop kundv√§rde, produktbeteenden och aff√§rsresultat f√∂r fokus, alignment och ansvarstagande.
- K√§rnan: North Star Framework
    - Identifiera en enda North Star Metric (NSM) som f√•ngar levererat kundv√§rde och korrelerar med h√•llbar tillv√§xt.
    - Komplettera med ett litet set input‚Äëmetrikar (ledande indikatorer/aktiviteter) som teamen direkt kan p√•verka.
- Vad k√§nnetecknar en bra NSM?
    - Speglar kundv√§rde, inte f√•f√§nga aktivitetstal
    - Kopplad till l√•ngsiktiga aff√§rsutfall
    - Tillr√§ckligt ledande f√∂r dagliga beslut
    - M√§tbar, l√§tt att f√∂rst√• och anv√§nd i era ritualer
- Vanliga NSM‚Äëm√∂nster (exempel ‚Äì anpassa till produkten)
    - Media/konsument: Tid √§gnad √•t kvalitetsinneh√•ll per aktiv anv√§ndare
    - Marknadsplatser: Lyckade matchningar per kohort
    - SaaS‚Äësamarbete: Veckovis aktiva samarbetande team
    - E‚Äëhandel: Andel √•terkommande k√∂p eller ordrar med lyckad leverans
    - B2B‚Äëarbetsfl√∂de: Uppgifter framg√•ngsrikt slutf√∂rda per konto
- Checklista och ‚Äústatement‚Äù‚Äë√∂vning
    - Formulera ett North Star‚Äëstatement som kopplar m√•lgrupp, v√§rde de f√•r och hur det m√§ts.
    - Validera med en checklista: kundv√§rde‚Äëfokus, koppling till tillv√§xt, styrbarhet via inputs, tydlighet och t√§ckning √∂ver team.
- F√∂rtydliga med input‚Äëmetrikar
    - 3‚Äì5 inputs som driver NSM, t.ex. f√∂rv√§rvskvalitet, aktivering/f√∂rsta‚Äëv√§rde, retention/vane‚Äëdjup, samarbetsfrekvens, utbudsh√§lsa, leveranss√§kerhet.
    - S√§kerst√§ll tydligt √§garskap och p√•verkansspakar f√∂r varje input.
- Fels√∂kning och vanliga f√§llor
    - F√•f√§nga metrikar: DAU/MAU utan v√§rdesignal
    - Int√§ktsm√•l som NSM (f√∂r tr√∂ga/efterliggande)
    - F√∂r m√•nga inputs som sp√§der ut fokus
    - M√§ta det som √§r l√§tt ist√§llet f√∂r det som betyder n√•got
    - Inputs som teamet i praktiken inte kan p√•verka
- S√• f√•r ni det att f√§sta
    - Bygg in i planering, uppf√∂ljningar och dashboards
    - Rikta teamm√•l och experiment mot inputs
    - Revidera n√§r produkt eller strategi √§ndras
    - L√§r upp intressenter i det gemensamma spr√•ket
- Fr√•n teori till praktik
    - Nul√§gesm√§t NSM och inputs, s√§tt m√•l
    - Mappa spakar till inputs, k√∂r experiment, utv√§rdera p√•verkan p√• NSM
    - Anv√§nd analys f√∂r att sp√•ra input ‚Üí NSM och se avtagande avkastning
    - Justera portf√∂ljsatsningar baserat p√• evidens
- N√§r ska ni byta North Star?
    - Stora strategiska skiften
    - F√∂r√§ndrad aff√§rsmodell
    - N√§r nuvarande NSM inte l√§ngre representerar levererat kundv√§rde

### Kort summering (2 stycken)

North Star Playbook handlar om att etablera ett gemensamt nav f√∂r produktstyrning genom en North Star Metric (NSM) som f√•ngar levererat kundv√§rde och korrelerar med h√•llbar tillv√§xt. Runt denna byggs ett litet antal input‚Äëmetrikar som teamen direkt kan p√•verka, s√• att dagliga beslut och experiment kan kopplas till ett tydligt, l√•ngsiktigt m√•l. Playbooken visar hur man formulerar ett tydligt North Star‚Äëstatement, validerar det mot en checklista, och g√∂r det operativt genom √§garskap, m√§tning och l√§rloopar.

Boken adresserar √§ven vanliga f√§llor som f√•f√§nga metrikar, f√∂r m√•nga inputs och m√•l som ligger f√∂r l√•ngt fr√•n kundv√§rde. Den betonar att ramverket m√•ste in i ritualer, dashboardar och portf√∂ljbeslut f√∂r att skapa verklig effekt, samt hur och n√§r man b√∂r byta North Star n√§r produktstrategi eller aff√§rsmodell f√∂r√§ndras.

### Metoder i playbooken (5‚Äì10)

- North Star‚Äëstatement‚Äë√∂vningen f√∂r att koppla m√•lgrupp, v√§rde och m√§tning
- North Star‚Äëchecklistan f√∂r att validera kundv√§rde, tillv√§xtkoppling och styrbarhet
- Input‚Äëmetrik‚Äëkartl√§ggning och √§garskap per input
- Metric tree/driver tree f√∂r att visualisera input ‚Üí NSM‚Äësamband
- Experiment‚Äë och l√§rloopar kopplade till inputs och hypoteser
- Dashboarding och ritualer (planering, veckorevyer) f√∂r att g√∂ra NSM operativ
- Troubleshooting‚Äëm√∂nster f√∂r att undvika vanliga f√§llor och anti‚Äëm√∂nster
- Byte av North Star: kriterier och process n√§r strategin skiftar
- Portf√∂ljstyrning med evidens: justera satsningar utifr√•n input ‚Üí NSM‚Äëeffekt

body:
Skiss

T√§nka det helt motsatta f√∂r b√§ttre beslut

N√§r vi f√∂rs√∂ker f√∂rst√• n√•got som hj√§lper det att st√§lla ett antal fr√•gor f√∂r att hitta nya perspektiv p√• utmaningen vi har framf√∂r oss. N√•gra av mina favoriter √§r:

- B√∂rja med slutet (m√•let).
- Om det var enkelt? Hur g√∂r vi d√•?
- 5 varf√∂r?
- Be om andras insikter och be dem argumentera varf√∂r.
- Anv√§nd varf√∂r, vad, hur, vem, vart, var, n√§r.

Men den sista som kommit upp p√• min radar √§r ‚ÄúInversion Process‚Äù. T√§nka det helt motsatta.

Om m√•let √§r att skapa en b√§ttre skola. Vad ska vi g√∂ra f√∂r att g√∂ra skolan katastrofalt mycket s√§mre? Genom att st√§lla den andra fr√•gan s√• ska vi undvika det samt g√• fram och tillbaka mellan vad vi ska g√∂ra och vad vi inte ska g√∂ra.

Mycket som handlar om strategier √§r just m√∂jligheten att besvara fr√•gan. Det d√§r ska vi inte g√∂ra. Om vi dessutom s√§tter det i ett kontext att det saboterar v√•rt egentliga m√•l, ja d√• har vi en bra lista p√• saker att undvika.

Refererar till denna video av Charles T. Munger.

### **T√§nk tv√§rtom f√∂r att t√§nka klart**

N√§r vi f√∂rs√∂ker f√∂rst√• n√•got komplicerat √§r det ofta b√§ttre att st√§lla b√§ttre fr√•gor √§n att jaga fler svar. N√•gra av mina favoriter:

- B√∂rja med slutet. Vad √§r m√•let?
- Om det var enkelt. Hur hade vi gjort d√•?
- Fem varf√∂r. Gr√§v tills det g√∂r ont (rotorsak).
- Be andra t√§nka h√∂gt och motivera varf√∂r.
- Anv√§nd fr√•gorna: varf√∂r, vad, hur, vem, var, n√§r.

Men min nya favorit kommer fr√•n Charles T. Munger:

> Inversion.
> 

Om m√•let √§r att skapa en b√§ttre skola. Vad g√∂r vi f√∂r att skapa en riktigt d√•lig?

Genom att formulera de destruktiva aktiviteterna tydligt, kan vi f√∂rhoppningsvis undvika dem.

Vi kan g√• fram och tillbaka mellan vad vi **ska** g√∂ra och vad vi **inte** ska g√∂ra.

Bra strategier handlar ofta inte om att v√§lja r√§tt, utan om att veta vad man ska undvika.

N√§r n√•got aktivt saboterar m√•let, d√• h√∂r det hemma p√• ‚Äúinte-listan‚Äù. Och den listan √§r ofta viktigare √§n den andra.

title: Think Slow
ai_summary: Meetings often suffer when one voice dominates, stifling mutual understanding and thoughtful contributions. Leaders should create space for quieter voices by pausing and reflecting on whether they are allowing others to contribute. Listening fosters real progress and encourages diverse input.
body:
Ever been in a meeting where one voice takes over?(The one with endless opinions and random ideas, consuming all the oxygen in the room.)

It‚Äôs frustrating for the quiet thinkers and the entire team.

When this happens, something crucial gets lost:

‚Üí Mutual understanding‚Üí Space for thoughtful contributions‚Üí The chance to actually make progress

The Dalai Lama nailed it:

"When you talk, you are only repeating what you already know.
But if you listen, you may learn something new."

So here‚Äôs the challenge for leaders and teams: How do you make room for every voice, especially the quieter, more reflective ones?

üí° Try this: Pause.

Before your next meeting, ask yourself:
"Am I creating space for others to contribute, or am I talking just to be heard?"

Real progress happens when we listen.

What‚Äôs one way you encourage more voices to be heard in meetings?

title: Let us talk about communication when improving organisations
ai_summary: To improve organizational communication, we propose using a simplified Business Map model focusing on "Why, What, How, and Who." Plans include creating a Miro Template for collaboration, hosting a workshop, and forming a community to enhance understanding and reduce misinterpretation in communication.
body:
- [ ] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)
-
How simply can we explain an organisation? Well, Albert Einstein said that perfectly.

> Everything should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler
> 

![[Presentations.png]]

To create a shared understanding of an organisation, we often try to invoke new words that might help. Often, that fails. Simon Senik wrote a book that changed a lot in the business Area. *Start with why.* He called it the golden circle in order: Why, What, How. Without more details, that was too simple.

In many attempts by the Enterprise Community, there have been a lot of attempts to create frameworks. Some work better than others. Everyone eventually fails.

What if that is ok? To fail?

What if we create a language that is 80% correct, doesn‚Äôt fit everything, and doesn‚Äôt take care of all corner edge(s)? What if we use words that are already in use and try to humanise communication?

We will be using an easy-to-understand Business Map as the Anchor Model.

That is our mission.

It starts with four words. Why, What, How and Who.

It might be to oversimplify, but we will try anyway :-)

Remember that what you understand, what you communicate and what the receiver eventually understands is something else.

## Next steps

1. We will start 2024 by creating the easiest-to-use Miro Template for full collaboration.
2. Half day of Workshop with this Template, Map-Day.
3. We are starting a Community in February that we want you to be a part of.
4. Evolve to our mission to create an easy-to-understand communication.

Cecilia and Thomas have experience from over 100+ organisations that we have helped in courses and consultants. One of the main problems comes down to the misinterpretation of the communication of words.

Do you want to be a part of the solution for better communication? Just message me and tell me how you want to be involved.

title: Your next Business Model
ai_summary: Embrace new business models by recognizing warning signs, experimenting early, focusing on customer needs, diversifying revenue streams, accepting failure, and preparing for the future to foster innovation and growth.
body:
Is It Time for Your Next Business Model? Instead of squeezing the last drops from a dying business, it might be time to embrace a new model. As Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella said: ‚ÄúBring me new business models!‚Äù
1. Recognize the warning signs
‚Äì Shrinking profits or fading customer interest? Time for a change.
2. Experiment early
‚Äì Don‚Äôt wait. Test and validate new ideas before it‚Äôs too late.
4. Focus on customer needs
‚Äì What do they need today? What will they need tomorrow?
5. Diversify revenue streams
‚Äì Expand your options, reduce risk, and boost income.
6. Embrace failure
‚Äì Fail fast, learn, and adjust. Every failure is a step toward success.
7. Look to the future
‚Äì Don‚Äôt get stuck in the past. Build a model that prepares for what‚Äôs next.

The big question: Have you created an environment where new business ideas can be tested and flourish, not only be brought to the table?

Your next Business Model?
Instead of trying to squeeze the last bits and pieces out of what is left in a dying business, it might be time for a change. A change in an earlier successful Business Model.

> ‚ÄúBring me new business models!‚Äù, said Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella.
> 

J.D. Meier on LinkedIn: "[Bring me new business models!", said Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella.](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/jdmeier_bring-me-new-business-models-said-microsoft-activity-7199081510681890816-BaIp/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios)

title: One Definition at the time
ai_summary: To enhance organizational communication, it is crucial to establish clear definitions, starting with the term "customer." By documenting and publishing key definitions, and regularly reviewing them, misunderstandings can be minimized. Consistent language is essential for effective communication, especially in compliance contexts like GDPR.
body:
![[Pasted image 20241003164758.png]]
[[Definition]]
[[Naming and definitions]]
To improve your chances to be understood, start by speaking the same language. Today‚Äôs challenge: One definition ‚Äúcustomer‚Äù.
Suppose you could do one thing to improve your organisation‚Äôs communication ability today. What would that be? I argue that you start with your definitions.
For example, ‚ÄúWhat is a customer?‚Äù ask from a different perspective, document it, publish it, and ensure that it is used.
The next step is to create and publish the most critical definitions on our intranet. We must review and update these definitions systematically and frequently to ensure they remain accurate and relevant.
In compliance, you could use this definition as information (object, entity) and set rules for it, such as GDPR. In this case, the definition is even more critical.
Why is this important for you? When you talk to someone about ‚Äúcustomer,‚Äù the person on the other side may think you are talking about a customer type, consumer, business, partner, supplier, or product.¬†
If we don‚Äôt speak the same language, what is the purpose of talking in the first place?

what is the purpose of talking in the first place?

title: Preach the false to know the truth Cunninghams Law
ai_summary: Cunningham‚Äôs Law suggests that the best way to obtain the correct answer online is to post an incorrect statement, prompting others to provide the right information. For example, claiming "Agile is Dead" can lead to valuable insights and discussions.
body:
**Cunningham‚Äôs Law**¬†states ‚Äúthe best way to get the right answer on the internet is not to ask a question; it‚Äôs to post the wrong answer.‚Äù
So if you have a statement that, for e.g.¬†Agile is still going strong, you should say, ‚ÄúAgile is Dead‚Äù. There will be a lot of information that you haven‚Äôt researched yourself.

title: Strategy made simple
ai_summary: Understanding strategy can be challenging due to its broad application. The document emphasizes the importance of distinguishing between various views of strategy, including structural and workflow perspectives. It highlights the Strategy Cycle, which includes formulation and execution processes, and discusses the need for clarity in strategy components and their interdependencies. Additionally, it mentions an upcoming course on explaining strategy and provides various links for further exploration of strategy concepts.
body:
[https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mionescu_what-is-the-essence-of-strategy-the-success-activity-7331957456027148288-aNgA/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios&rcm=ACoAAABYo3YBpNFn3EjbVJxuiB6CdYLSNw26-uA](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mionescu_what-is-the-essence-of-strategy-the-success-activity-7331957456027148288-aNgA/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios&rcm=ACoAAABYo3YBpNFn3EjbVJxuiB6CdYLSNw26-uA)

Status #idea
Tags: [[Strategy]] #Porter
Michael Porter.
Why is is so difficault to understand the word Strategy?
Because we use it to everything we don‚Äôt really understand, or if we would like to emphazise something important, urgent.
Prioritized Plan - Streategy Plan

## Reference

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/andrewconstable-mba_heres-what-michael-porter-emphasizes-about-ugcPost-7258745935168442368-662D/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios

[](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mionescu_strategy-view-structural-workflow-sometimes-activity-7353441776688332801-SNCN?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_ios&rcm=ACoAAABYo3YBpNFn3EjbVJxuiB6CdYLSNw26-uA)

- STRATEGY VIEW: STRUCTURAL & WORKFLOW | Mihai Ionescu
    
    STRATEGY VIEW: STRUCTURAL & WORKFLOW Sometimes, we may get distracted by various views types related to Strategy's definition. Yes, there are more than one way to view the Strategy. THE WORKFLOW VIEW Some of you may have watched the evolution of the Strategy Clockwork, which is a typical decision workflow view of the Strategy. It illustrates the main processes of the Strategy Cycle (Formulation & Execution), as well as the decision stages that we go through along these processes. Strategy Model's components (as well as Strategic Plan's components) are generated in some of these stages. But we also have procedural-only stage, like the Strategy Feasibility Gateway, or the Strategy Review, which don't produce any model components. THE STRUCTURAL VIEW You might have seen a series of posts (links below) that illustrate the Strategy Model components, aggregated into constructs (Strategy Core, Business Model, Strategy Execution System) that exhibit the interdependencies between Strategy's components, as well as between the constructs themselves. Those illustrations are presenting a structural view of the Strategy. Sometimes the difference between different views may get a little blurry. For instance, Strategy Execution is a process for implementing the Strategy and for adapting it along its implementation. But we also have a Strategy Execution System that is a structural construct that incorporates a number of components that allow us to decide on Corrective & Adaptation actions, along a Strategy Execution cycle (Strategy is a multi-annual construct that gets implemented in a sequence of annual Execution Cycles). If you want to get more clarity on these Strategy views, don't forget that there is a coming edition of the [Explaining Strategy course](https://www.linkedin.com/company/explaining-strategy?trk=public_post-text), scheduled for Sep 1-29. Enrollment, here: [explaining-strategy.com](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=http%3A%2F%2Fexplaining-strategy%2Ecom&urlhash=tGlR&trk=public_post-text) Also read: THE STRATEGY MODEL [https://lnkd.in/dMBrBtAg](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2FdMBrBtAg&urlhash=fWn7&trk=public_post-text) THE STRATEGY CORE [https://lnkd.in/dPiHamHG](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2FdPiHamHG&urlhash=3sUV&trk=public_post-text) THE BUSINESS MODEL [https://lnkd.in/dGJPDawK](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2FdGJPDawK&urlhash=cXKz&trk=public_post-text) FROM STRATEGY CORE TO BUSINESS MODEL [https://lnkd.in/dBrnT5xB](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2FdBrnT5xB&urlhash=sPBU&trk=public_post-text) THE STRATEGY EXECUTION [https://lnkd.in/d4cAryZa](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2Fd4cAryZa&urlhash=6RiV&trk=public_post-text) THE FULL STRATEGY CYCLE [https://lnkd.in/dTFTnCTH](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2FdTFTnCTH&urlhash=PDAD&trk=public_post-text) EXPLAINING STRATEGY [https://lnkd.in/dEUscBt3](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2FdEUscBt3&urlhash=t0_f&trk=public_post-text) Higher-resolution image: [https://lnkd.in/d2y4GFnv](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flnkd%2Ein%2Fd2y4GFnv&urlhash=Pu1Q&trk=public_post-text)

title: Patterns of Business
ai_summary: Different business models have varying effectiveness, with some becoming outdated. The simplest models tend to be the most memorable, though simplicity doesn't imply ease of mastery. A business should address real problems that people are willing to pay to solve, focusing on task-oriented solutions rather than just theoretical frameworks.
body:
Some models fails faster than others.

Some models are usefull.

Why

What

How

Who

In the area of trying to explain what a business do there have been a lot of attempts such as Zachmnans Framework for enterprise architecture, Koppler in Operational Processes, BMC, Kottler in marketing, x in change, y in strategy and Meyer Briggs type indicator in personal test. 

Some are aleady outdated. All of them had a purpose in trying to explain something that is abstract. And I would argue that the easiest to understand models are the one that sticks.

Easy dosent mean that it is uncomplicated. For e.g. Chess is easy to understand how to move the pieces on the board but takes a lifetime to master.

 I have my bag of tools with me when I enter and work in a organisation. For me SImon Sinek really did mess things up for a while but now I just came to understand it better and need to interpetad his words in another context.

In his book he starting with Why as a groundwork for every organisations existance.

And that is correct if you understand what Simon means with why.

I reprase everything as our need to solve things. Task oriented. A problem.

A definition would be something like:

‚ÄúA Busienss is to adress a real problem that someone is willing to pay for getting help with

I intentinally wrote help because some problems cant be solved. They can just be mitigrated.

title: Technical Dept and Financial Dept should it be handled in the same way
ai_summary: Debt can take various forms, including financial, technical, organizational, and skill debt. It is essential to quantify and manage these debts to avoid merely paying interest without addressing underlying issues. A comprehensive plan should be created and communicated to tackle these debts effectively, ensuring that investments lead to sustainable organizational growth rather than just short-term fixes.
body:
[[Planning - Predicting the Unpredictable]]
![[Technical Dept.jpg]]
Illustration from: Vincent DNL
We often think of debt as financial, but what about technical or skill debt? Without a plan to address them, you‚Äôre just paying interest. Here‚Äôs why quantifying and managing all forms of debt is crucial to your organisation‚Äôs survival.
Is debt always a bad thing? No.¬†Sometimes, you need capital from outside to realise your idea or invest to move faster. The problem is when your cash flow is used only to pay the interest.
Dept can have many shapes and forms. It can be:
- a financial debt
- technical debt
- organisational debt
- skill debt
- innovation debt
Sometimes, you need to go faster than your organisation can, creating a debt that can be dealt with later. But after a while, you only pay interest if you don‚Äôt tackle the problem.
I strongly recommend quantifying your debt, putting a number on it, and, most importantly, creating a comprehensive plan to work with it. Having a plan that is communicated is the key.
For e.g.
- Financial dept: 100mUSD - 8mUSD in interest
- Technical dept: 250mUSD - 25mUSD in ‚Äúinterest‚Äù
- Skill Dept: 100mUSD - 30mUSD in ‚Äúinterest‚Äù.
The numbers are, of course, more objective than a bank loan can be.
For example, after many years, the Technical Debt would cost 250mUSD to fix in its entirety. In the current state, we need to add 25mUSD per year to patch what is broken for today‚Äôs situation. Remember, a system was often built for its purpose those years ago, so that decision might have been the right one at the time. However, the lack of investment has contributed to the current situation over the years.
You could have a prognosis that if you invest 100mUSD, you go from 25mUSD to 5mUSD and have an ROI of 5 years.
The same goes for the Skill Debt, where you might need more or other competence today. That can be much more costly to handle in everyday operations. Again, put a number on it. Make a plan. Be transparent.
Some say it is impossible to argue. But last year‚Äôs profits were okay, right? Another way is to borrow money and not put that in the books and say, ‚ÄúHey, look, we‚Äôre rich.‚Äù
Suppose you are transparent with all your debts. In that case, there will be a better discussion of whether we should:
do the next shiny thing
or fix our basics and get a sustainable organisation that doesn‚Äôt only pay interest.
A bank loan is only one type of debt.

title: A real problems is the nicest gift you can get
ai_keywords: Customer Insight Gathering, Problem Identification, Real Issue Verification
ai_summary: Problems are valuable gifts that help identify real issues. Key methods to define a problem include interviewing customers, analyzing competitor solutions, sending surveys, reviewing complaints, monitoring social media feedback, and observing product usage to uncover common issues.
body:
Problems are the nicest gift you can get

Don't Solve Imaginary Problems: A Guide to Verifying Real Issues

10 ways to define a problem

1. Interview the customer. Ask what problem they have and why they aren't happy about the solution today.
2. Understand how five other services or products solves what specific problem?

1. Ask customers what problems they have with current options.
2. See how five other products solve similar problems.
3. Send out surveys to learn about customer issues.
4. Read customer complaints to find common issues.
5. Check social media for what customers are saying.
6. Watch customers use your product to find problems.

[Why you want to see everything in imanges or pictures ](A%20real%20problems%20is%20the%20nicest%20gift%20you%20can%20get/Why%20you%20want%20to%20see%20everything%20in%20imanges%20or%20pictu%20331d6f9001644cf29833a00a6c56fc95.md)

title: Team Interaction
ai_summary: The interaction and contract within a team are crucial, often more so than the team's structure itself. This interaction can be formalized as a service contract, outlining expectations of input and output. A reference to Martin Kralj's insights on this topic is provided.
body:
What kind of interaction and contract you have between your team is more important than the team setup itself.
You could argue that the interaction is part of the team setup, but often, this is overseen.
As Martin Kralj illustrated in his post, the discussion could be nuanced. The definition of the interaction could be written down as a contract.
You would have service contracts that state send x get y.
