title: The work against Ageism I hired an 65-ish old consultant
ai_summary: Hiring older, experienced consultants is crucial as they bring valuable lessons from past mistakes. It's disheartening that many companies overlook their expertise, opting instead for a "move fast and break things" mentality. Every team should include at least one seasoned professional to guide and prevent repeating errors.
body:
- [x] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)

I hired an very experienced consultant in a specific niche area. The reason? I wanted someone that have done all the misstakes that are in the book and some.

With age comes expericens.

Im saden that we still have problem hiring older people with experice. That is like saying ‚Äúwe do not care of the earlier misstakes that are made, we want to do them again‚Äù.

Well, ‚Äúgo fast and break things‚Äù is the new black (Qoute from Marc Sucker).

I highly recommend to have at least one experienced person in your team of 8.

But that just me. And I also starting to come at age. I will be 50 this years old. And have I made misstakes :-) More than fits in this story.

What is your take on hiring older people with experience?

# **Embracing Wisdom: Why I Chose a Seasoned Pro for My Team**

So, I went ahead and hired a consultant who‚Äôs been around the block‚Äî65 years old and packed with experience in a very specific field. Why? Because this person has already made every mistake you can think of, and probably invented a few new ones!

Experience matters.

It‚Äôs disheartening to see how often older folks with a wealth of knowledge are overlooked in the job market. It‚Äôs as if companies are saying, ‚ÄúWho cares about past blunders? Let‚Äôs make them all over again ourselves!‚Äù

Remember Marc Suckers mantra, ‚ÄúMove fast and break things‚Äù? Well, that‚Äôs trendy, but sometimes it‚Äôs wiser to move wisely and fix things. That‚Äôs why I believe every team should include at least one veteran of the game.

But hey, that‚Äôs just me, getting on in years too‚ÄîI‚Äôm hitting the big 5-0 soon, and boy, have I racked up some stories of my own! More than I could fit here, for sure.

What is your take on hiring older people with experience?

body:
Du kan inte leva p√• dina gamla meriter üèÜ!

B√∂rjade tr√§na Kyokushin karate ü•ã igen efter ca 25 √•rs uppeh√•ll. Jag fick ett r√§tt brutalt uppvaknande att den h√§r gamla kroppen inte beter sig som den gjorde back-in-the-days.

Nu g√∂r jag det med min 13-√•riga son och vi har v√§ldigt roligt ihop. Vi pushar varandra, vilket √§r viktigt i tr√§ning.

Nu √§r tr√§ningen l√•ngsiktig f√∂r jag har som m√•l att vara en pigg 70-√•ring som fortfarande kan vara aktiv.

title: Reconfigurable organization
ai_summary: Reconfigurable organizations require clear principles and a strong team purpose, with dynamic cross-boundary teams formed for growth and innovation, as conceptualized by Jay Galbraith. Reference: "Networked, Scaled, and Agile" by Kates et al.
body:
There are many try to fix organisation. But you need to create a some principles that you want to work from. Teams that could be organisated as fit and the main thing is a strong purpose. So what is a strong team-purpose? Perhaps we should start with that?
Purpose
Function
Outcome

Read book.
‚Äúreconfigurable organization,‚Äù he conceptualized it as a multi-dimensional matrix that remained relatively stable.
When Jay Galbraith (Galbraith, 2010) introduced the ‚Äúreconfigurable organization,‚Äù he conceptualized it as a multi-dimensional matrix that remained relatively stable, boosted with a set of dynamic cross-boundary teams that would be formed around major growth and innovation opportunities and disband once the task was accomplished. ‚Äî location: [1819](kindle://book?action=open&asin=B08PQ2DH4V&location=1819) ^ref-63879

title: F√∂ruts√§ttningarna i strategiarbetet
ai_summary: Strategiarbete kr√§ver en hypotes om framtida m√•l och en f√∂rst√•else f√∂r verksamhetens inre funktioner. Viktiga verktyg inkluderar aff√§rsmodeller, kundresor, processkartor och informationsmodeller f√∂r att validera strategin. En bra strategi fokuserar p√• att l√∂sa ett par centrala utmaningar snarare √§n att lista m√•nga initiativ, och arbetet ska vara iterativt f√∂r att anpassa sig till nya insikter.
body:
# F√∂ruts√§ttningarna i strategiarbetet

Strategi √§r inte n√•got man visar upp.
Det √§r ett samtal som m√•ste forts√§tta.
S√• fort man s√§ger att man √§r klar, slutar man t√§nka.

# F√∂ruts√§ttningarna i strategiarbetet

*Av Thomas Larsson*

Vad beh√∂vs egentligen f√∂r ett lyckat strategiarbete?

Det finns inget enkelt svar. Men jag vet hur man inte ska g√∂ra.

Jag t√§nker inte utge mig f√∂r att vara en strategi-guru som kan analysera omv√§rld, marknad och den egna organisationen och sedan s√§tta n√•gra bets som visar sig vara r√§tt.

Men jag kan p√•st√• att m√•nga bygger sitt strategiarbete bakv√§nt. Man tittar f√∂r mycket ut√•t och f√∂r lite in√•t. Som arkitekt har jag s√•klart en bias. Jag beh√∂ver en struktur f√∂r att f√∂rst√• verksamheten. Det g√•r att jobba utan, men det blir on√∂digt mycket dimma.

## **Det b√∂rjar med en hypotes**

Alla strategier handlar i grunden om en f√∂rflyttning.

Vi ska n√•gonstans. Bli b√§st, billigast, st√∂rst, mest unika eller mest relevanta. Men oavsett m√•l √§r det i b√∂rjan bara ett antagande. En strategihypotes.

Hur man kommer fram till den hypotesen kan variera. Kaplan och Norton pratar om Balanced Scorecard. McKinsey om 7S. XXP (Extreme Enterprise Planning) √§r ett annat exempel.

Men oavsett modell m√•ste hypotesen testas.

## **Det du beh√∂ver f√∂r att testa strategin**

F√∂r att kunna validera strategihypotesen beh√∂vs en bild av hur verksamheten faktiskt fungerar. N√•gra verktyg jag ofta anv√§nder:

1. **Aff√§rsmodell** (till exempel BMC) om aff√§ren i sig ska f√∂r√§ndras.
    
    Hj√§lper till att se *hur v√§rde skapas och f√•ngas* och om int√§ktslogiken h√•ller n√§r strategin f√∂r√§ndras.
    
2. **Kundresa** om kundens beteende √§ndras.
    
    Anv√§nds f√∂r att f√∂rst√• *var upplevelsen skaver* och var nya m√∂jligheter till v√§rde uppst√•r n√§r strategin m√∂ter marknaden.
    
3. **Process- och f√∂rm√•gekarta** f√∂r att f√∂rst√• f√∂rflyttningar i verksamheten.
    
    Visar *vilka f√∂rm√•gor som b√§r strategin* och vilka som beh√∂ver st√§rkas, byggas upp eller kanske avvecklas.
    
4. **Informationsmodell och systemkarta** f√∂r att se hur informationsfl√∂den p√•verkas.
    
    Hj√§lper till att f√∂rst√• *vilken information som blir kritisk* f√∂r att kunna genomf√∂ra strategin, och var flaskhalsarna finns.
    

Tillsammans bildar de en meta-modell √∂ver vad strategin egentligen ska p√•verka.

Strategin blir d√• inte ett dokument utan en upps√§ttning prioriterade aktiviteter. Vad vi ska g√∂ra och lika viktigt, vad vi inte ska g√∂ra.

## **En sv√•r sak**

Richard Rumelt beskriver i sin bok *The Crux* att en bra strategi ofta handlar om att identifiera en eller tv√• riktigt sv√•ra saker och l√∂sa just dem.

Det √§r s√§llan en lista med fyrtio initiativ.

Det √§r oftare en riktning som kr√§ver mod och fokus p√• det som g√∂r skillnad.

## **Reality check, inte ritual**

Strategiarbete f√•r aldrig bli en linj√§r process. Det ska vara iterativt.

Varje hypotes beh√∂ver testas, stressas och ibland kasseras. ‚ÄúNow it‚Äôs only execution‚Äù √§r ofta ett tecken p√• att t√§nkandet tog slut f√∂r tidigt.

Jag brukar titta p√• alternativa scenarier.

- Kanske outsourca problemet.
- Eller bygga kompetensen sj√§lv.
- Eller v√§lja en helt annan v√§g.

Det g√∂r strategin mer trov√§rdig att inte l√•sa fast sig i en enda m√∂jlig v√§g fram√•t.

## **F√∂rm√•gor som karta**

En f√∂rm√•gekarta hj√§lper till att se var hypotesen tr√§ffar.

- Vilka delar av verksamheten kommer klara f√∂r√§ndringen bra?
- Vilka kommer f√• problem?
- Vad f√∂rst√•r vi inte √§n?

F√∂rm√•gekartan blir d√• ett verktyg f√∂r att visualisera f√∂rflyttningen, nu- och senl√§ge. Det kan vara f√∂r√§ndringar i People, Processes och Tools. Eller helt nya f√∂rm√•gor som m√•ste till.

## **Slutord**

Strategi √§r inte en PowerPoint.

Det √§r ett p√•g√•ende samtal om vad vi ska bli bra p√• och vad vi v√§ljer bort.

Utan det samtalet finns ingen riktning, bara aktivitet.

[What_is_strategy_4_pdf_1690720173.pdf](F%C3%B6ruts%C3%A4ttningarna%20i%20strategiarbetet/What_is_strategy_4_pdf_1690720173.pdf)

Vad beh√∂vs i grunden f√∂r ett lyckat strategiarbete? Det finns inte ett enkelt svar p√• den fr√•gan. Dock vet jag hur man inte ska g√∂ra.

T√§nker inte p√•st√• att jag √§r en strategi-expert som kan jobba igenom omv√§rld, marknad och den egna organisation och s√§tta ett antal bets som sedan visa sig vara r√§tt.

Det jag dock t√§nker p√•st√• √§r att m√•nga bygger sitt strategiarbete genom att titta f√∂r mycket ut√•t och f√∂r lite vad verksamheten kan bli bra p√•. Som arkitekt har jag s√•klart en bias p√• hur jag vill beskriva en verksamhet. Det √§r viss struktur jag beh√∂ver f√∂r att kunna f√∂rst√• b√§ttre. Det g√•r utan, men √§r enklar med. 

S√• vad beh√∂ver man f√∂r att jobba med strategi i en organisation? Vissa s√§ger, inget. Men d√• kommer vi tillbaka till mitt p√•st√•ende att vi inte har fokus p√• vad vi kan bli riktigt bra p√•.

Mitt resonemang g√•r ungef√§r s√•h√§r:

Det b√∂rjar med ett framtida l√§ge. Vi ska √•t n√•got h√•ll. Vara b√§st, billigast, flest produkter, flest l√§nder, st√∂rst volym, h√∂gst kvalitet, r√§tt m√•lgrupp, unikt erbjudande, smartast genomf√∂randet, b√§st supplychain, b√§sta partners. Oavsett vilket m√•l och vilken strategi man kommit fram till s√• √§r det ett antagande som borde verifieras i omg√•ngar. Vi kan kallad det f√∂r en strategihypotes. Hur man kommer fram till m√•len och strategivalen √§r det andra √§n jag som b√§ttre kan f√∂rklara. Balanced Scorecard (Kaplan & Norton), XXP ‚Äì Extreme Enterprise Planning, McKinsey 7S √§r exempel.

Men f√∂r att validera sin hypotes anser jag att det beh√∂vs ett antal saker (inte alla, men n√•gra).

1. Aff√§rsmodell (t.ex. BMC) om man ska f√∂r√§ndra sin aff√§r.
2. Kundresa om kundens beteende √§ndras.
3. Process och f√∂rm√•gekarta f√∂r att f√∂rst√• f√∂r√§ndringar i verksamheten.
4. Informationsmodell och systemkarta f√∂r att f√∂rst√• informationsf√∂rs√∂rjningen.

![CleanShot 2025-05-13 at 22.25.55@2x.png](F%C3%B6ruts%C3%A4ttningarna%20i%20strategiarbetet/CleanShot_2025-05-13_at_22.25.552x.png)

Om ovanst√•nde √§r meta-modellen f√∂r vad strategin ska √•stadkomma. Strategin ska slutligen best√• av prioriterade aktiviteter som beh√∂vs f√∂r att n√• m√•let. Vad vi g√∂r. Och kanske √§n viktigare, vad vi inte g√∂r.

Om man inte vill g√• djupare s√• beskriver Richard Rumelt i sin bok ‚ÄúThe Crux‚Äù [https://thecruxbook.com/](https://thecruxbook.com/) att v√§gen till f√∂rflyttningen som beh√∂ver g√∂ras best√•r ofta av en eller tv√• sv√•ra saker. Identifiera och v√§rdera dessa.

I ett iterativt arbete s√• kan d√• hypotesen snabbt besvaras om det g√•r, genom att en ‚Äúrealitycheck‚Äù eller provtryckning g√∂rs f√∂r varje hypotes som kommer upp p√• bordet. Det man ska undvika √§r att se det som en linj√§r process d√§r man s√§ger ‚Äúnu √§r strategiarbetet klart, dags f√∂r verksamheten f√∂r execution‚Äù.

> Now its only execution foks.
> 

En sak jag brukar jobba med √§r att se om det finns scenarion f√∂r att l√∂sa utmaningen. Kanske outsourca problemet, eller skaffa sig r√§tt kompetens sj√§lv, eller ta en annan v√§g. Det g√∂r strategin mer trov√§rdig, enligt mig.

Ett s√§tt att anv√§nda f√∂rm√•gekartor √§r att g√∂ra lager ovanp√• f√∂rm√•gan f√∂r att se var det strategiska hypotesen sl√•r. Vad som kommer troligen fungera bra. Vad som inte kommer fungera. Vad vi inte f√∂rst√•r.

F√∂rm√•gorna kan agera som bilden √∂ver vilka f√∂rflyttningar som beh√∂ver g√∂ras. M√•nga anv√§nder People, Processes and Tools som perspektiv vad som ska f√∂r√§ndras. Nu och senl√§ge. Det kan √§ven vara helt nya f√∂rm√•gor som beh√∂vs.

![CleanShot 2025-05-13 at 22.48.12@2x.png](F%C3%B6ruts%C3%A4ttningarna%20i%20strategiarbetet/CleanShot_2025-05-13_at_22.48.122x.png)

title: Worst possible environment to predict the future
ai_summary: In a VUCA world‚Äîcharacterized by volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and ambiguity‚Äîpredicting the future is challenging. Organizations must adapt to constant change, as nothing remains fixed.
body:
To predict the future and create a plan, you need something fixed. For some organisations, nothing is fixed. Welcome to the world of VUCA.
Volatile, Uncertain, Complex and Ambiguous.
Driving Change in a VUCA world
The acronym stands for Volatile, Uncertain, Complex and Ambiguous. So when people refer to a VUCA world, they refer to a world where you cannot possibly foresee everything ahead of time (if anything, really). This is true to the whole world ‚Äì the planet Earth, but also to the world, or context if you like, in which you and your organization operate.
‚ÄúThe only constant in life is change‚Äù (Heraclitus, Greek philosopher, 535 BC ‚Äì 475 BC)
## Metadata

* Published Date: 2020-08-03

title: Why use map layers
ai_summary: Map layers enhance organization and structure by allowing thematic grouping, hierarchical organization, and simplified layer lists, which reduce clutter and improve navigation for users.
body:
## Organization and Structure

https://www.perplexity.ai/search/explain-map-layers-and-continu-78Ug4P0HRoeOHPspqWOEIQ
Group layers allow you to logically organize related layers together, improving the overall structure of your map:
- **Thematic grouping**: You can group layers by theme or topic, such as grouping all water-related layers (rivers, lakes, watersheds) together.
- **Hierarchical organization**: Group layers can be nested, allowing for multiple levels of organization.
- **Simplified layer list**: By grouping related layers, you can reduce clutter in the layer list, making it easier for users to navigate.

title: The most important part of designing a map or a model Picking the right layer
ai_summary: Choosing the right layer is crucial when designing a map or model, as it influences user understanding and experience. Focus on essential information, simplify for clarity, and ensure the map serves its intended purpose for the audience.
body:
2x faster decision-making by simplifying your map or model to only information needed for action.

Yesterday, I had two meetings with clients about this topic: ‚ÄúWe need a model to have a good discussion before a decision,‚Äù and ‚ÄúWe always need to understand why we are creating a model for a specific purpose.‚Äù

When creating a map or a model, the most important decision you‚Äôll make is choosing the right layer. Why? Because the layer you choose dictates how users will view and understand your data‚Äîand ultimately defines their experience.

Consider Google Maps. Its main focus is transportation, and it is designed to help people get from point A to point B, whether by car, bus, bike, or foot. It‚Äôs about highlighting only what is important to send the message to your audience as simple as possible.

So, when designing a map or model, ask yourself:

1. Who is the primary audience for this map or model?
2. What‚Äôs the important information my map should show?
3. How can I make it as straightforward as possible without distraction?
4. What specific action do I want the user to take after viewing your map?

Creating a map isn‚Äôt about piling on data; it‚Äôs about understanding what‚Äôs essential to your audience and stripping away what‚Äôs not. Less is more!

Remember: No one needs a map that is a piece of art. üòâ

Before you dive in, always answer the key question: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most important message I want my audience to see?‚Äù And once you‚Äôre done, be sure to follow up to see if that message is received by your audience.

## Reference

[https://dataanddesign.substack.com/p/saying-more-with-less-how-designing](https://dataanddesign.substack.com/p/saying-more-with-less-how-designing)
Author: Christopher K Wong

title: En viktig sak foÃàr att foÃàrstaÃä din framtid üöÄ
ai_summary: F√∂r att f√∂rst√• framtiden, reflektera √∂ver tidigare beslut och nuvarande f√∂ruts√§ttningar. Identifiera n√∂dv√§ndiga √•tg√§rder f√∂r √∂verlevnad och skapa flera scenarier f√∂r att vara b√§ttre f√∂rberedd p√• f√∂r√§ndringar. Skriv din egen framtid.
body:
Att f√∂rutsp√• framtiden √§r sv√•rt eftersom ingen egentligen kan g√∂ra det. Men det hindrar inte mig att be dig f√∂rs√∂ka üòä

Jag har senaste √•ren funderat ü§î¬†√∂ver vad som g√∂r organisationer l√•ngsiktigt relevanta!

Det handlar √§ven forts√§ttningsvis att f√∂rst√• kundens **riktiga problem**.

Du beh√∂ver troligen t√§nka om lite n√§r det kommer till l√•ngsiktig planering. Idag kanske du funderar i banor som, digitialisering, innovation och trendande ord. Jag vill att du ist√§llet‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶tittar bak√•t!

## D√•l√§ge üëÄ

Vad blev du och din organisation tvungna att g√∂ra de senaste fem √•ren? Vilka m√•sten har genomf√∂rts? Vilka var besluten?

Var det en ny eller uppdaterad produkt eller tj√§nst som upptog din uppm√§rksamhet? Var det lagkrav (som GDPR)? Var det en ihopslagning f√∂r att n√• nya marknadsandelar? H√§r hittar du f√∂rhoppningsvis de beslut som ledde fram till n√∂dv√§ndiga f√∂r√§ndringar, √§ven vilka prioriteringar som gjordes. N√•gra av besluten kan ha lett till dagens interna problem.

## Nul√§ge üö¶

Sen f√∂rs√∂ker du kartl√§gga nul√§get. Vilka f√∂ruts√§ttningar har du idag, givet er historia? Vart √§r du och organisationen p√• v√§g om det forts√§tter som det g√∂r idag? Summera d√• b√•de styrkor, svagheter, hot och m√∂jligheter. Interna som externa.

## Senl√§ge üó∫Ô∏è

N√§r dessa grundl√§ggande delar finns p√• plats, d√• kan du b√∂rja sia om framtiden. Anv√§nd dig d√• av fr√•gorna:

1. Vad **m√•ste** vi g√∂ra f√∂r v√•r √∂verlevnad? Vilka **beslut** beh√∂ver vi ta?
2. Vilka olika **scenarion** har vi?

Om ledningen inte beh√∂ver svara p√• den fr√•gan om det √§r ett **m√•ste** s√• beh√∂ver du kanske byta ut ledningen. Ingen organisation √∂verlever utan att adressera sina m√•sten och det enda som √§r konstant h√§r i v√§rlden √§r‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶f√∂r√§ndring.

Hur du v√§ljer att se p√• er f√∂r√§ndring √§r upp till dig. Med ett proaktivt arbetss√§tt s√• kan du skapa den framtid du vill ha p√• dina villkor ist√§llet f√∂r att reaktivt reagera p√• vad andra g√∂r.

**Scenarion** √§r till f√∂r att hj√§lpa till att f√•nga flera m√∂jliga framtider. Det h√§r √§r egentligen nyckeln att vara mer f√∂rberedd. Ist√§llet f√∂r att ha en enda plan, s√• har du fler.

D√•, nu, sen. G√∂r om.

Historien upprepar sig sj√§lv. Mitt tips √§r att du skriver framtiden sj√§lv.

title: Flexible
ai_summary: Organizations need to adopt a flexible approach across all departments, not just IT, to meet the growing demand for flexibility, often referred to as Agile.
body:
Companies need¬†to be more flexible, which is a strong need.

Some people call that Agile.
I have started to use the word Flexible :-)

title: Feeling Lost in All the Details Lets Sort It Out with Our Easy-to-use Business Map Workshop!
ai_summary: Join the Business Map workshop on January 25th to learn how to visualize customer journeys, align your steps, identify improvements, and manage projects effectively using Miro. Sign up to become a Map Talker and lead the initiative!
body:
- [x] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)

Ever feel like it‚Äôs tough getting everyone in your team on the same page? Or maybe you‚Äôre trying to figure things out for yourself? We‚Äôve got just the thing for you - it‚Äôs called a Business Map.

Please have a look at what we have in store for you!

Link to our Talk Track in Miro: [https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVN5hdi70=/?playRecording=8372607f-ecd8-467c-8cf0-90eb93805d57](https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVN5hdi70=/?playRecording=8372607f-ecd8-467c-8cf0-90eb93805d57)

Think of a Business Map as a treasure map for your work. It helps everyone see the big picture and the small details really easily. We start with the basics and then add more stuff step by step, depending on your needs.

On January 25th, Cecilia and I will show you how to make your map. Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôll do:

1. **Customer Journey:** We begin by looking at what your customers go through.
2. **Your Steps:** We make sure your steps match up with your customer‚Äôs journey.
3. **What You Do:** We talk about everything your organisation does in simple action words.
4. **Your Tools:** We add in the tools you use.
5. **Connect the Dots:** We link what your customers do with what you do.
6. **Spot Improvements:** We use the map to find places where things can get better.
7. **Your Projects:** We put in all the projects you‚Äôre working on.
8. **First Check:** We ask ourselves, ‚ÄúAre we doing the right stuff?‚Äù

Please look at what we will do in miro and our [Miro Talk Track](https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVN5hdi70=/?playRecording=8372607f-ecd8-467c-8cf0-90eb93805d57).

Do you want to become a Map Talker and lead the way? Just send me a DM, and we will take it from there!

title: Close the back doors2
ai_summary: Establish an investment board to make decisions based on clear criteria and progress evidence, ensuring no side channels for funding ideas outside the approved process.
body:
[[Align how to prioritise for everyone to accept and work towards common goals]]

## Highlights

- Set up an investment board where leaders use predefined criteria for making investment decisions. Only increase investment in ideas based on evidence of progress towards success.
    - **Note**: No priority line in the checkout to approved projects or initiatives. All handledequal. If it change the process and often how to evaluate things.
- Once this process is set up, close the back doors! This is an important discipline to have. Teams should not be allowed to have a backchannel to leaders where they can get investment in their ideas on the side.

title: Maps More Than Just Directions
ai_summary: Maps are powerful tools that go beyond navigation; they provide understanding of geography, culture, and social trends, offering stability in a changing world and connecting us in meaningful ways.
body:
7 Sections x 30 sec = 3,5 min.

**Introduction**
- Hello everyone! Today, let‚Äôs take a journey, not just to the north, south, east, or west, but into the world of maps. Maps are not just about finding our way; they are powerful tools that guide our understanding of the world and if you want your business.
**Understanding Maps**
- When we think about maps, we often picture a static image showing roads, rivers, and cities. But maps are so much more. They are stable companions in an ever-changing world, providing a sense of direction whether you‚Äôre exploring a bustling city or navigating through life‚Äôs metaphorical wilderness.
**The Power of Zoom In**
- Let‚Äôs zoom in, literally. With modern maps, we can dive into incredible detail. Zoom in level by level, and you see streets, then buildings, and even individual trees. This zoom feature isn‚Äôt just about seeing closer; it‚Äôs about understanding our environment on a micro-level.
**Maps as Guides**
- Maps guide us. Not just in the literal sense of getting from point A to B, but they guide our understanding. They tell stories of landscapes, cultures, history, and even politics. They make the complex world more comprehensible.

**Mapping Beyond Geography**

- Maps aren‚Äôt just geographical. They map economies, social trends, and even our brains. Imagine a map of human thought, or a map showing the spread of a viral tweet. Maps are tools for understanding patterns, trends, and connections.

**Stability in a Changing World**

- In our fast-paced, ever-changing world, maps provide a sense of stability. They are constant yet adaptable. As our world evolves, so do maps. They are living documents constantly updated to reflect new roads, new countries, and even new planets.

**Conclusion**

- In conclusion, maps are more than just tools for direction. They are guides to understanding our complex world. They provide stability in a fast-changing environment and connect us in ways we often overlook. And they are excellent for understanding an organisation.

---

# References

1. [[Map a help not replacement]]

[[Enterprise Architecture]]
Enterprise Architecture is dead! What business value do you bring to your organisation? Most professions with ‚Äúarchitecture‚Äù in their title can‚Äôt answer that question. And if that is the case, you should look for another job or return to the basics.

Today‚Äôs situation:

For expert only

Questionable Real Value

Never-ending Method wars

Bloated Enterprise Frameworks

Hidden Data in non-collaborative Tools

Tomorrows needs:

Explaining how everything is connected

Being flexible and creative to define the future

Creating sustainable long-term business outcomes

Define the future state and a plan for how to get there

Use words like Why, How, What, Who for common ground

Words I will replace in 2024:

Agile ‚Üí True Flexibility

Enterprise Architecture ‚Üí Sense Maker

Frameworks ‚Üí Your own Building Blocks

Enterprise Capability Models ‚Üí Business Map

Digital Transformation ‚Üí Necessary Movement

‚ÄúOrganizations no longer want their (EA) practice to be focused on standards, domains, structure and control ‚Ä¶ They want an EA practice that is focused on driving business outcomes, working in a flexible and creative way to help define the future and how to get there.‚Äù

title: Being better at Being better
ai_summary: Continuous improvement is about making small, important changes consistently. The mindset of "being better at being better" can differentiate us in 2025, emphasizing that progress is about direction rather than perfection. Each small step contributes to long-term success.
body:
**Being better at being better.** The road to greatness starts small.

- One easy decision.

- One simple message.

- One resource to complete the work.

At its core, continuous improvement means just one thing:

Being better.

But can we sustain it for the long term?

That‚Äôs about something deeper. It‚Äôs about a decision to:

Being better at being better.

That‚Äôs the mindset that can set us apart in 2025.

Small, important improvements. One step at a time.

Because after 1 000 steps in the right direction, you realize:

You don‚Äôt need to have it all figured out, just a direction.

(The Phrase ‚ÄúBeing better at being better‚Äù is borrowed from Seth Godin.)

So‚Ä¶ what‚Äôs your first step toward being better?

title: Possible - Obstacle
ai_keywords: Growth Mindset, Problem Identification, Real Issue Exploration
ai_summary: Addressing obstacles involves starting with positive possibilities to create rapport before discussing challenges. Establish shared alignment while acknowledging problems to effectively motivate and engage.
body:
- [ ] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)

Everything is not a clear problem. It might be an obsticle.
Playing with words.
Root Cause problem
Problem
Imaginary problem
Obsticles
And so on. What would you work on next?

> Why ‚ÄúProblem/Solution‚Äù is the #1 Pitch Mistake. | Michael Margolis posted on the topic | LinkedIn
Start with the Positive (The Possibility)
> 
> 
> 1. The big ideas that will capture the imagination.
> 
> 2. Create instant rapport and alignment.
> 
> 3. Connect around aspiration and motivation first.
> 
> Then, present the Challenges that stand in the way (The Obstacle)
> 
> 1. You see, you can still talk about the problems.
> 2. We‚Äôre all here to solve problems and make things better.
> 3. But you need to establish shared alignment.

Stop Burning Cash: Real Savings Next Year
Enterprise alignment can seem simple: Combine your strategy PPT with your ERP and CRM systems and a¬†pile of Excel files in the middle. Then we‚Äôll be fine.
Right?
No!
It‚Äôs often in the messy middle that things can feel like they‚Äôre falling apart. Sandwiched between well-established systems and clear strategic direction, it can be a bit confusing. But that‚Äôs exactly where we can create meaningful change!
NoCode tools are ready to solve this, and **Airtable** stands out. Airtable can transform that chaos into something usable - one step at a time. See it as something that stitches everything together, and the more separated your data is today, the more you have to win.
Next year, focus on real savings. Make fewer mistakes by removing your excels in the middle, and start building a system you can trust.
Two practical steps for better data next year:
1. Fix one Excel file and, with it, improve one workflow.
2. Redo the first step.
Aim for excellence in the middle, and you may finally stop feeling like you‚Äôre duct-taping the whole thing together and stop burning time and money.

body:
Styr ni p√• processer? D√• har konkurrenterna f√•tt en f√∂rdelen att ni √§r oflexibla

Processer och avdelningsnamn, syften √§ndras st√§ndigt. Nya chefer som kommer in ritar g√§rna om organisationsschemat, nya ramverk fylls p√• med bokstavskombinationer som f√•r Star Wars-modeller att framst√• som tydliga. √Ñnd√• v√§ljer m√•nga att styra och m√§ta just d√§r. Resultatet √§r tyv√§rr givet.

Ni blir oflexibla och konkurrenterna f√•r f√∂rdelen.

**F√∂rm√•gor √§r n√•got helt annat**

En f√∂rm√•ga √§r VAD organisationen faktiskt kan √•stadkomma, oavsett process och form. Att utveckla nya erbjudanden, att rekrytera kompetens, att hantera leverant√∂rer. Det √§r f√∂rm√•gor. De best√•r √§ven n√§r ni ritar om kartan. Hamel & Prahalad uttryckte det redan f√∂r 20 √•r sedan:

> ‚ÄúWhat people respect about the companies ‚Ä¶ is not how they are structured ‚Ä¶ but their capabilities.‚Äù
> 

*Capitalizing on Capabilities*

PwC Strategy visar samma sak. Strategier faller n√§r de inte byggs p√• verkliga f√∂rm√•gor, utan fastnar i strukturer och processlogik (min argumentation att det √§r d√•liga saker att leda och styra mot).

**Tre enkla sk√§l att byta fokus:**

- **F√∂rm√•gor √§r stabila.** De st√•r kvar √§ven n√§r organisationen √§ndras.
- **F√∂rm√•gor √§r begripliga.** Alla f√∂rst√•r vad det inneb√§r att ‚Äúkunna utveckla erbjudanden‚Äù.
- **F√∂rm√•gor √§r styrbara.** Ni kan f√∂lja upp p√• f√∂rm√•gor utan att kv√§va arbetss√§tten.

Pulakos & Kaiser (HBR, 2020) p√•minner:

> ‚ÄúTo achieve genuine agility and resilience, companies first have to commit themselves to stability.‚Äù
> 

Det √§r exakt det processer och avdelningar inte ger. De √§r till f√∂r att f√∂r√§ndras ‚Äì inte f√∂r att vara styrande fundament. N√§r ni placerar styrningen d√§r bygger ni cement i st√§llet f√∂r r√∂relse.

**Processer** finns f√∂r att beskriva hur arbetet g√•r till just nu och f√∂r att kunna f√∂rb√§ttras eller bytas ut n√§r vardagen f√∂r√§ndras. De m√•ste vara flexibla. D√§r har du verksamhetens m√∂jlighet att kunna st√§lla om och m√∂te omv√§rldens behov.

**Organisationen** finns f√∂r att f√∂rdela ansvar och resurser. Den ritas om n√§r f√∂ruts√§ttningar skiftar. Ofta √§r den √§ven kopplad till kostnad och [,](http://bokf√∂ring.men) bokf√∂ring. Men √§ven h√§r utmanar jag och f√∂rordar f√∂rm√•gor ist√§llet. 

Min po√§ng √§r! Sluta ge konkurrenterna gratis f√∂rdelar genom att l√•sa er sj√§lva. Styrning h√∂r hemma p√• f√∂rm√•gor, d√• bygger ni verklig styrka och l√§ttr√∂rlighet utan att det p√•verkar er flexibilitet.

Styr ni p√• processer och avdelningar? D√• √§r ni redan oflexibla vilket konkurrenterna tackar er f√∂r. Men det finns ett annat s√§tt att se p√• det. Styr mot r√§tt saker och till√•t b√•de processer och avdelningar √§ndras, ofta.

title: Three steps to destroy a company
ai_summary: To destroy a company, address the wrong problem, hire an uninformed CEO, and follow McKinsey's advice blindly. This approach leads to management confusion and can be an opportunity for competitors.
body:
![[Pasted image 20240805211348.png]]
Three steps to destroy a company

Inspired by my own experience and the book When McKinsey Comes to Town.

1. Addressing the wrong problem. Not seeking root cause.
2. Hire a CEO without industry or domain knowledge to address the wrong problem.
3. Ask McKinsey for a plan and analysis from people with even less knowledge of this specific company and follow it to the letter.

There you have it.

A bulletproof way of destroying your company!

Or you see it as an anti-pattern and celebrate with champagne when your biggest competitor asks McKinsey for help. This is an opportunity that you shouldn‚Äôt miss. They will have a lot of management confusion in the following years. Use it!

My work usually starts years after McKinsey has been in the town. Then, I try to save what can be saved.

I‚Äôm guessing that is a skill as well :-)

#WIP

title: Is your risk-based Prioritization one metric that needs a Better context
ai_summary: Prioritize risk by identifying areas of potential growth, compliance fines, customer loss, and talent attraction. Use visual tools like diagrams to facilitate discussions on understanding and mitigating these risks effectively.
body:
- [x] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)
- [ ]
If you prioritise Risk as a Metric, this can be interesting.

The question you want to ask your, business, process (map) is:

Where do I have the risk of:

- not growing fast enough
- possible compliance Fines
- losing customers due bad delivery
- not attracting the right people to your team
- not attracting the right customers to your business

Follow up by:

How can I better understand:

- Why do we have this risk?
- Who and what is causing the risk?
- How can/should we mitigate this risk?
- Where on the map did this risk appear?

By starting with a shared understanding of the basics of your organisation with a Diagram, Process or Map in for e.g.¬†Miro, you can ask these questions and have a good starting point for the discussion. I am biased, of course, and have the methods I‚Äôm in love with.

What is your best ‚Äúmap‚Äù that you use for visually show the organisation where the risk can be found?

[https://enterpriseadvocates.miro.com/c/advocates-homebase/is-your-risk-based-prioritization-one-metric-that-needs-a-better-context](https://enterpriseadvocates.miro.com/c/advocates-homebase/is-your-risk-based-prioritization-one-metric-that-needs-a-better-context)

title: Simplify how you explain your business for quicker clearer results
ai_summary: Simplifying business explanations enhances clarity, memorability, and actionability. Focus on four key elements: Why (purpose), Who (target audience), What (actions), and How (process) to improve communication and achieve quicker results.
body:
![[Post_why-what-who-how.png]]

Status: #article
Tags: #published #Patterns
- [x] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)
10 reasons why simplifying how you explain your business leads to better results
1. ‚ÄúSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication‚Äù:
Steve Jobs once said it. Simplicity makes ideas memorable, easily understood, and actionable.
2. Memorable Ideas:
Simple ideas stick. They are easy to remember and share.
3. Clarity:
People understand simple messages fast. No need for long explanations.
4. Actionable:
When things are simple, there is less room for confusion. People know what to do next.
5. Less is More:
Focus on the core message. Remove unnecessary details.
6. Avoid Jargon:
Use plain language. Everyone should understand your message.
7. Visuals Help:
Use simple visuals to explain complex ideas. A picture can be worth a thousand words.
8. Consistent Messaging:
Keep your message consistent across all platforms. This reinforces understanding.
9. Test and Refine:
Share your message with others. See if they understand it quickly. Refine as needed.
10. Practice Simplicity:
Make simplicity a habit. Apply it to all areas of your business communication.

Remember, simplicity leads to quicker understanding and quicker results!

Steve Jobs once said, ‚ÄúSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication.‚Äù He was onto something ‚Äì think about it!
Here‚Äôs why simplicity works:
- It‚Äôs memorable. Simple ideas stick.
- It‚Äôs easily understood. People get it, fast.
- It‚Äôs actionable. Less room for confusion or misinterpretation.
So, how can you simplify your business explanation? Try focusing on only four words: Why, Who, What, and How.
Here‚Äôs how you can apply this:
WHY: Define your purpose.
‚Ü≥ What problem do you solve for who? Your product or services.
WHO: Find Out Who Matters.
‚Ü≥ Who is buying your stuff, and who fits in your team?
WHAT: The things you do (a verb)
‚Ü≥ What do you need to do to solve your customer‚Äôs problems?
HOW: Explain How You Work.
‚Ü≥ What steps do you need to take to fix your customer‚Äôs problems?

Are you using overcomplicated words when they are not needed? Could these four be a good start?

body:
**ü¶ä R√§ven vaktar h√∂nshuset. Om ansvarsflykt och IT-s√§kerhet**

> ‚ÄúOm du beslutar om att gasa, d√• ska du inte ocks√• vara den som installerar bromsarna.‚Äù

Men det finns regler, det finns lagar och de kommer f√∂rr eller senare att bli dyrare √§n det arbete man enkelt hade kunnat g√∂ra i tid.

Som man brukar s√§ga: *A stitch in time saves nine.* Inget kunde vara mer sant n√§r det g√§ller IT-s√§kerhet.

### **Tre s√§tt att t√§nka r√§tt om IT-s√§kerhet**

**1. Separera rollerna ‚Äì alltid**

Den som driver aff√§r eller utdelning ska inte ocks√• ansvara f√∂r att granska sig sj√§lv.

**Det kan stilla samvetet, men skadan √§r redan skedd och kundernas f√∂rtroende √§r sv√•rt att reparera.**

N√§r styrning och kontroll hamnar hos samma person uppst√•r en tyst risk som inte syns i rapporter eller dashboards.

title: N√§r AI f√∂r√§ndrar spelplanen varje vecka ‚Äì hur t√§nker du strategi?
ai_summary: AI f√∂r√§ndrar snabbt spelplanen, vilket kr√§ver en mer flexibel och hypotesdriven strategi. Det √§r viktigt att f√∂rst√• hur v√§rdekedjan p√•verkas, hur kundbeteenden f√∂r√§ndras och vilken f√∂rm√•ga man har att leverera v√§rde. body:
**N√§r AI f√∂r√§ndrar spelplanen varje vecka, hur t√§nker du strategiskt och l√•ngsiktigt?**

Du kanske har en plan.
Men vad h√§nder n√§r det du planerar f√∂r idag inte ens √§r relevant n√§sta vecka?

Det h√§r handlar inte om att sl√§ppa strategiarbetet.
Det handlar troligen att t√§nka p√• ett helt annat s√§tt.

Ny artikel om hypoteser, scenarier och varf√∂r det mest strategiska du kan g√∂ra just nu‚Ä¶ √§r att b√∂rja experimentera. L√§s p√• min Substack.

**N√§r AI f√∂r√§ndrar spelplanen varje vecka, hur t√§nker du strategiskt och l√•ngsiktigt?**

Strategi har aldrig handlat om att du ska f√∂rutsp√• framtiden. Det handlar om att f√∂rst√• sin position p√• marknaden, sina egna f√∂rm√•gor och vad som h√•ller p√• att f√∂r√§ndras. AI har skruvat upp tempot: fr√•n √•rsplaner till n√•got som knappt ens hinner bli veckoplaner. Det kr√§ver ett annat t√§nk. Inte mindre strategi, men en som √§r mer lyh√∂rd, mer hypotesdriven och betydligt mer snabbfotad.

Traditionellt √§r strategi n√•got som f√•r ta tid. Du l√§gger m√•nader p√• att komma fram till en plan som ofta str√§cker sig √∂ver flera √•r. Den kan ompr√∂vas, men i grunden √§r den ett bet: ‚Äúvi tror att det h√§r √§r r√§tt riktning‚Äù.

Men det fungerar inte l√§ngre p√• samma s√§tt.

Vi st√•r inf√∂r n√•got som i sin karakt√§r kanske p√•minner om n√§r elektriciteten f√∂r√§ndrade samh√§llet. AI kommer p√•verka alla delar fr√•n hur beslut fattas, till hur kundv√§rde skapas och levereras. Djupet varierar, men bredden √§r omfattande.

Redan idag skriver politiker beslutsunderlag med hj√§lp av AI. M√•nga f√∂retag anv√§nder det i sin produktutveckling, kommunikation eller analys tyv√§rr ofta utan att ha en tydlig policy eller strategi. Men, hur ska du t√§nka d√•?

Precis som med andra tekniska m√∂jligg√∂rare beh√∂ver du fortfarande g√∂ra jobbet. Det nya √§r att AI:s f√∂rm√•ga f√∂r√§ndras n√§stan fr√•n vecka till vecka. Det som var science fiction i april √§r vardag i juni.

Vi √§r mitt i ett VUCA-landskap:

Volatility, Uncertainty, Complexity, Ambiguity.

### **Vad kan du g√∂ra?**

Det finns tre grundfr√•gor att b√∂rja med:

1. **Vilka delar av er v√§rdekedja kan p√•verkas?**
    
    Fr√•n r√•vara eller data, till leverans till slutkund. Vad f√∂r√§ndras? Var?
    
2. **Hur f√∂r√§ndras kundens beteende och f√∂rv√§ntningar?**
    
    Vad h√§nder n√§r dina kunder sj√§lva anv√§nder AI snabbare √§n du?
    
3. **Vad √§r din faktiska f√∂rm√•ga att leverera kundv√§rde i det nya l√§get?**
    
    Vilka problem l√∂ser ni? Vilka borde ni l√∂sa?
    

Utifr√•n det bygger du scenarier. Os√§kra, g√§rna provocerande. Du b√∂rjar experimentera. Du l√§r medan du g√∂r. Du g√•r tillbaka till dina hypoteser.

Ofta.

Du f√∂ljer utvecklingen n√§ra. Och du h√•ller koll p√• akt√∂rer som f√∂rs√∂ker f√∂r√§ndra spelplanen helt, troligen med AI som sin utg√•ngspunkt snarare √§n ett till√§gg.

### **Kort sagt:**

Strategin idag √§r kanske att vara utforskande och extremt lyh√∂rd.

Men det betyder inte att du saknar riktning. Du har en hypotes. Du har en id√©.

Skillnaden √§r att du vet att det du planerar f√∂r idag kan vara irrelevant redan n√§sta vecka.

S√• s√§tt ig√•ng. B√∂rja skapa hypoteser och experimentera! Lek üôÇ

PS. Jag experimenterar med Ai p√• daglig basis och ‚Äúleker‚Äù med verktygen. Har s√•klart en id√© men mycket handlar om att f√∂rst√• vad som g√•r och inte.

Ett verktyg som √§r extra sn√§llt √§r Airtable d√§r man bygger en hel ‚Äúapplikation‚Äù ovanp√• datat som √§r l√§tt att f√∂rst√• och adderar Ai-m√∂jligheter.

title: Create a simple plan
ai_summary: Simple plans are more effective than complex ones, as they lead to action rather than hesitation. Bill Gates advises hiring lazy people for problem-solving to find cost-efficient solutions, while Douglas Adams recommends choosing simplicity for easier management and control. A clear and straightforward approach enhances focus and execution speed.
body:
**A simple plan always beats a perfect one you never start.**
(Have you ever felt this way?)
When creating a plan, avoid overcomplicating things. Simple plans lead to action; complex ones lead to hesitation.
Here‚Äôs some advice from two brilliant minds:
**Bill Gates** suggests: *‚ÄúHire a lazy person to solve a problem. They will always find the easiest solution, which is also cost-efficient.‚Äù*
Douglas Adams says, ‚ÄúIf you can‚Äôt decide between a simple plan and a complicated one, choose the simple one. It‚Äôs easier to manage and control.‚Äù_
**Why simplicity wins for you:**
- Simple tasks are easier to manage.
- A clear plan keeps you focused.
- Fewer steps mean faster execution.
Next time you‚Äôre stuck between a simple or complex plan, choose the plan you‚Äôll actually do.
What‚Äôs your go-to approach when planning if a choice is an option?

Create a simple plan
Because a simple plan you do know always beats a perfect plan you never reach.

Bill Gates
Hire a lazy person to solve a problem. They will always try to find the easiest solution which is also cost-efficient.

Douglas Adams
If you can‚Äôt tell whether a simple plan or a complicated one will be the best, choose the simple one. If it‚Äôs a coin toss, you might as well do whatever is easiest. If the cost of failure is high, simple tasks are the best because they are easier to manage and control. ‚Äî location: [981](kindle://book?action=open&asin=B00FHI0XK2&location=981) ^ref-9355

When creating a plan you could have a strategy (chocies)
Optimizing is often the strategy of people who have specific goals and feel the need to do everything in their power to achieve them. title: Planning - Predicting the Unpredictable
ai_summary: Effective planning requires preparing for unknowns and adapting to unexpected changes. Incorporating scenarios into planning helps anticipate multiple outcomes, as plans often deviate from initial predictions. Remember, flexibility is key since things rarely go as planned.
body:
![[Pasted image 20241009220011.png]]
Planning: Predicting the Unpredictable. Your job as a planner is one of the toughest out there. Why? Because you‚Äôre tasked with predicting the future ‚Äî and let‚Äôs face it, no one‚Äôs truly great at that.
Your responsibility isn‚Äôt just to create a plan; it‚Äôs to prepare for the **unknowns**. You need to expect the unexpected ‚Äî like packing a raincoat even when the forecast says sunshine.
Most plans I see assume everything will go perfectly. That‚Äôs a mistake. As Maarten Dalmijn said, **‚ÄúDon‚Äôt limit your plans to your current limited understanding of the situation.‚Äù**
You have to be ready to adapt your plan from day one. Dwight D. Eisenhower got it right: **‚ÄúPlans are nothing; planning is everything.‚Äù**
It‚Äôs your duty to create scenarios and plan for different outcomes. This way, you‚Äôre not just predicting the future but preparing for multiple possibilities. Lao Tzu‚Äôs wisdom still holds: **‚ÄúIf you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading.‚Äù**
So, the next time you think, **‚ÄúNow it‚Äôs just about execution,‚Äù** remember ‚Äî it‚Äôs your responsibility to stay flexible because nothing ever goes exactly as planned.

Scenario

### Planning: The Art of Predicting the Unpredictable
Planning is one of the most challenging disciplines you need to master. Why? Because it asks you to predict the future ‚Äî and let‚Äôs face it, we humans aren‚Äôt exactly great at that.
The difference between a plan and a successful one lies in your ability to prepare for the

**unknowns**

‚Äî those unpredictable elements we can‚Äôt foresee. To navigate these uncertainties, you need to approach planning as we do with weather forecasting: with scenarios.
Imagine you‚Äôre planning a day out in nature. The weather forecast says there‚Äôs an 80% chance of sun, 10% chance of clouds, and 10% chance of rain. Even with a high probability of sun, you still pack a raincoat ‚Äî just in case.
Yet, what surprises me is that most plans I see rarely include scenarios where things deviate from the initial understanding. They assume everything will go perfectly according to the baseline prediction.
Maarten Dalmijn once said,

**‚ÄúDon‚Äôt limit your plans to your current limited understanding of the situation.‚Äù**

That line stuck with me.
Your plan should probably be adjusted from the very first week. As Dwight D. Eisenhower wisely put it,

**‚ÄúPlans are nothing; planning is everything.‚Äù**

When you incorporate scenarios into your planning, you‚Äôre not just predicting one future; you‚Äôre preparing for multiple possible outcomes. It‚Äôs like ‚Äúcheating‚Äù at predicting the future ‚Äî you‚Äôre planning for different versions of what might come next.
A few thousand years ago, Lao Tzu wrote,

**‚ÄúIf you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading.‚Äù**

The wisdom in that thought still holds true today.
So, the next time someone confidently says,

**‚ÄúNow it‚Äôs just about execution,‚Äù**

just smile and face the reality ‚Äî things will never go as planned.

---

This revision enhances readability, highlights key points, and creates a smooth narrative flow that draws in the reader while still maintaining a conversational tone. It also strategically incorporates quotes to strengthen the message.

Planning is one of the most challenging disciplines that you can work with. Reason? You are asked to predict the future, and we humans suck at it.
The main difference between a plan and a successful one is being prepared for what you don‚Äôt know‚Äîor your unknowns unknowns. To handle that, you need to predict your plan as we predict the weather. With scenarios.
So you‚Äôre planning a day out in nature. The weather forecast is 80% sun, 10% cloudy, and 10% rain. Then, you pack a raincoat before heading out.
What surprises me is that most plans I see seldom have a scenario where anything deviates from our current understanding.
Maarten Dalmijn wrote something stuck: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt limit your plans to your current limited understanding of the situation.‚Äù
You should be aware that the plan should probably be adjusted already from the first week, or as Dwight D. Eisenhower said, ‚ÄúPlans are nothing; planning is everything.‚Äù
So, if you put some scenarios in your plan and shift direction, you can predict the future better because you cheated. You are planning for different futures. A few thousand years ago, Lao Tzu wrote: ‚ÄúIf you do not change direction, you may end up where you are heading.‚Äù
So next time someone says, ‚ÄúNow it is only execution,‚Äù just smile and face reality; it will never go as planned anyway.

ai_summary: Styrelser och ledningsgrupper beh√∂ver utbildas i AI och dess m√∂jligheter och hot. Det √§r viktigt att f√∂rst√• hur AI p√•verkar arbetsmarknaden och demokratin. body:
Ai k√∂rkort f√∂r styrelser och ledningsgrupper

Tror styrelser och ledningsgrupper m√•ste utbildas i vad internet √§r, f√∂rl√•t Ai. Ja vissa beh√∂ver du starta med m√∂jligheterna internet ger. F√∂r vissa skolpolitiker s√• beh√∂ver du backa till att en dator kan va bra √• ha (det som kom 1950).

Efter genomg√•ng kan alla i samma ledningsgrupp g√∂ra egen analys i sitt kontext. Exempel:

Hur p√•verkar datorvana (inklusive flugor som internet och Ai) elevernas m√∂jlighet att f√• jobb? Vad h√§nder om eleverna inte kan datorer n√§r de kommer ut i arbetslivet?

Om v√•ra konkurrenter anv√§nder Ai f√∂r att bli effektivare. Exempel s√• anst√§ller inte Klarna fler och lutar sig √•t vad Ai kan g√∂ra. Liknande tendenser finns hos Amazon, Microsoft, konsultfirmor, advokatbyr√•er i US. Vad h√§nder f√∂r v√•r egna konkurrensm√∂jlighet om vi st√•r och tittar p√•? Hinner vi st√§lla om? Kan vi idag nyfiket explorativt b√∂rja titta och starta idag f√∂r att skapa oss f√∂rst√•else?

Om politiker anv√§nder Ai f√∂r att skriva svar p√• f√∂rslag utan egen √∂vertygelse hur p√•verkar det d√• demokrati? En mycket djupare fr√•ga d√§r resultatet inte n√∂dv√§ndigtvis beh√∂ver bli s√§mre. Men styr d√• Ai v√§rlden inklusive besluten? √Ñr du konspirationsteoretiker s√• √§r steget inte l√•ngt, √∂vriga som inte f√∂rstod det sista har mycket att l√§ra vart vi √§r p√• v√§g.

M√•nga tror att man kan styra och kanske bromsa utvecklingen. Kalle Eriksson, Ume√• Universitet g√∂r ett viktigt p√•st√•ende i sin avhandling ‚ÄùPolitisering av automatisering‚Äù 

> Att inte f√∂ra ett s√•dant samtal vore faktiskt djupt odemokratiskt med tanke p√• vilken central roll tekniken kommit att spela f√∂r samh√§llets √∂vergripande organisering.
> 

Tolkar det s√•h√§r:

Stadiet √§r samtal. Inte beslut om sk√§rm skolan.

Stadiet √§r f√∂rst√•. Inte f√∂rbjuda f√∂r att skydda arbetstillf√§llen.

Stadiet √§r skapa hypoteser. Inte regulera.

Dessa p√•st√•ende utmanas p√• veckobasis d√• teknikutvecklingen g√•r fort och n√§r v√•r f√∂rst√•else g√•r fr√•n 0‚Üí1 s√• omv√§rderas ovanst√•ende.

Spelar det h√§r n√•gon som helst roll? Min √∂vertygelse √§r att det g√∂r det p√• ett grundl√§ggande s√§tt som f√• har f√∂rst√•tt.

Linneuniversitet har en utbildning som riktar sig delvis till denna m√•lgrupp.

> Syftet med kursen ‚ÄùArtificiell intelligens f√∂r Ledare‚Äù √§r att ge chefer, ledare och beslutsfattare en djupare f√∂rst√•else f√∂r AI och √∂ka f√∂rst√•elsen f√∂r m√∂jligheter, sv√•righeter, nytta och risker kopplat till AI.
> 

Dock hade jag velat sett en utbildning som √§r mer kopplat till framtida utmaningar och hur en strategi i att nyttja Ai √§r en del av l√∂sningen. Strategiarbete helt enkelt.

Vi √§r i stort behov av b√•de en strategi och plan f√∂r hur vi ska se p√• teknikutveckling och just nu Ai i synnerhet.

Det f√∂rsta vi gemensamt beh√∂ver g√∂ra √§r att komma till f√∂rst√•else och egna insikter. Vi √§r √§n s√• l√§nge mycket l√•ngt ifr√•n det s√• just nu svamlar de flesta.

De som vet ser att kejsaren har inga kl√§der.

Ps. Jobbar med Ai som verktyg dagligen ur ett arkitektoriskt, styrningsperspektiv och f√∂rs√∂ker f√∂rst√• hur Ai kan √§n mer hj√§lpa oss se samband i data som vi sj√§lva √§r chansl√∂sa att g√∂ra.

Hemma har mina tre barn tillg√•ng till Chat GPT och vi pratar och leker r√§tt mycket med det.

Min son √§r autistiskt med grav dyselexi och l√§sa √§r inte s√§ttet han l√§r sig. Det √§r uppl√§sning och dialog med Chat GPT, YouTube videos samt summeringar med referenser i Perpexity. Har har n√§stan fotografiskt minne s√• de √§mnen har g√∂r kunskapsprov utan krav p√• att formulera meningar och skriva med penna (√§ven finmotoriskt problem) s√• √§r det n√§stan alla r√§tt. Vi har dock lite problem med sl√∂jd d√§r l√§raren v√§grar att sl√§ppa det skriftliga dokumenteringskravet. Hantverket? Mycket bra.

Perioden nu f√∂r mina barn √§r liknande den som n√§r min pappa drog hem en Apple Dator hem i mitten av 1980 talet som lite ersatte min Comondore 64.

title: Toyota training peogram
ai_summary: Toyota has a dual-pattern training program for both administrative and technical staff, emphasizing continuous development known as "On the Job Development (OJD)." This approach is crucial for sustainability and applies to all employees, not just technical roles, highlighting the historical significance of Toyota's training methods.
body:
Executive Coach | Board Advisor | Interim Executive | Co-Creator of The Flow System | Creator of Scrum The Toyota Way | Forbes Noted Author | Who‚Äôs Who Listee | Toyota Alumni | Renowned Speaker

Toyota Training Program circa 1969. "Toyota Motor has a dual-pattern training program for administrative and technical staff, which was designed by Toyota to meet the company's specific needs." Spotify method pundits take note; you did not invent squads. Continuous development thought the organization is key to sustainability. This is ongoing, what Toyota calls "On the Job Development (OJD)", and it covers not just technical staff, but all staff including admin roles. From a rare and historical text published by the Asian Productivity Organization. Thanks to my friend [Charlie Protzman](https://www.linkedin.com/in/charlie-protzman-0149519?trk=public_post-text) for finding this. title: How Do McKinsey Do It?
ai_summary: McKinsey-presentationer k√§nnetecknas av klarhet, struktur och ber√§ttande. Varje slide har en slutsats, rubriker uttrycker huvudbudskapet, och pyramidprincipen anv√§nds f√∂r logisk struktur. Presentationerna √§r evidensbaserade, med tydliga diagram och en konsekvent informationshierarki. Designen √§r diskret och fokuserar p√• aff√§rsv√§rde, vilket leder till beslut och rekommendationer.
body:
[McKinsey - Julia.pdf](How%20Do%20McKinsey%20Do%20It/McKinsey_-_Julia.pdf)

[McKinsey - prez rules.pdf](How%20Do%20McKinsey%20Do%20It/McKinsey_-_prez_rules.pdf)

[McKinsey Example.pdf](How%20Do%20McKinsey%20Do%20It/McKinsey_Example.pdf)

[McKinsey presentation.pdf](How%20Do%20McKinsey%20Do%20It/McKinsey_presentation.pdf)

[The_400k_Presentation_Framework_1691186276.pdf](How%20Do%20McKinsey%20Do%20It/The_400k_Presentation_Framework_1691186276.pdf)

Se √§ven projekt i ChatGPT.

McKinseys s√§tt att presentera handlar i grunden om **klarhet, struktur och ber√§ttande med precision**. De utg√•r alltid fr√•n ett tydligt syfte ‚Äî att driva beslut ‚Äî och varje sida i en presentation fungerar som ett eget mikrokapitel i ber√§ttelsen. Det som g√∂r McKinsey-formatet s√• effektivt √§r att det kombinerar analytisk stringens med visuellt lugn: inga on√∂diga effekter, inga l√∂sa tankar, bara den logiska v√§gen till insikt och handling.

K√§rnan √§r **‚ÄùPyramidprincipen‚Äù** (Barbara Minto): b√∂rja med slutsatsen, f√∂rklara huvudargumenten och st√∂d dem med fakta. Resultatet blir en presentation som talar direkt till beslutsfattare ‚Äì snabbt, tydligt och med tyngd.

---

### **üîü saker som g√∂r McKinsey-presentationer unika**

1. **En slutsats per sida** ‚Äì varje slide har ett tydligt huvudbudskap, inte en lista av punkter.
2. **Rubriker med mening** ‚Äì rubrikerna √§r fullst√§ndiga meningar som uttrycker slutsatsen, inte bara √§mnet.
3. **Pyramidprincipen** ‚Äì logisk struktur fr√•n huvudpo√§ng till underbyggda argument och evidens.
4. **Evidensstyrd kommunikation** ‚Äì alla p√•st√•enden backas upp med data, k√§llor eller exempel.
5. **Tydliga och enkla diagram** ‚Äì visualiseringar anv√§nds f√∂r att f√∂rtydliga, inte f√∂r att imponera.
6. **Konsekvent informationshierarki** ‚Äì l√§saren leds fr√•n helhet till detalj utan f√∂rvirring.
7. **Inga on√∂diga element** ‚Äì all ‚Äúchart junk‚Äù tas bort; endast det som st√∂djer budskapet f√•r finnas kvar.
8. **Diskret design** ‚Äì lugna f√§rger, tydliga kontraster, konsekvent typografi. Inneh√•llet b√§r presentationen.
9. **Klar koppling till aff√§rsv√§rde** ‚Äì varje insikt leder mot ett beslut, en rekommendation eller en f√∂r√§ndring.
10. **Ber√§ttande logik** ‚Äì presentationen k√§nns som en v√§lskriven ber√§ttelse: situation ‚Üí problem ‚Üí analys ‚Üí rekommendation ‚Üí resultat .

title: If your analytics only shows numbers, you are doing it wrong
ai_summary: Analytics should drive decision-making; if data does not facilitate decisions, it indicates a problem. Key questions to consider include trust in the data, ability to make decisions based on it, and transparency in executing those decisions. Modern tools like Airtable can help bridge the gap between data and actionable insights, emphasizing that viewing data is only the first step in a decision-making workflow.
body:
[[Airtable]][[Analytics]]

![[Pasted image 20241121195205.png]]
If Your Analytics Only Shows Numbers, You‚Äôre Doing It Wrong.
(This is where most teams fall short.)
Analytics should lead to decisions. If your data isn‚Äôt driving action, you have a bigger problem to solve first.
Here‚Äôs how to think about it:
1. Can I trust the data?

2. Can I make a decision based on this data?

3. Is it easy to execute the decision transparently?
If you answered ‚Äúno‚Äù to any of these, you don‚Äôt have a decision-making workflow - you have numbers on a screen.
The solution? Modern tools like Airtable make it possible to bridge this gap.

But here‚Äôs the key:
Viewing the data is only step one.

The real value is in using that data to drive transparent, actionable decisions.
Where do you see the biggest bottlenecks in analytics workflows?

**If You Can‚Äôt Make Decisions on Your Numbers, You‚Äôre Doing It Wrong**

Analytics should lead to decisions. If your data isn‚Äôt helping you make decisions, that‚Äôs a problem you need to fix first.

I prefer when there‚Äôs a clear workflow that connects insights directly to decision-making. Here are a few things to consider:

1. **Can I trust the data?**
2. **Can I make a decision based on this data?**
3. **Is it easy to execute the decision transparently, showing which data supports it?**

If you answer ‚Äúno‚Äù to any of these questions, you have analytics but not a workflow that drives a real, data-based decision.

Bridging this gap is possible with modern tools like Airtable. However, it‚Äôs crucial to remember that viewing the data is just a fraction of the workflow. The real value lies in using that data to drive transparent, actionable decisions.

‚Äî org
If your analytics only shows numbers, you are doing it wrong
Analytics is a path towards a decision. And if you can‚Äôt make the decision based on the data, you need to fix that first.
I like when there is clear Workflow when the insights from analysis is a part towards the descision.
So there would be a few things you need to concider:
1. Can I trust the data?
2. Can I take descision on this data?
3. Is it hard to execute so that the desicion is transparent and on what data it is based?
If you answer no on any of these questions I would say you have anaytics. But you dont have a workflow that really drives a data-bases descision.
It is nowdays possible with tools like Airtable to get there. But we need to acknowledge that viewing the data is just a fraction of the workflow.

body:

Why Building a Visual Product Portfolio and creating shared innovation practices is essential for Adaptive Organizations
Use different maps to create a full strategic context.
1. Arena (Enterprise Map based on Capabilities)
2. Product Portfolio map

A lot of it is about visualising instead of talking: that speeds things up.
The only thing we agree on is: Is this the way we all see this today? Yes, that‚Äôs fine. No, is it honest? Yes, that‚Äôs the best we can do.
So instead of talking, we can use a map and agree on whether it is the current status or our current misunderstanding.

title: What Is Jobs-to-be-Done-
ai_summary: A job-to-be-done is a precise statement describing what people aim to achieve in a specific situation, including tasks, goals, or problems to resolve, typically structured as [verb] + [object] + [contextual clarifier].
body:
## Metadata
* URL: [https://jobs-to-be-done.com/what-is-jobs-to-be-done-fea59c8e39eb](https://jobs-to-be-done.com/what-is-jobs-to-be-done-fea59c8e39eb)
* Author: Tony Ulwick
* Publisher: jobs-to-be-done.com
* Published Date: 2020-11-10
* Tags:

## Highlights

- A JOB-TO-BE-DONE is a statement that describes, with precision, what a group of people are trying to achieve or accomplish in a given situation. A job-to-be-done could be a task that people are trying to accomplish, a goal or objective they are trying to achieve, a problem they are trying to resolve, something they are trying to avoid, or anything else they are trying to accomplish. A job statement is written as [verb] + [object of the verb] + [contextual clarifier] (optionally). For example, pass on life lessons to children, repair a torn rotator cuff and prevent a shooter from entering a school, are all jobs-to-be-done.

title: Value is set by the customer
ai_summary: Value is determined by those who choose to pay it, not by those who set the price. Reference link provided for further reading on customer value.
body:
Value is not determined by those who set the price. Value is determined by those who choose to pay it.

title: A well-researched system of how to communicate change in an organisation
ai_summary: Effective communication in organizations requires a return to basics: ensure understanding, address communication problems, and use clear language. Focus on intent to understand and engage in meaningful dialogue.
body:
- [ ] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)
- [ ]
A well-researched system of how to communicate change in an organisation.

With all the new tools we built, you would assume that communication problems would be a thing of the past.

No! If anything, it has become worse.

But there is a way forward, a solution.

I spent the last years trying to understand what I was doing.

Yes. Fundamentally.

Let‚Äôs say that I‚Äôm a former Enterprise Information Architect and project manager slowly recovering from the last 10+ years.

My conclusion.

It is time to get back to basics. In the time of AI, I call it the most powerful model we humans have ever invented. It is the:

Natural Language Language, NLLs.

Communicate with the intent to understand each other!

Communication is only done once you know that the receiver has understood.

Five points to start with:

- Go back to basic ways of talking
- Make sure the other person gets it
- Talk about communication problems
- Use words like what, why, who, when
- Aim to understand and be understood

Have you been lost in communication?

Drop your story in the comments, and let‚Äôs decode it with a smile :-)

title: I don't think business agility is the problem organizations face anymore
ai_summary: The main issue organizations face is messy prioritization and lack of focus, rather than business agility. It's crucial to determine the importance of initiatives and projects, ensuring they have management support and resources before investing time or money.
author: Thomas Larsson
body:
I don't think business agility is the problem organizations face anymore

I think it is the messy prioritization and lack of focus. We don't need to do more ways of trying to force agility and have management add even more shit-projects-as-a-distraction. SPAAD. We need to do better. And it all starts with figuring out what the f*** we are doing.

Chief bullshit Detector

As Warren Buffet used to say. You only have 10 bets in your card for the rest of your life. Spend them wisely. 

Is your CEO going to talk about this initiative or project? Is it going to have a management focus? Who is really sponsoring it? Resources?

If not. It's unimportant, so don't invest time or money.

title: Future US
ai_summary: Carl Sagan warns of a future America where superstition and pseudoscience undermine reason and rationality, leading to a decline in critical thinking. He envisions a society where technological power is concentrated, the public cannot grasp important issues, and media content deteriorates, resulting in a celebration of ignorance and a loss of the ability to question authority.
author: Carl Sagan
body:
In his 1995 book¬†[*The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark*](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/159731/the-demon-haunted-world-by-carl-sagan/), Sagan explained how the scientific method helped to illuminate many of the universe‚Äôs gloomiest corners. However, he argued that the pursuit of peace and truth was being undermined by humankind‚Äôs old friends: superstition and pseudoscience.

Within a passage of the text that frequently goes viral, Sagan set out his pessimistic vision of where the US will go if it loses its admiration for reason, rationality, and open-minded thinking.

It reads: ‚ÄúI have a foreboding of an America in my children‚Äôs or grandchildren‚Äôs time‚Äîwhen the United States is a service and information economy; when nearly all the key manufacturing industries have slipped away to other countries; when awesome technological powers are in the hands of a very few, and no one representing the public interest can even grasp the issues; when the people have lost the ability to set their own agendas or knowledgeably question those in authority; when, clutching our crystals and nervously consulting our horoscopes, our critical faculties in decline, unable to distinguish between what feels good and what‚Äôs true, we slide, almost without noticing, back into superstition and darkness.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd when the dumbing down of America is most evident in the slow decay of substantive content in the enormously influential media, the 30-second sound bites now down to 10 seconds or less, lowest-common-denominator programming, credulous presentations on pseudoscience and superstition, but especially a kind of celebration of ignorance.‚Äù

title: Be intentional with your communication
ai_summary: Communicate intentionally by attending meetings with clear agendas, decluttering emails by questioning necessity, and using chat effectively. Regularly evaluate your communication practices to improve quality and efficiency.
body:
[[Knapp-Zeratsky-Make Time]]
![[Pasted image 20241007103044.png]]
![[Pasted image 20241007220701.png]]
To Whom it May Concern:
Are you communicating intentionally?

Was communication more intentional and efficient in the past? I think so, and one reason is that it required some effort.
A problem today is that we get help producing massive amounts of poor-quality information and sending it to too many people. We also have the ‚Äúluxury‚Äù of inviting a big meeting in teams just because I don‚Äôt have the time to write an easy-to-understand email.
Ai is making this worse.
If we set up some rules, we could cut 50% of our meeting times and 80% of what gets into our mailbox.
So, my 2 cents for a more uncluttered work-life and getting back to producing more quality stuff.

Only attend meetings where:
- There is a clear agenda and desired outcome.
- The meeting booker has summarised the background.
- You have a clear role in how to contribute intentionally.

Declutter email:
* Most important! Newer reply all.
- Ask yourself, ‚ÄúShould I send this?‚Äù
- Do all people need to be involved?
- What am I trying to say intentionally?

Chat:
- Restrict channels and discussions.
- Is this channel a good way for my intentions?
- There must be rules on when to use and when to not.
- Try to remove email as a channel if you want to use chat.

If you use AI, ask it to summarise and strengthen your point, and learn when it suggests something that is an improvement.
From time to time, evaluate whether you communicate intentionally. Start by looking at the email and chat sent last week.
So my question is, have you communicated intentionally?

title: A lot of car companies are soon going out of business
ai_summary: Many car companies face imminent failure due to outdated management practices and reliance on rigid planning. The shift towards electric vehicles and rapid technological changes necessitates a more agile approach, including empowering decision-makers, owning supply chains, and reducing overengineering. Companies must adapt quickly to survive against competitors, particularly from China, which has a more integrated and flexible manufacturing ecosystem.
author: Thomas Larsson
body:
A lot of car companies are soon going out of business

For a long time a Car manufacture had an advantage on the experiences on how to create cars when a new model should be invented. But now I see a big shift that the old structures are in the way. Just the notion that everything could be planned ahead when you create new EV-battieries, motors and the software, internetconnection and interaction changes in months not decades.

Old organisations leans towards to have rigid plan, because that is how it always have been done.

So where does this leave us. As Ford CEO Jim Farley says in this interview. We need to proof that we can create proftible cars within 5 years. And today everything that has to do with a battery in a EV is made in China. And also invention of next gen battery is a Chineese invention and their IP.

Besides that everything Ford and Volkswagen is putting into a car is often created by others such as Bosch, Panasonic and 100 of other vendors. Ford can‚Äôt change that software.

In China they change whatever they want, they produce it themself whithin a eco-network of business called China. Yeaph that is seen as ONE mission.

What is the response?

Not one thing.

First is to remove every old thinking of management and start putting the doers into descision-making spots. What could be the risk of doing this? Well I see two outcome. Either you succed to respond and survive. Or you don‚Äôt. With today thinking there is only one outcome.

The second is to start owning your own supply chain. Either as a own company, see Tesla, or as a colongromat of Car Manufactors. Batteries can be created in other places. A lot of bets need to be made, but do it together, remember your competitor is whole China, not one Chinese car manufacture.

The third part is to self-sabotage your capability to do things. Don‚Äôt overthink everything. Test and do. Learn and redo. Germans problems isn‚Äôt engenering. It is overengenering management and relly on SAP. Everything that isn‚Äôt done by SAP is done in a PowerPoint and 100 of Excels to for every aspect of the organisation. It is inefficent, proon to errors, and gives almost 0 trust to a quick descision and gives paralyzes in the organisations.

But what do I know?

I‚Äôm often just there to extingue a fire and very seldon anyone taking full responsibilty of the situation. I know management dosen‚Äôt.

Often called leadership.

I ditt k√∂k kanske felet bara g√∂r grytan f√∂r salt, men m√∂nstret √§r likadant: avvikelser som f√•ngas f√∂r sent, kostar.

Genom att se hela kedjan av steg innan n√•got h√§nder skapar du m√∂jlighet att vara proaktiv. Du samlar krav, granskar arbetss√§ttet och f√•ngar avvikelser tidigt. Varje kontrollpunkt √§r ett skyddsn√§t som hindrar sm√• problem fr√•n att bli dyra incidenter.

Hur t√§nker man i system och vad skulle en definition kunna vara? Nedan, f√∂renklat fr√•n Wikipedia.

> Systemt√§nkande √§r ett s√§tt att f√∂rst√• komplexa problem genom att se hur delar h√§nger ihop, ist√§llet f√∂r att bara titta p√• varje del f√∂r sig. Det hj√§lper oss att hitta b√§ttre l√∂sningar genom att f√∂rst√• helheten.
> 

Mitt f√∂rslag √§r att du b√∂rja h√§r:

1. Lista fem moment som inte f√•r fallera och beskriv rutinen f√∂r arbetet.
2. L√§gg till ett tydligt kontrollsteg f√∂r varje rutin: checklista, logg eller test.
3. N√§r n√•got brister: g√∂r en kort analys, √•tg√§rda orsaken direkt och justera rutinen f√∂r att f√•nga problemen i f√∂rv√§g.

Saker vi hittar kallas ibland f√∂r incidenter, problem eller findings.

Skillnaden √§r ofta att vi hittar och r√§ttar till saker n√§r det h√§nder (Ad-Hoc). N√§r vi jobbar systematiskt s√• funderar vi f√∂rst varf√∂r det h√§nder. Sedan hur kunde vi uppt√§cka det i f√∂rv√§g och f√∂rhindra att det uppst√•r n√§sta g√•ng. 

Ibland √§r det inte viktigt. 

H√§rdsm√§lta k√§rnkraft, viktigt. 

Om maten hemma blir f√∂r salt hemma s√• inte lika viktigt.

Resultatet √§r f√§rre akuta r√§ddningsinsatser och mer f√∂ruts√§gbar drift.

Du v√§ljer kontrollen nu, innan n√§sta incident v√§ljer √•t dig.

title: And then want
ai_summary: Effective change management requires addressing personal priorities and answering key questions: what happens next, how will it work, and why will the system respond positively to the proposed changes?
body:
Arguments for a change can be explained in three steps.
Why are we doing this?
* What‚Äôs in it for me? Why should I care?
And then what?
- What would the effect be if we do this thing? And the effect for me?
How will it work?
- What do I need to do? Will it be better, for me?
The priority for making sustainable change is to address people‚Äôs three top priorities.
Me, I and Myself.

If you‚Äôre actually proposing something thoughtful and practical, perhaps you could answer three questions:
* And then what happens? After we take this action, after you shut down that agency, eliminate that division or launch this new project, what will happen after that?
* How will that work? What are the mechanics involved, the ones that don‚Äôt suspend the laws of physics or organizational behavior that will support this new way forward?
* Why? Can you explain, beyond your reality-suspending confidence, why the system will respond to your approach? It‚Äôs entirely possible that this is precisely the change we need and the change that will work. But when the pronouncer refuses to answer the questions, it should give the rest of us pause.

It translates high-level strategy into actionable steps, ensuring alignment across the organization, and is crucial for efficient resource allocation, consistent customer experience, adaptability, scalability, and clear governance.
