title: Why SAFe¬Æ, Flight Levels¬Æ, and Theory of Constraints Show Three Layers - And What It Means for Your Success?
ai_summary: Agile frameworks like SAFe¬Æ, Flight Levels¬Æ, and Theory of Constraints feature three layers: Portfolio, Coordination, and Team, each serving distinct roles in managing complexity. The Portfolio layer aligns projects with strategic goals, the Coordination layer manages dependencies, and the Team layer focuses on daily tasks. Effective frameworks recognize these layers and apply appropriate methods tailored to their characteristics, avoiding a one-size-fits-all approach. The Theory of Constraints adapts techniques for each layer, leading to more efficient management and smoother delivery.
body:
[](https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/D4E12AQFZYgRSVIgJ4g/article-cover_image-shrink_720_1280/B4EZa_NGqVHIAI-/0/1746964606278?e=2147483647&v=beta&t=RLd9lrhBxkwNcdhwTbw51HwCejibfzlqscsllrabgM8)

SAFe¬Æ, Flight Levels¬Æ/Kanban and Theory of Constraints - all show the same three layers - WHY?

### Wolfram M√ºller

### Founder of the open DolphinUniverse community, helping organizations worldwide leverage expertise to build highly agile, productive teams, resulting in Fun & Flow‚Äîour goal: making this knowledge accessible to all.

Published May 11, 2025

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Fwhy-safe-flight-levels-theory-constraints-show-three-layers-m%25C3%25BCller-tyy7e%3Futm_source%3Dshare%26utm_medium%3Dmember_ios%26utm_campaign%3Dshare_via&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

Wolfram M√ºller - 2023-07-26 (remastered 2025-05-11) - CC-BY-SA

When scaling agile or managing projects, frameworks frequently feature a common tri-layered structure. These layers - portfolio, coordination, and team - organize the complexity from strategic initiatives down to daily tasks.

But why these specific layers? Let's explore their unique roles and how recognizing their characteristics can help determine if your chosen framework is truly effective or fundamentally flawed.

## The Three Layers: What Each Layer Does

Every scaled knowledge work management framework includes these three layers:

1. Portfolio Layer (top): Aligns projects and initiatives with your strategic goals, identifies constraints, prioritizes the projects, and ensures resources are optimally allocated to high-value projects.

2. Coordination Layer (middle): Manages dependencies between projects or teams to keep deliveries synchronized and on track.

3. Team Layer (bottom): Handles day-to-day tasks, ensuring smooth workflows and effective delivery of smaller work items or stories.

Interestingly, these layers alternate between "production/process" and "project" characteristics. The Portfolio and Team layers are more production-oriented, whereas the Coordination layer is project-focused. Why this distinction?

## Projects vs. Production: Two Types of Work in Organizations

Organizations have two fundamental types of work:

- Projects (initiatives, missions): work packages with fixed sequences, strong dependencies, and high complexity and uncertainty ‚Äì further on the touch time (on the longest chain) should be very near to the lead time. But therefore, higher complexity in management.
- Production (processes, value streams): Small, interchangeable tasks with flexible sequences ‚Äì requires a backlog and leads to longer waiting times and lower touch times. But therefore, it is simpler to manage.

At the Team layer, production is clearly visible - you see it in agile practices like Scrum (similar to the ‚Äúboxes/space WIP limits‚Äù at the Ford‚Äôs assembly line) or Kanban (like Toyota‚Äôs just-in-time system). Similarly, the Portfolio layer also operates like production, managing multiple projects or initiatives with flexible sequences.

The Coordination layer, however, behaves like projects, due to its role in managing dependencies. Here, effective methods include Critical Chain Project Management (CCPM) are used.

Understanding this distinction is critical - it helps you choose the right management tools for each layer.

### A Deeper Insight: Fractal Patterns in Layers

Looking even deeper, this pattern repeats itself at other scales:

- Below the Team layer, managing subtasks within a story or task involves again fixed dependencies ‚Äì you have to think first how to do it, then do it, then quality check, then hand over to the next or delivery (very simple but project characteristics).
- Above the Portfolio layer, coordinating between different programs (often between companies) or large initiatives again exhibits project-like characteristics.

This creates a repeating, fractal-like pattern, alternating production and project characteristics throughout the organizational structure.

## The Evolution of Workflow Controls

Over time, the workflow controls fortunately underwent some progress ‚Äì here is a very rough overview of the current state of development:

[](https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/D4E12AQHav8SOI3luSA/article-inline_image-shrink_400_744/B4EZa_OdYTHwAY-/0/1746964961597?e=2147483647&v=beta&t=TD-QHLd-Oq20rwkORWgFTmbGYpeMT28KvHcce9oXlFA)

Article content

With each generation, flexibility increases, and the amount of work-in-progress necessary to keep a steady flow is reduced. So with every generation, the lead time decreases and the throughput increases.

## Tools and Methods from Theory of Constraints

Besides well-known agile methods like Scrum and Kanban, TOC offers multiple elements tailored to different scenarios:

- Drum Buffer Rope (DBR) ‚Äì production with a real constraint
- Critical Chain Project Management (CCPM) ‚Äì high-speed and high-reliability projects and portfolios
- Reliable Scrum ‚Äì high-reliable agile deliveries
- Simplified Drum-Buffer-Rope (sDBR) ‚Äì very flexible production, like queue management
- agile Critical Chain Project Management (aCCPM) ‚Äì a combination of Critical Chain for portfolio and projects, and agile on the team level
- TameFlow Boards (aka Ultimate Scrum) ‚Äì minimal WIP swim lane boards = optimal flow in agile teams

The full overview of all building blocks can be found here in "[The TOC Lego Brick Article](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/build-your-own-high-performance-framework-theory-lego-m%25C3%25BCller/?trackingId=rQ5eQjsvQJeOfWt3J31Miw%3D%3D&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block)."

## Evaluating Frameworks: Is Your Choice Effective?

Now, with this understanding, you can easily evaluate your framework's effectiveness.

There are two dimensions:

- Does the framework recognize the different layers and provide appropriate methods?
- Are the methods provided efficient and of new generations?

Take SAFe¬Æ and Flight Levels¬Æ/Kanban, for example:

- Both use similar/same methods (Scrum and Kanban) at all three layers, ignoring each layer‚Äôs unique needs. This "one-size-fits-all" approach can be inefficient, like using a hammer to drive in a screw. It works, but takes extra effort, especially at the Coordination layer, where managing dependencies requires precise control.
- SAFe¬Æ uses mainly first generation methods and compensates with cadences, a lot synchronization meetings and may new roles. Most probably not efficient.

So, a good framework recognizes the three different layers and uses different appropriate control mechanisms of the best available generation.

## Comparison: How SAFe¬Æ, Flight Levels¬Æ, and the Theory of Constraints Stack

SAFe¬Æ and Flight Levels¬Æ apply uniform management methods across layers, which might not match the distinct characteristics required at each layer.

In contrast, the Theory of Constraints (TOC) adapts to each layer:

- Portfolio & Team Layers (Production): Uses Drum-Buffer-Rope (DBR) techniques.
- Coordination Layer (Project): Applies Critical Chain Project Management (CCPM).

The following table gives an overview, especially for project organizations:

[](https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/v2/D4E12AQE5nZtpwwymuQ/article-inline_image-shrink_400_744/B4EZa_O1r9HYAY-/0/1746965061497?e=2147483647&v=beta&t=evN0EWpzZqH1KjLvP2K7cOkXMA_ncqxlvrWYwg4nBOk)

Article content

Attention: Some organizations do not have projects! These organizations have dedicated self-containing product lines with one product. Their goal is to deliver as fast as possible as cheap as possible and continuously improve in small steps. In this case the three-layer structure does not emerge.

These full product organizations are very rare and will get more rare in future because our systems get more complex over time and more collaboration company over spanning will be seen.

## Conclusion: Choosing the Right Framework Matters

A truly effective agile or project management framework must respect the unique characteristics of each layer, applying appropriate methods of the newest generation to manage complexity efficiently.

Unfortunately, most current frameworks fail this test because they use the same method across all layers.

In contrast, the Theory of Constraints understands and utilizes the alternating fractal patterns of production and projects, applying suitable tools at every layer. The result is less management overhead and smoother, more effective delivery.

Now, consider your own organization. Is your current framework working effectively, or could embracing these insights improve your outcomes?

If you would like to learn practical implementation techniques, you can visit the DolphinUniverse community.

Join the free DolphinUniverse to [stay ahead of the curve and learn more about 3rd-generation flow methods](https://dolphinuniverse.circle.so/join?invitation_token=466103edae2de06a1a0ef5b53c0f3151e4ff842f-6b1cce1f-0c6a-41e0-9fa0-61af2653dea9&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block)!

P.P.S. Generation 1 and 2 on all layer approaches are less complex and easier to sell because they seem simpler to implement. This advantage is often used by organizations to productize an approach and scale selling protected by unclear intellectual property claims ‚Äì you easily recognize this by the ¬Æ after the product name.

title: The two most important things you can do to get better data in your organisation
ai_summary: To improve data quality, stop using Excel, which is often the source of bad data, and consider switching to user-friendly no-code databases like Airtable or Baserow for better management. Finding the right tool for specific needs is essential.
body:
- [x] Due üóìÔ∏è(@)
![[Untitled 33.png|Untitled 33.png]]

1. Stop using Excel.
2. Redo 1.

In almost all organisations around the globe, there is one single point of source for bad-quality data.

Microsoft Excel.

The reason is that it is flexible and easy to create = cheap.

But when the happiness of the quick and dirty solution is over, the struggle begins.

So, where have I found Excel as the Master data in use in large organisations?

1. Users
2. Budget
3. Bonuses
4. Contracts
5. As log files
6. ISO Processes
7. Application lists
8. Incident reporting
9. Compliance tracking
10. Financial Bookkeeping

However, there is always a solution for most of our self-inflected wounds. In this case, I would highly suggest using an easy-to-use no-code database such as Airtable (SaaS) or Baserow (onPreem) instead.

However, the best way is probably to find the right tool for the specific solution.

E.g. budget tools actually exist :-)

Do you avoid Excel when managing your data?

title: It All Started with My Son‚Ä¶
ai_summary: A comment from the author's son inspired the creation of a book, which evolved into a podcast using AI technology. The author expresses surprise at the effectiveness of AI in shaping ideas and invites others to share their creative experiences with AI.
body:
**It All Started with My Son‚Ä¶**

A simple comment from my son, Eskil, sparked an idea. That idea became a book. And now? It‚Äôs a ‚Äúpodcast‚Äù, created with Google‚Äôs Notebook LM.

I wanted to see what‚Äôs possible, and the result surprised me: a 9-minute episode that actually *works*. AI isn‚Äôt just a tool; it‚Äôs a way to explore and shape ideas in ways we (or at least I) couldn‚Äôt before.

From a conversation with Eskil to a book to a podcast, who knows what‚Äôs next? Have you ever used AI to bring an idea to life? Please share some good creative moments.

title: Do you meet resistance in your change initiative Five insights to work with!
ai_summary: Motverka motst√•nd i f√∂r√§ndringsinitiativ genom att skapa gemensamma m√•l, tydlig kommunikation fr√•n ledningen, r√§tt resurser och incitament, samt f√∂rst√• att f√∂r√§ndring handlar mer om m√§nniskor √§n processer. L√•t teamet ta ansvar f√∂r hur f√∂r√§ndringen genomf√∂rs.
body:
![[Pasted image 20241015204602.png]]
Do you face resistance ‚úä in your change initiative? Let me share five that might be the reason.
Now, I could just tell you that ‚Äúchange is hard,‚Äù ‚Äústay patient,‚Äù and all that usual stuff‚Ä¶ But we both know it‚Äôs about creating the right conditions.

Create a shared goal

‚Ü≥ Get your team to understand the common objectives. When everyone understands ‚Äúwhy‚Äù we need to do ‚Äúwhat‚Äù, they will be engaged.

Allocate the right resources and time

‚Ü≥ Don‚Äôt expect change without the right support. Resources and time are critical.

Leadership must communicate clearly

‚Ü≥ If leadership doesn‚Äôt explain ‚Äúwhy‚Äù this change is happening, confusion will spread.

Set up correct KPI:s and incentives

‚Ü≥ A common mistake! Current incentives might be contra-productive to the goals. Get this right!

Remember: Change is 10% process and 90% people
‚Ü≥ You can change the processes, but can‚Äôt change people.

As a leader, focus on setting the vision, allocating resources, and getting the right incentives. Let your team own ‚Äúhow‚Äù to make it happen.

---

This version removes all bolding, uses arrows and emojis, and maintains a clear, engaging flow suitable for LinkedIn.

1. Skapa **ett** **gemensamt m√•l** att samlas runt.
2. Ledningen m√•ste vara tydlig **varf√∂r** vi g√∂r f√∂r√§ndringen.

4. Ekonomistyrning och **incitament** m√•ste st√∂tta f√∂r√§ndringen.
5. F√∂r√§ndring √§r 90% m√§nniskor, 10% teknik och vi kan bara **kontrollera** tekniken.

Gl√∂m inte att ledningens arbete handlar om att kommunicera det gemensamma m√•let och f√∂rklara varf√∂r. Hur det ska genomf√∂ras vill du l√•ta dina medarbetare ta ansvar f√∂r.

Vad √§r det viktigaste enligt dig n√§r det kommer till att skapa r√§tt f√∂ruts√§ttningar till en f√∂r√§ndring?

body:

Here's how I ghostwrite engaging content in minutes:

LinkedIn ghostwriting is a demanding job.

You need to:

Come up with content ideas.

Research the niche you write for.

Study the client's character u write for.

Not only that, the content needs to drive social proof, leads, and revenue, or you'll lose the client.

It's a tough job.

But AI helps me do my job faster.

AI tools save me so much time as a ghostwriter.

I use AI to get content ideas.

I use AI to write content.

I use AI to research.

A lot of the AI tools & tricks I use can be complex.

But I'm going to show you:

Please make the new post with the thought leadership of Sahil Bloom and the formatting and copywriting skills of LinkedIn ghostwriter (ùëñùëõùë†ùëíùëüùë° ùë§ùëüùëñùë°ùëíùëü ‚Ñéùëíùëüùëí) with a slight influence from (ùëñùëõùë†ùëíùëüùë° ùë§ùëüùëñùë°ùëíùëü ‚Ñéùëíùëüùëí). I want you to make the sentences short and concise and also switch up the formatting so it's enjoyable to read. Please take your time and think about what you write carefully.

Be sure to use no hashtags, and make sure the posts follow this opening format:

A short statement beginning with "How to" and then a number included in sentence 3.

title: Speach / write
body:
- [ ]  Varf√∂r ska jag lyssna eller l√§sa det p√• det h√§r?
- [ ]  F√∂rklara problemet.
- [ ]  Visa p√• en l√∂sning.
- [ ]  Slutsats / summering

|  | **What** |
| --- | --- |
| **Think** | ‚Ä¢ Brainstorm inspiration for the topic
‚Ä¢ Analyze the situation and the audience
‚Ä¢ Narrow the topic
‚Ä¢ Develop a working thesis statement |
| **Investigate** | ‚Ä¢ Locate resources:¬† articles, books and websites
‚Ä¢ Keep research cards or notes with bibliographic citations
‚Ä¢ Frame your thesis statement |
| **Compose** | ‚Ä¢ Identify main points and supporting material
‚Ä¢ Develop a working draft of the outline of the speech body
‚Ä¢ Prepare introduction and conclusion
‚Ä¢ Develop a polished draft of the speech outline
‚Ä¢ Prepare presentation aids |
| **Rehearse** | ‚Ä¢ Prepare necessary speech notes
‚Ä¢ Give the speech aloud
‚Ä¢ Practice with presentation aids
‚Ä¢ Work on vocal and nonverbal delivery
‚Ä¢ Obtain feedback from another person |
| **Revise** | ‚Ä¢ Develop a final speech outline as indicated by practice feedback |

Source: [https://community.macmillanlearning.com/t5/communication-blog/a-five-step-model-for-speech-preparation/ba-p/5229](https://community.macmillanlearning.com/t5/communication-blog/a-five-step-model-for-speech-preparation/ba-p/5229)

Are your LinkedIn posts "transformative" enough?

This is a writing hack I wish everyone knew:

Turn CTA (call to action) into CTV (call to value).

1. A CTA (action) typically covers the 1st step:

‚ÄúSign up for my copywriting newsletter‚Äù

2. A CTV (value) typically covers the end goal:

‚ÄúBecome a better writer in 90 days‚Äù

Action vs. transformation.

This "problem" is most noticeable in the endings or P.S. sections of the posts you see in your feed.

A few more examples:

"Optimize your profile" ‚Üí "Get leads on autopilot"

"Download PDF" ‚Üí "Start your workout plan"

"Repost" ‚Üí "Teach others something new"

(a combo of the above works well too)

In a nutshell...

Don't tell them "how to stop being a beginner".

‚Ü≥ Tell them "how to start being a pro".

#Chase Dimond

![Untitled](Speach%20write/Untitled.png)

WEBINAR: Fokus üéØ¬†p√• kundens framtida problem

Vill du skapa de b√§sta f√∂ruts√§ttningar f√∂r en l√•ngsiktig h√•llbar organisation genom r√§tt fokus?

Det inneh√•ller tre saker:

1. Fokusera p√• vad som √§r viktigast f√∂r kunden: Me, I and myself.
2. Du beh√∂ver f√∂rklara att du f√∂rst√•r kundens riktiga problem.
3. Ber√§tta hur kundens liv blir b√§ttre genom din vision att l√∂sa problemet.

Den h√§r resan vill dina kunder (och medarbetare) vara med p√•.

Det √§r vad mitt kommande webinar handlar om. Skriv ‚Äúrelevant‚Äù nedan üëá¬†s√• f√•r du en l√§nk!

V√§lkommen p√• mitt webinarium som handlar hur du s√§tter fokus üéØ p√• kundens riktiga problem i din vision, ditt syfte och de beslut du beh√∂ver ta, f√∂r att framtidss√§kra din organisation.

Vill du med? Skriv ‚ÄúRelevant‚Äù nedan. Vi h√•ller p√• mellan 0830-0900 den 15 november.

Jag √§r √∂vertygad att du i din roll kommer ta med dig n√•gra anv√§ndbara tips att arbeta vidare. Det blir bland annat:

‚úÖ¬†Att f√∂rst√• varf√∂r s√• m√•nga organisationer, kanske √§ven din egen, fastnar i att l√∂sa fel problem.

‚úÖ¬†Hur du kliver in i rollen som problem√§gare och verkligen f√∂rst√•r kundens underliggande utmaningar och inte ger dig f√∂rr√§n problemet √§r l√∂st.

‚úÖ¬†Vikten av direktkommunikation med kunder, utan antaganden och sluta killgissa.

Har skrivit en bok som heter Relevant d√§r jag samlat de senaste √•rens frustration i att inte fokusera p√• det som egentligen √§r betydelsefullt. Att l√∂sa kundernas riktiga problem.

Vill du med? Skriv ‚ÄúRelevant‚Äù nedan. Om du dessutom taggar en kompis s√• √§r du med i utlottningen av n√•gra b√∂cker.

Formatting your LinkedIn posts matters A LOT.

(so here's my mini-masterclass for you)

How people "read" is how they "understand".

A well-written post = great message

A well-formatted post = great readability

Best of both worlds = great for understanding

That being said...

Let's dive into 5 areas of textual formatting.

1. Listicles

1. Use listicles to explain "steps"

2. Use numbers ‚Üí not bulletpoints

3. Write your lists with one-liners only

4. Don't add any white space to your list

5. Make sure every item in the list is "clear"

6. My magic number for listicles is number 7

7. Try to format the list items by length ‚Üí TRY

2. Listicles with examples

1. Write every item in the list as a two-liner

‚Ü≥ "The second line should be your example"

3. Paragraphs

Never write paragraphs longer than 3 lines.

Try to put short sentences in clusters of 3 too.

If your list is not numbered, keep it under 3 lines too.

4. Hooks

Write every hook as a 1-liner. Always.

Hooks longer than 1 line perform 20% worse.

Hooks with "negative" words perform 30% worse.

(Those are my stats based on my own 500+ posts)

5. Post endings

Keep your summary / closing statement to under 3 lines. Or 1 paragraph (like the one you're reading).

Ideally, write just 1 line.

Look...

Your LinkedIn posts "need" to be read.

Formatting isn't "magic". But it is the "sauce".

Your readability directly impacts your message.

Make it easy to read ‚Üí it'll be easy to understand.

Thanks for coming to my masterclass. ‚úåÔ∏è

Repost if useful ‚ôªÔ∏è

P.S. How much attention do you pay to formatting?

[PAS](Speach%20write/PAS%204219cb49be394884bce77c8af4f38374.md)

[Jasmin Aliƒá p√• LinkedIn: This 1 LinkedIn rule changed everything for me: Everything I share ‚Üí it‚Ä¶ | 1¬†175 kommentarer](Speach%20write/Jasmin%20Ali%C4%87%20p%C3%A5%20LinkedIn%20This%201%20LinkedIn%20rule%20chang%2057cb775faa6745d98a76947eb3c1c99f.md)

[Speaking](Speach%20write/Speaking%20225193dbd6474657bcc1371e7e54f179.md)

I start every post with:

"Dear son,"

and end with:

"Love, Dad"

After I'm done, I just delete those 2 parts.

For you, it could be a friend, mentor, or client.

But you will 100% save time when you're writing.

And you will 100% find the best words every time.

Put yourself "at ease" when you write.

‚Ü≥ Your audience will read with ease too!

Day 1:

Chris Anderson - TED's secret to great public speaking

- Avoid the common pitfalls that trip up most speakers.
- Learn to create connection and understanding with your audience.
- Master tools like curiosity, narration, explanation, and persuasion to convey your idea.

[**https://lnkd.in/dtXWMrgj**](https://lnkd.in/dtXWMrgj?trk=public_post-text)

Day 2:

Joe Kowan - How I Beat Stage Fright

- Embrace and transform stage fright into a powerful speaking performance.
- Learn "The Stage Fright Song" method to win the audience's care and support.
- Connect more authentically with your audience while reducing your anxiety.

[**https://lnkd.in/dWjFAXka**](https://lnkd.in/dWjFAXka?trk=public_post-text)

Day 3:

Bren√© Brown - The Power of Vulnerability

- Vulnerability is a key component for great public speaking.
- Build better trust and authentic connection with your audience.
- Don't fear not being perfect - it's a normal part of the human experience.

[**https://lnkd.in/dZPJN9PT**](https://lnkd.in/dZPJN9PT?trk=public_post-text)

Day 4:

Amy Cuddy - Your Body Language May Shape Who You Are

- Learn the concept of "Power Poses" to increase your self-confidence.
- Adopting such poses leads to positive hormonal changes.
- Come across as confident to your audience even if you don't feel so initially.

[**https://lnkd.in/dN2hqgbu**](https://lnkd.in/dN2hqgbu?trk=public_post-text)

Day 5:

Julian Treasure - How to Speak So That People Want to Listen

- Learn (and avoid) the "Seven Deadly Sins of Speaking".
- Master HAIL ‚Äî Speaking with Honesty, Authenticity, Integrity, and Love.
- Develop your vocal toolbox to make your speech dynamic and engaging.

[**https://lnkd.in/dyM8rWcb**](https://lnkd.in/dyM8rWcb?trk=public_post-text)

Day 6:

Nancy Duarte - The Secret Structure of a Great Talk

- Discover the secret repeated pattern in great speeches anyone can learn.
- Decode the success factors of Martin Luther King Jr. and Steve Jobs' speeches.
- Learn how you can use this simple stucture in your next talk or speech.

[**https://lnkd.in/dpejVSRG**](https://lnkd.in/dpejVSRG?trk=public_post-text)

Day 7:

Andrew Stanton - The Clues to a Great Story

- Understand how Pixar captivates the audience's emotions in their films.
- Every great story uses a secret formula that engages people.
- Watch as your audience becomes active participants in your talk.

[**https://lnkd.in/dErwqRWQ**](https://lnkd.in/dErwqRWQ?trk=public_post-text)

title: PAS
body:
![Untitled](PAS/Untitled.png)

![Untitled](PAS/Untitled%201.png)

[https://beomniscient.com/blog/pas-copywriting/#:~:text=The PAS copywriting framework is,and then offer a solution](https://beomniscient.com/blog/pas-copywriting/#:~:text=The%20PAS%20copywriting%20framework%20is,and%20then%20offer%20a%20solution).

### **1. Problem**

The first step is to identify your reader‚Äôs problem. What pain point are they trying to solve?

This is where you need to do your research so that you fully understand their challenges.

Only then can you craft a message that resonates with them.

For example, let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre selling a new type of toothbrush that‚Äôs designed to remove plaque more effectively than traditional toothbrushes.

Your potential customers might not even know that plaque is a problem.

So part of your job is to educate them about the issue and make them aware of the potential consequences if they don‚Äôt take action.

### **2. Agitation**

Once you‚Äôve identified the problem, it‚Äôs time to agitate it so your reader understands the full extent of the issue.

This is where you need to be careful not to come across as too sales-y or pushy. The goal is simply to get them to realize that this is a problem worth solving.

For example, let‚Äôs say plaque can lead to gum disease, which can lead to tooth loss.

If that‚Äôs not enough to get them interested in your product, you could also mention that gum disease has been linked to other health problems like heart disease and stroke.

### **3. Solution**

Finally, you need to offer a solution to the problem.

This is where you introduce your product or service and explain how it can help solve their specific challenge.

Be sure to focus on the benefits rather than the features so that your reader can easily see how your solution will make their life better.

In our toothbrush example, you might talk about how your product removes plaque more effectively than traditional toothbrushes, making it easier for them to keep their teeth healthy and avoid gum disease.

You could also mention that it‚Äôs gentle on sensitive gums and comes with a money-back satisfaction guarantee.

This 1 LinkedIn rule changed everything for me: Everything I share ‚Üí it has to be applicable NOW Not 24 hours from now. Not 3 whole months from now. Right away. As soon as you read my post. This creates a "masterclass" feeling in all my content. Because you don't just "receive good information". You are 100% certain you can apply it too. Because "it's that easy to apply". The second I started doing this, every post did 1k+. You might think it's a small, meaningless detail but... I see the 'applicable' factor missing in so many posts. The information might be valuable... but I can't 'use' it. "Valuable" content? No. "Applicable" content. Applicable now. P.S. I'm dropping my 1st LinkedIn Masterclass soon!

title: Fr√•n WS med Tom Jenkins
body:
<aside>
üìå

Syftet med att ta fram **operativa modeller** utifr√•n tavlan √§r att skapa en **styrbar och m√§tbar l√§nk mellan strategi och utf√∂rande**.

Det handlar inte bara om struktur ‚Äì utan om att g√∂ra organisationens v√§rdeskapande arbete **f√∂ruts√§gbart, transparent och f√∂rb√§ttringsdrivet**.

</aside>

### **K√§rnsyfte**

Att etablera ett **operativt system** som:

1. **√ñvers√§tter ledningens m√•l** (t.ex. Target 2030) till konkreta prioriteringar och planer.
2. **Kopplar dessa planer till f√∂rm√•gor**, med tydliga kontrakt, ansvar och fl√∂den mellan dem.
3. **Standardiserar arbetss√§tt** via playbooks, assessments och gemensamma principer.
4. **M√§ter och f√∂rb√§ttrar resultatet** kontinuerligt ‚Äì genom KPI:er, automatisering och l√§rande.

---

### **Resultatet av modellen**

- Ett **styrbart nav** f√∂r hur verksamheten fungerar i praktiken (PMO, processer, IT, management).
- **Kontrakt och gr√§nssnitt** mellan aff√§r, IT och st√∂dprocesser.
- En **m√§tbar koppling mellan kundv√§rde, datafl√∂de och interna f√∂rm√•gor**.
- Ett underlag f√∂r **kontinuerliga f√∂rb√§ttringar och automation** mot l√•ngsiktiga m√•l (2030).

![IMG_0580.png](Fr%C3%A5n%20WS%20med%20Tom%20Jenkins/IMG_0580.png)

| **Del** | **Rubrik** | **Inneh√•ll / Syfte** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **1** | PLAN | Kapabilitetsprioritering, styrning, m√•l och roadmap. |
| **2** | MANAGEMENT / PMO | Koordinera och driva f√∂r√§ndringsplaner. |
| **3** | TRANSFORMATION PLAN | Kopplar nul√§ge till m√•lbild (2030). |
| **4** | OPERATIONAL PRINCIPLES | Definierar hur organisationen arbetar ‚Äì kontrakt, fl√∂den, data. |
| **5** | CONTRACT FLOW | Definierar ansvar mellan funktioner (kundintegration, finans, API). |
| **6** | PLAYBOOK & ASSESSMENT | Standarder, m√§tningar, och m√•lbild per f√∂rm√•ga. |
| **7** | OUTPUT / UT | F√∂rb√§ttringar, automation, kontinuerlig utveckling av f√∂rm√•gor. |

## **√ñversikt: Operativa modeller**

Tavlan verkar visa ett fl√∂de fr√•n **strategi och planering (v√§nster)** ‚Üí **utf√∂rande och styrning (mitten)** ‚Üí **p√•verkan p√• f√∂rm√•gor och resultat (h√∂ger)**.

Temat √§r att skapa en **operativ modell** som l√§nkar **ledningens prioriteringar** till **kontrakt, processer och KPI:er** ‚Äì och vidare till **f√∂rb√§ttringar och automation**.

---

## **V√§nster sida: PLAN och Managementstruktur**

### **Rubriker / Begrepp**

- **PLAN**
- **Cap Priorities**
- **Management Dept**
- **Transformation Plan**
- **PMO**
- **CEO**
- **IT / Operations**
- **TODAY ‚Üí THEN**
- **TARGET 2030**
- **Execution Framework**
- **TEAM**
- **#WoW ‚Äì Sourcing and Internal Contracts**

### **Inneh√•ll / Tolkning**

1. **PLAN / Cap Priorities**
    - Startpunkt f√∂r det operativa arbetet.
    - Fokus p√• **kapabilitetsprioritering** (Cap priorities) som kopplas till verksamhetsm√•l.
    - Pilar visar fl√∂det fr√•n strategi till exekvering.
2. **Management Dept**
    - En struktur med olika niv√•er: ‚ÄúCEO ‚Üí Management Dept ‚Üí PMO ‚Üí IT‚Äù.
    - Kanske beskriver rollerna som ansvarar f√∂r plan, styrning och leverans.
    - P√• tavlan syns √§ven ‚ÄúCon.‚Äù och ‚ÄúOn.‚Äù vilket kan vara *Continuous* / *Ongoing* arbete.
3. **Transformation Plan / PMO**
    - PMO (Project Management Office) verkar b√§ra ansvaret f√∂r att driva **transformationsplanen**.
    - ‚ÄúTransformation Plan‚Äù l√§nkas till ‚ÄúExecution Framework‚Äù.
    - M√∂jligen ett programkontor som koordinerar olika initiativ.
4. **Then / Now**
    - ‚ÄúToday ‚Üí Then‚Äù visar f√∂rflyttningen mellan nul√§ge och m√•l.
    - ‚ÄúTarget 2030‚Äù visar en l√•ngsiktig vision.
    - ‚ÄúExecution Framework / Team‚Äù visar organisationens operativa motor.
5. **WoW**
    - St√•r sannolikt f√∂r **Ways of Working**.
    - Anteckningen ‚ÄúSourcing and internal contracts‚Äù tyder p√• att man vill skapa interna avtal eller kontrakt mellan f√∂rm√•gor och funktioner.

---

## **Mitten: Operativa principer och fl√∂de**

### **Rubriker / Begrepp**

- **Operational Principles (OR. PRINCIPLES)**
- **Contract / Flow**
- **New Customer Integration**
